PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Medicare
To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilising chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bolkus (from 20 citizens) and Haines (from 60 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain elected representatives and officers of local governments in Australia shows that:
General revenue grants to local government under personal income tax sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2 per cent in 1983-84 over 1982-83,
The inflation rate over the same period was 11.2 per cent
The increase in grants to State Governments over the same period was 11.8 per cent,
Increased demands are being made on local government authorities to participate in Federal Government programs e.g., Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in general revenue grants to local government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act of 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to Local Government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Lewis (from 13 citizens) and Withers (from 17 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and requests the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Wynyard Airport, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Tasmania shows:
(a) We are shocked and disappointed at the Federal Government's decision not to upgrade the Wynyard Airport.
(b) This decision will inevitably lead to downgrading and closure of the Wynyard Airport.
(c) Closure of Wynyard Airport will cause grave hardship and inconvenience to the people of the North West and West Coast regions of Tasmania.
(d) We urge the Federal Government to immediately reverse this disastrous decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Meat Export Inspection Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

1. That Australia's meat exports are being placed in an uncompetitive position by the imposition of substantial export meat inspection charges whilst Australia 's competitors receive free inspection plus considerable subsidies.

2. These charges are causing substantial loss of business for export abattoir operators and loss of jobs for their employees due to the disparity in inspection costs of export and non-export works arising from a 200 per cent increase in Federal Government charges at export works.

3. That immediate steps should be taken to end serious injury being done by these charges to export abattoir operators, their employees, livestock producers and all others dependent on the Australian meat and livestock industry.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government will Act to immediately suspend all export inspection charges for a period of three years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

2. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

3. We call upon the Federal Government, however, to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own special programs and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

4. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State-Territory Governments, to ensure a planned program of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Hearn (from 15 citizens) and Walters (from seven citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principled opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government, however, to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own special programmes and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State-Territory Governments, to ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1)
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
1. Undue cost to the nation at this time.

2. 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

3. The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
4. The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 19 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to:
- Undermine civil liberties and religious freedoms;
- Entrench abortion funding and render liable to action Hospitals, Doctors and Nurses, who conscientiously refuse to become involved in morally objectionable operations;
- Deny to parents their rights to insist that the school ''community'' provide an environment conducive to the development, including moral development, of their children.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of all principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Sir John Carrick (from 23 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Commonwealth Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 could be used to support the provision by the Commonwealth Government of funding, counselling, etc., for deliberately procured abortions.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled should amend the Sex Discrimination Bill so as to prevent it from being used in support of deliberately procured abortions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 534 citizens), Sir John Carrick (from 15 citizens) and Withers (from 603 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom.
It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the members of the Parliament assembled should delay the Bill and ask:
That the Government set up a Joint Parliamentary Committee to examine:
(a) the implications of the U.N. Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibilities and accountability in terms of the Convenant;
(b) the full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the U.N. Convention.
The Terms of Reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submissions sought from the interested organisations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Papers are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable senators. With the concurrence of the Senate, I ask that the list be incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The list read as follows-
1. Australian Meat Research Committee-Annual Report 1982-83-pursuant to section 17 of the Meat Research Act 1960
2. Agreement between the Government of Australia and the Government of Japan concerning Japanese Tuna Long-Line Fishing-pursuant to section 9 (c) of the Fisheries Act 1952
3. Aussat Pty Ltd-Annual Report 1983
4. Industrial Overalls-(Interim Report)-IAC Report
5. National Advisory Committee on Computers in Schools-Report
6. Implementation of the Supplementary Licence Scheme-Text of a statement by the Minister for Communications made in the House of Representatives 30 November 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I believe it is very important that the public at large should understand that, by having a look at this report, they may see a whole range of projects that the industry itself is undertaking to try to improve profitability, for the benefit of the whole nation. The summary of projects covers some 650 items, all States and a whole range of departmental pursuits, university projects and so on. There is an enormous range of projects which, hopefully, will be pursued to the benefit of the nation as a whole and will be paid for by the industry as a whole . I call upon anybody who believes that the livestock industries are asking for handouts to see what those industries are doing for themselves in a whole variety of ways. The report covers what is being done in the areas of breeding, feeding, pest control, pasture development, marketing and presentation. As I say , it covers not only the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation but also the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, universities and other pursuits. I commend the report to everybody who has an interest in seeing where the livestock industry is going and what it is doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to commend the Australian Meat Research Committee upon the publication of its annual report, which is extremely well written. I wish to congratulate those who were responsible for the description of the various projects because they are lucidly explained for lay readers-I use that term in a non-sacred sense, of course-such as I. As I say, the description of the various projects is very illuminating.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is, though, that the whole question of the levies in relation to the meat industry needs very careful consideration. Grants totalling over $10m were allocated from the Meat Research Trust Account for 1982-83. Almost $6m went to cattle and beef research, almost $4m to sheep and lamb research and further amounts to post-graduate studentship and study awards.

Matching grants paid for by the taxpayer supplement the levy on cattle, sheep and lamb slaughtering paid for by the industry. Even with all that money being available on a matching basis, it is quite clear, according to the general introductory remarks in the report, that there will be a need to reduce expenditure in 1984-85 by 25 per cent. This requirement will have a very drastic effect on the research programs which are so necessary for this very important Australian industry. That decision, with all the dire consequences and severe impact it will have, is a direct result of the recent drought and its effect on anticipated livestock slaughterings. When one combines the decline in the number of cattle available for slaughtering in the abattoirs with the additional levies that are being faced by the industry one has a very difficult prospect which has already led to the putting off of many hundreds of workers right around Australia and the closing, probably permanently, of many abattoirs.

The following levies apply to the slaughtering of cattle: Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation administration $1.20; AMRC research 35c; Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation research 3c; brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication $4; and export inspection fee $5.40. The total charge is something like $11 per head. One has an overall situation where obviously, whilst no individual levy can be said to be the straw that breaks the camel's or cattle's back, the impact of the levies combined with the declining number of cattle available for slaughter is leading to a situation where, as I say, workers are being put off and abattoirs are being closed. It is quite apparent, therefore, that there needs to be a total review of all the levies and charges. Whilst at the moment there is a plea from livestock and meat exporters for a three-year moratorium on the recently announced meat inspection levy increase which brings up the contribution of the industry to 50 per cent of the meat inspection costs, I think in isolation that proposal is perhaps going further than a government could concede. The very real impact of the cumulative effect of these levy charges has to be conceded, and I think Senator Archer is nodding in agreement, in conjunction with the fact that with the breaking of the drought and the need to build up cattle herds, there is a real need to give some breathing space. Perhaps a 12-month breathing space would be more sensible and could find more ready agreement.

The fact is, and I know that Senator Robert Ray is particularly interested in this, that there has been a very dramatic fall in the number of cattle available . Slaughtered in Australia in 1982-83 were about 9.6 million cattle and calves and 29.3 million sheep and lambs. These figures are expected to fall to about 7. 6 million cattle and calves and 26.6 million sheep and lambs in 1983-84. Obviously, farmers are restocking and building up the herds so essential to Australia's future and our future export income. In that situation, I think the Government and the industry need to look very carefully at the whole question of the various levies imposed on the industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Around Australia there is always a certain amount of apprehension about entering into agreements with foreign countries for the use or dispersal of our natural resources. This is very much the case with the new Australian-Japanese Tuna Long -Line Fishing Agreement. I do not believe that there is any need for apprehension, but I believe that there is a need to make sure that people in Australia, particularly those with fishing interests, are better informed as to what it actually implies. The Agreement provides up to 290 Japanese vessels to pay $2,275,000 for fishing in Australian territorial waters, within the 200-mile limit. It enables them to use the ports of Brisbane, Sydney, Hobart, Fremantle, Albany and Port Hedland.

This Agreement is an improvement on other international agreements, and this is something that I would certainly urge the Government and the Department of Primary Industry to take note of, in that article 5 permits bulk applications for licences. Other joint fishing ventures do not allow for this. I believe it is important that there should be heads of agreement so that things can be done in the easiest form and these international arrangements can be made to work. The preliminary Agreement provides that all the little details can be organised after the main Agreement is put into force. I think that is important because it needs to be shown that things can work and will work if they are done in that manner. As a result of discussions, it was suggested that the Australian fishing industry should have more access to Japan. The subject of whether the entry of best quality Australian tuna into the Japanese sashimi market would be difficult was discussed. The Japanese delegation informed us that there would be no particular restrictions against the Australians being able to export tuna and that market access is and will be available for such Australian fish and fish products under the Japanese import system. They would attract a tariff of 5 per cent, but apart from that they would be acceptable. I hope it will be possible to modify the Agreement in the years ahead as, I hope, more and more Australian fishermen see the possibilities of fishing in these waters which the Japanese have traditionally used but which have not been normally used by the Australian fishermen. I believe that if we follow the lead and the development that has gone on in the years past by the traditional fishermen of the area, there is still an avenue open to Australia to provide food for a world which needs it more than ever.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The paper which is before the Senate at the moment concerns, basically, the agreement between Japan and Australia on the catching of tuna. I point out to the Senate and the Government that this is one area in which the Government can fulfil its promise to create 500,000 new jobs by putting something into this industry. In Queensland at the moment there are 2 ,600 registered trawlers. There is a complete overcapacity to service the fishing ground. If the Government gave some assistance to the people of the fishing industry, to remove them from the in-shore fishing area and to help them establish a tuna industry in the outer areas, I believe it would solve two problems. Firstly, it would enable Australia to form a competitive industry to service the Japanese sashimi tuna market. Secondly, it would develop a very great export market. It would also relieve the prawning industry of Queensland whose grounds are overserviced. If the Government gave some thought and help to the fishing industry in this direction by offering fishermen grants to service their boats or tune up their boats for catching tuna and to undertake long-line fishing, I believe it would help relieve unemployment. Such assistance would establish an export fishing industry that would be of tremendous benefit to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I point out how interested I have been in the development of the concept of Australia having its own satellite, particularly because of the value this will be to people living in the remote areas of Australia. I notice that it is planned to introduce earth stations to enable remote areas to receive television . Up to the time of the introduction of the satellite, that was not possible. At the moment we share a satellite system which is assisting quite a good deal. For example, areas in South Australia are now able to receive television services from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, but these are restricted to news broadcasts from Sydney. Some people are very interested in some aspects of Sydney or New South Wales news and they do receive the major elements of national news, but they still miss out on the local element which is of great interest to the smaller communities of Australia. I know that Senator Kilgariff is very interested in the proposition. We hope that ultimately, when Aussat is in place-I understand it is due to be in place by about 1985-there will be an opportunity for commercial television to participate in a very substantial way so that not only will ABC television programs be able to be viewed in country areas but also the people in these areas will have the additional benefit of commercial services. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON COMPUTERS IN SCHOOLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is an important document which will help to provide a framework in which the development of computer education can occur. On behalf of the Opposition, I congratulate the National Advisory Committee on Computers in Schools, which put so much effort into this report. It draws attention to the financial implications, the extent of the need for computer education, the number of activities it has to cover and the extent of those activities. At page 43 of the report, it states:

It is unrealistic to expect that the amount of funding available initially for the Computer Education Program will enable all schools to make dramatic improvements in use of information technology in general and computing in particular.

One of the problems that has come up is that the program is one which has great aspirations and, indeed, is an appropriate program. But the funding provided for it by the Government in the guidelines is inadequate. It is certainly less than the Government promised before the election and will not carry out the task. I remind honourable senators that before the election, both major political parties-I cannot speak for the Australian Democrats because I do not remember that part of their policy-went to the people with programs that included a program on computer education.

I remind the Senate also that the Commonwealth Schools Commission, before that time, had indicated, in its report, that a program was needed and indicated the amount of money that was necessary. The amount of money it identified was a need for $125m spent over five years. The program, by process of simple deduction, would require about $25m a year. The then Government went to the people with a program which added up to $100m or $20m a year over five years. The then Opposition-the now Government-offered a smaller program. That smaller program would clearly not have enabled the Australian Labor Party to achieve what the Schools Commission identified was necessary and what the Committee, in its report, still identified as necessary.

After the election and in the first set of guidelines, the Government further reduced what was available and has failed to keep what it promised before the election. It is quite clear from this report and from a statement of what is needed that the funding provided by this Government will not allow these computer education procedures to be carried out satisfactorily. I appeal to the Government that, if it is going to take any notice of this report and take seriously the commitment to computer education for young Australians, it recognise the inadequacy of the provision it has made to support the program, that it look carefully at what the Committee is saying, that it draw heavily on the expertise of the Commonwealth Schools Commission and that it think again about the funding which it has provided. It is not enough.

The kinds of activities that need to be covered include the provision of machines and hardware, the development and provision of computer software of which there is very little, the provision of coursewear, the assistance to educators, both by means of pre-service and in-service training, and the development of computer awareness for the enhancement of people's feeling of comfort when dealing with computers so that they do not feel computers are hostile or foreign. The amount of money which the Government has put up through the guidelines will not be enough for those activities to be carried out.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is more than you put up in seven years, though.

—I will go back and remind Senator Primmer, who is chattering away in the background, that we put up a much larger amount by way of promise in the election. That amount of money was of the magnitude which accorded with what the Commonwealth Schools Commission had asked should be provided.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I draw attention to the two dissenting reports which make up part of the document before us. I suggest to the Government that there is serious need to resolve the total rejection by New South Wales of the hardware recommendations in the report. Under the State system, the New South Wales Government does not accept the basis on which the hardware recommendations are predicated. Without New South Wales supporting the program, a serious difficulty will exist with its implementation. I also ask that the Government give careful consideration to the other dissenting report, by my old school colleague Paul Jeremy, in which he draws attention to the same problem, and to a failure adequately to address the need for courseware development in computing.
Again, this is a very important report. I hope that the Government will give it a considered response. When it is given, I hope that the response can be discussed in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report by the National Advisory Committee on Computers in Schools is long overdue. The fact that it is overdue is responsible, partly at least, for some of the comments in the two dissenting reports. I think we all agree with the comment in chapter 3 of the report that in Australian society schools should provide students with knowledge of the electronic information technologies and with skills in their use, and that this should be a very broad spectrum knowledge, not limited to the science and mathematics faculties but developing into all faculties. That is because the new literacy in the 1990s and the next century will be computer literacy, and it should not be limited only to the two faculties which seem to see some sort of proprietorial aspect to computerisation.

SPEECH.PARA: The two dissenting reports concentrate predominantly, as Senator Baume has said , on the four pieces of hardware which have been selected. The Committee went into considerable detail and went to considerable effort to look at what was being done in the individual States in Australia before it made any recommendation. From contacts that I have in schools in various States, I know that there was concern that this would not happen and that the most populous State, New South Wales, would have an unnecessary amount of say in the Committee 's final recommendation about the hardware that it approved for school use. That has not happened. The Committee has taken note of the decisions that have been made, in particular, by the South Australian, Western Australian and Tasmanian governments to recommend the BBC computer system for government school use. The non-government schools in those States have had a tendency to follow suit.

That action was made necessary by lack of attention to the need for a national program for computer technology by the previous Government. There is no question about that. Each was forced into investigating the best sort of hardware for that State simply because the previous Federal Government had closed its eyes to the need for an assessment of computer technology at a national level. As a consequence, we got a plethora of recommendations from State to State. Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania adopted the BBC, which, interestingly enough, is one of the few computer systems that were specifically designed for teaching purposes. Perhaps my own bias in that line is enhanced by the fact that I believe Australian schools probably have more cultural connections with something that emanates from Britain, with the appropriate software to match, than with some American software, with the peculiarities of language that Americans use. The Microbee 16 and the Apple II were the computers that were accepted by the New South Wales Government. To the best of my knowledge, the Victorian Governmment was still playing around with its investigations at that stage.

One of the dissenting reports complains about the fact that 16K models of computers have been excluded. They have been excluded for a fairly good reason. Basically, the Committee's report has come down in favour of the BBC Acorn, with or without a couple of component support systems, the Microbee 64 and the Apple II and Apple IIe. Given the problems that the Committee had of combining the already determined recommendations of the different States for computer systems in their States, I think it did all that was possible under the circumstances. Of course, it has added a rider that support should also be provided for professional development and consultancy activities directed at other machines recommended by participating systems and that the list of recommended microcomputers should be regularly reviewed in the light of changes in technology and school needs. As I have said, given the problems facing the Committee, it is to be commended on its recommendations and the detail in this report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: IMPLEMENTATION OF THE SUPPLEMENTARY LICENCE SCHEME

PROCTEXT.PARA: Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a very interesting development. The Senate will remember that last December we debated at some length in a first class debate the proposals of the then Minister for Communications, Mr Neil Brown, for supplementary licences. As I understand it, it was a brainchild of Mr Tony Staley. It was a brilliant idea to give country provincial towns another service by granting a supplementary licence, essentially, to the holders of existing licences. This was a way in which country towns could quickly receive another television channel or radio outlet.

Controversy raged about giving a supplementary licence to a company that held an existing licence. Concentration of ownership in a country town was a quite proper concern for people to raise at that time. Senator Button raised it in a responsible way when he was in opposition. The reason for Mr Staley's original thinking was that very few country towns in Australia could support two television stations. Very few country towns could support another independent radio station. Yet there is a need in those towns for another station. I have a great deal of admiration for the local television station here in Canberra. It does a magnificent job, particularly running a one-hour news service, half of which is devoted to local news. Those of us who sometimes spend an evening here with nothing to do are not terribly enamoured--

TALK.START.PARA: —We like it.
—If Senator Ryan likes Cop Shop, followed by Prisoner-
—No, we like the local news.
—Indeed. I am not critical of its running Prisoner, Cop Shop and others--
—And the other rubbish.

—I was being more kind than that. They are popular programs. I do not blame the commercial station. Apparently the majority of people in Canberra think those programs are marvellous. They add to the revenue. But the fact is that a great number of the people of Canberra want another television station. It is extremely doubtful whether it would be economically viable if all the infrastructure for a new television channel were established. That was the motivation behind Mr Staley's brilliant idea. The original Bill was passed, as I understand it, not implemented or proclaimed. The present Minister for Communications, Mr Duffy, is to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act in a different way so as to make concentration of ownership a major issue. Without trying to be mischievous, I just give Mr Duffy and the Government a warning that the Australian Democrats and I am sure the Liberal Party-and the National Party, indeed, as it has a vested interest in this matter because it represents country areas-will be looking very closely at the terms of that Bill because if on the first criterion, that there is concentration of ownership, the licence cannot be given to that existing station, that would virtually disqualify every holder of every country television licence at the moment. That would be ridiculous; it would be absurd. Mr Duffy, however, has inserted some criteria:

SPEECH.PARA: A supplementary licence will not be granted . . . if a thorough investigation by the ABT determines that an extra independent commercial service, the first and preferred option, is commercially viable and in the public interest.

I do not think anybody would object to that but it will depend on the way in which it is worded in the Act. Finally, I am very concerned at the development of Aussat Pty Ltd. A significant paragraph in this morning's Australian Financial Review states:
The supplementary scheme dovetails with the intended use of the satellite by the major Sydney and Melbourne broadcasting networks.

That is ominous and I will be keeping a very close eye on that to make sure that country towns throughout Australia will not be the prisoners of the three major networks via the satellite. Some protection has to be given to those areas so that people in outback areas are not fed only those kinds of programs. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SECOND COMMONWEALTH CONFERENCE ON DELEGATED LEGISLATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report, Documents and Transcript

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator COATES

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report, documents and transcript of proceedings of the Second Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation, held in Ottawa in April 1983.

INTERJECT.PARA: Ordered that the report, documents and transcript be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I will speak briefly to this motion, which I have moved mainly to allow honourable senators who were associated with the Conference to speak. In April this year the Regulations and Ordinances Committee sent a delegation, consisting of Senators Lewis, Missen and Tate, to the Second Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation, which was held in Ottawa, with the Canadian counterpart of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee as the host. The first conference was held in October 1980 in Canberra, and was arranged by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee at the request of a number of equivalent Commonwealth committees, whose members felt they would benefit from an exchange of experiences and ideas.

It was fitting that Australia should have been the host for the first conference, because we have at the federal level the oldest and one of the most advanced systems for the parliamentary control of delegated legislation, through the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. It was the first such committee to be established in the Commonwealth, in 1932, and through the statutory provisions for the disallowance of delegated legislation which have been built up over the years. One has only to look at some other countries, where delegated legislation is subject to little or no parliamentary control and has got completely out of hand, to realise how fortunate Australia has been.

The Ottawa conference was pronounced by those who participated in it as an outstanding success in continuing and extending the exchange of information and co-operation between the various committees throughout the Commonwealth. The report, which has been produced by the Canadian committee, is a valuable statement of the determination of parliamentarians throughout the Commonwealth to ensure proper parliamentary accountability of delegated law-making.

Unfortunately, copies of the report and associated documents are in short supply, but limited numbers are available from the Senate Records and Table Office. By moving for the printing of the papers I have ensured that they will be reproduced in the parliamentary papers series and widely distributed, as was done with the papers of the first conference. I commend the report to the Senate .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I wish to speak briefly in support of the motion and to urge members of the Senate in particular to get hold of a copy of the report of the Second Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation, which is a fairly short document and which summarises the major matters which were raised at the conference. As you know, Mr Deputy President, and as has been said, we in Australia have taken the lead in getting such conferences under way. As one who chaired the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances between the last Conference and this one, it was not always easy to keep in complete contact with parliaments, especially as one member of the last conference was in a parliament which disappeared during the three years between meetings and he was not heard of again by us. But the continuation of this process of consultation among the parliaments, all of which are struggling with the problem of delegated legislation, its control and the relationship between government and parliament and the rights and abilities of the Parliament to scrutinise and to disallow, are matters of continual interest. It is a fact that in Australia, not only in the Commonwealth but also in the State spheres, there is a considerable power of disallowance which one can say is stronger than in any other parliament. Many of them look to us for a lead and hope to emulate the example in Australia which has continued for over 50 years now.

SPEECH.PARA: I think there were some 16 parliaments represented at the first conference, including some state and provincial parliaments. In the conference held in April this year, 26 parliaments were represented and there was therefore a much wider range of exchange. The new committee which has been elected to continue this process covers all continents. Senator Austin Lewis is the representative for Australasia, and I am on it as past Chairman. It is a committee now which has in mind going ahead with the review and the study of the procedures, precedents and practices of the various parliaments dealing with delegated legislation.

When one looks at the report one will see that many common and separate problems are discussed. The report is self-contained and I think gives a lot of information. There is also the publication 'Documents of the Conference Volume 2 ' which includes the excellent paper which Senator Michael Tate prepared and presented to the conference on the scrutiny of Bills operation which is a development analogous to but not quite the same, of course, as delegated legislation matters, as it deals with Bills rather than with delegated legislation. The third of the documents is the transcript of the proceedings in which honourable senators will see the discussion that took place-and it was quite controversial discussion-over the way in which Parliament ought to control the making of delegated legislation. It is clear that the same powers do not exist in Canada and the Canadians suffer very considerably from the inability to get their motions in regard to delegated legislation and criticism of it onto the agenda so that they can be debated by the Parliament. As honourable senators know by the use of notices of disallowance no such problem occurs in Australia. Once notice is given, the matter must be dealt with.

Other problems which are covered in this report and which were discussed at this conference include government responses to reports and government responses to criticism of delegated legislation and the way it is handled in different countries. This includes the proposals in regard to notice of and comment on proposed delegated legislation. There is great public interest in what is often called 'deregulation' but what I think ought to be called 'regulatory reform', which is a field where no simple answers are to be found. But the giving of notice and allowing public comment before regulations come in is very popular in other countries and I hope that we will experiment with it in Australia to a much greater degree than we have in the past.

The report discusses problems relating to international regulations-for example , Britain and the Common Market-and the way in which parliaments can have any control over those regulations. Another topic mentioned, which is probably more appropriate to Australia, is the problem in a federal system of dealing with uniformity of legislation, such as company legislation and for the individual regulatory committees really to have any control because it is a uniform matter. If one does not adopt it, there is trouble. I think a great problem will arise here when we try to bring uniformity into our system in that we may squash out the ability of committees of the Parliament to be able effectively to criticise the proposals. The important question of the assessability of delegated legislation is a problem here as it is elsewhere. One should not have to tell the people of the Australian Capital Territory about the regulations which affect them and which have not been brought up to date for many years. The problem of people knowing the law as it affects them is one that is common to a lot of countries.

The Conference was an outstanding success, magnificently organised by the Canadian authorites. It was held in the Senate chamber in Ottawa and the delegation went to Montreal and Toronto and had discussions there with other members of the parliaments of Canada. I believe this type of getting together of parliamentarians, not just in a socialising way but in analysing the problems, enhances the opportunities of parliaments to reassert themselves as an important feature of government. The next Conference will probably be held in India in two or three years' time. I believe the development of such conferences is well worthwhile. Australia has given a lead by providing, among other things, the printing of the various journals of the conferences. The Senate has taken on that task and is continuing with it for the moment. It is a valuable exchange of information between all parliaments. It is a very worthwhile exercise. My colleagues who attended, Senator Lewis and Senator Michael Tate, and Mr Harry Evans from the staff of the Parliament all did splendid jobs during that Conference. I think Australia's standing in this area is in good shape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of my colleague Senator Missen on the Second Commonwealth Conference on Delegated Legislation. To carry on from where he left off, I agree that Australia was very well represented, not only by the three senators, but also by Mr Harry Evans of the Senate staff who, notwithstanding that he was most unwell for various days of the Conference, attended all of the sessions. He did very well despite his illness. Of course, he is very knowledgeable in this field and was of great assistance to those of us attending. Professor Dennis Pearce, Dean of the Faculty of Law at the Australian National University and counsel to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills also attended and made very worthwhile contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: I also congratulate those who organised the Conference in Canada, the members of the Canadian Parliament and the Canadian Standing Joint Committee on Regulations and Other Statutory Instruments and, in particular, Mr Graham Eglington, an Australian lawyer working in Canada who was the Conference Secretary and at some stage counsel to the Canadian Committee. Mr Eglington really worked very hard. He has very much at heart the interests of those parliamentarians who are concerned about the supervision of delegated legislation. Let me say also a sincere thank you to the Australian Government, because the proposal to visit this Conference was made under the former Government. As we know, there was than a change of government. This Conference was held in April of this year. The new Government approved the delegation's attendance at the Conference and all of us thank the Government for carrying out the previous Government's agreement.

Let me turn now to the Conference. Twenty-seven jurisdictions from the the Commonwealth were represented at the Conference, and a total of 75 official delegates attended. Many official observers and academic observers were present. It is a pity that no Australian States were represented. I think that is a great pity because Australian States have very good delegated legislation and supervisory committees. It is a pity that no State felt that it could afford to send delegates to this Conference. The delegates represented, of course, not only bicameral parliaments such as ours but also unicameral and one-part parliaments. The difficulties associated with having a delegated legislation committee in a one-party parliament must be almost unbelievable. However, great strength for the protection of parliamentary rights was shown by all delegates and I hope that honourable senators will have an opportunity to read pages 9, 10 and 11 of the report in particular, if they do not get a chance to read the whole report. I would like to quote from the first paragraph of the report so that it will be in Hansard and so that I may draw it to the attention of this Government, of the shadow Executive, of all Executives and of the media. It seems to me a great pity that the Australian media do not understand what the disallowance of a regulation means. The passage I wish to quote is:
. . . most Commonwealth governments are unwilling to countenance disallowance of a regulation by Parliament or the failure of an affirmative resolution on a regulation.
The last sentence relates, of course, to the British system; it is not applicable to Australia.
I quote further:

Some governments are even unwilling to accept the adoption of a scrutiny committee's report critical of a regulation. Each government feels, or purports to believe, quite unnecessarily and erroneously that the governments life, or at least its standing, is at stake.
It is important to note that delegates expressed their realisation that parliamentarians were being thwarted by a twisted representation of the doctrine of responsible government. The report adds:

It is no part of that doctrine that a government must win every vote on every issue in both Houses. The loss of a vote on a motion in one House or even in a unicameral parliament, to disallow a regulation . . . can very, very rarely amount to a question of confidence in the Ministry.

The paragraph ends by stating that delegates left the conference determined to free their parliaments and legislatures from the tyranny of this unwarranted extension of the doctrine of responsible government. I hope that honourable senators, and the media also, will note that observation in particular. Fortunately, in Australia, as a result of the activities of the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee, governments do not really take that to heart so much, although from time to time we have heard Ministers appear to argue that the disallowance of a regulation would mean the end of the Government , that the Government would have to fall. As has been indicated in the report, that is absolute nonsense. Of course a disallowance motion does not represent a vote of confidence or otherwise in the Government. I wish that journalists and media representatives would understand that these are Houses of a parliament, not Houses of an executive government; that Parliament must be able to retain powers to dissallow or amend legislation, even to throw it out, and to disallow regulations and ordinances in full or in part without a government being at risk , as if it were subject to a confidence vote.

Senator Missen dealt with most of the report but I would like to mention one or two other aspects of it. The Conference did become involved in discussion about the scrutiny of delegated legislation on its merits, that is to say, on its policy content and its substantive effect on people, as well as on its form. That is perhaps a little technical to go into at this stage. The Conference was very impressed by the Australian experiment in the form of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and the paper presented by Senator Tate was very well received. The comments made by Senators Tate and Missen and Dr Pearce were also very well put and received. Finally, let me mention another matter, in relation to which I will again quote from the report. I refer to the problem of quasi-law. I hope that honourable senators will take note of what I am about to read:
The Conference was clearly put on notice of the need to be careful lest the issuing of guidelines, manuals and circulars-
which they call quasi-law-

. . . allow governments to undermine and circumvent the scrutiny and control measures in respect of delegated legislation won by parliaments with so much difficulty. Just as there has been a slide from legislating by statute to legislating by regulation, so there is the danger of a slide from the use of detailed regulations to governments achieving their policy ends by issuing directions as to how officials shall carry out their functions and exercise their directions granted by statute or by delegated legislation. Unless these directions are subject to parliamentary control and scrutiny, a large body of the rules actually applied to citizens will pass under the unfettered power of the executive.

I know that Australia has had some experience in this regard and I am delighted to be able to remind the Parliament that when the uranium guidelines were brought down by the former Government they were brought down in such a manner that they could be disallowed and considered. I would hope that the Attorney- General, Senator Gareth Evans, who in the past has indicated that he believes in parliamentary control and scrutiny of all forms of legislation, would consider making this a matter of policy for the Government. I thank the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND GOVERNMENT OPERATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations, I present a report dated December 1983 on the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust and Commissioner for Superannuation annual reports 1980-81, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This annual report was referred to the Standing Committee for investigation and report on the causes of the delay in its tabling, and matters raised by the Auditor-General. After examining the report and considering comments from the Commissioner for Superannuation, the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance, the Committee held a one-day hearing earlier this year to take evidence.

There are two reasons for the delay of some 16 months in the tabling of the report: The introduction of a new accounting policy for the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust during the financial year 1980-81, which meant that financial statements were not prepared until almost 12 months after the end of the financial year, and the time taken for completion of the Auditor-General's examination of the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust financial statements. In chapter 2 we note that these two factors resulted in an inevitable but unacceptable delay in reporting to the Parliament.

Three matters were the subject of comment by the Auditor-General in his report to the Minister: The incomplete reconciliation of control accounts maintained by the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office; overdrawing of the Superannuation Fund Account, and consolidation of accounts for certain property unit trusts in which the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust has an interest. The Committee discussed these matters and made its comments in chapter 3 of the report.

As a final matter, having dealt with the 1980-81 report, the Committee notes with concern that the reports for 1981-82 and 1982-83 have still not been tabled -17 and five months respectively after the end of the financal year. Seventeen months is even later than the 1980-81 report was presented and such lateness ought to be unacceptable. The Committee has accordingly recommended that an interim report be tabled in accordance with the recommendations we have made in our fifth report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 213th report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Report 213 of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts documents the Committee's investigation of the administration of a wide range of income maintenance programs. In the study, income maintenance programs are taken to be those programs transferring cash to individuals or organisations for the purposes of social welfare. The Committee considered aspects of the administration of 127 programs as operated by 10 Commonwealth Government departments in 1981-82. The fact that the Commonwealth operated a total of 127 income maintenance programs is in itself striking. The cost was in excess of $14,000m annually. The programs considered included income replacement programs, for example, unemployment benefit; income supplement programs, for example, tertiary allowances; and programs subsidising expenditure, for example, free medical services.

SPEECH.PARA: This report has two volumes. Volume 1 is a discussion paper. It presents, in a fairly compact form, information and comment on the many programs considered and also lists a number of reference sources to assist further investigation in the area. Volume 2 is a reference document which has extensive descriptive material on each program considered. The methodology of the Committee's inquiry involved seeking material from departments on how the particular income maintenance program was initiated; the direct and administrative costs of the program; the number of beneficiaries; and the extent of program evaluation. These submissions were supplemented by public hearings with officers of three departments surveyed -namely, the Departments of Social Security, Veterans' Affairs and Employment and Industrial Relations. The Committee also received information from four agencies whose activities span more than one functional area. These agencies were the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Finance , the Public Service Board and the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat.

The Committee examined the information with three guiding principles in mind. These principles were: 'Mandate', 'management' and 'evaluation'. These three concepts capture the questions: 'What is the program's objective?'; 'how well is the objective being achieved?'; and, finally, 'when should the program be modified?'. The three concepts of 'mandate', 'management' and 'evaluation' provide the framework for Volume 1. They establish a structure for the presentation of information on departmental programs, provoke comment about specific aspects of a department's administration and influence the discussion of general issues. While the Committee has made a number of findings from its inquiry, and these are set out in the final chapter of Volume 1 of the report, the Committee emphasises that the findings should be addressed, appreciating the nature of the document.

Volume 1 is a discussion paper, as I mentioned earlier, and the Committee's conclusions and findings are presented to stimulate further discussion and analysis of the issues. The Committee recommends that a task force be established to review current social welfare administrative practices. The Committee sees its proposed task force composed of representatives of the Department of Finance, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Public Service Board and the Social Welfare Policy Secretariat very much in the light of stimulating further dicussion and analysis of the issues. The Committee suggests that the task force consider improvements in current administrative practice, bearing in mind the Committee's findings in respect of 'mandate', ' management' and 'evaluation'. The Committee also finds that the task force should consider alternative approaches to social welfare administration, including that of a guaranteed minimum income. The Committee hopes that the two volumes of report 213 on the administration of income maintenance programs will provide a basis for further exploration of this area both within and outside government circles.

Finally, let me comment briefly regarding responses by departments to the conclusions and findings in this report 213. As my colleagues would be aware, the Department of Finance minute procedures are designed to ensure that appropriate action is taken in response to comments contained in the Committee's reports. The Committee realises that the format of this report may require a somewhat different approach. While the Committee appreciates the challenge this discussion paper may present, it is reasonable to expect that the members of the proposed task force would address the tasks set out in Volume 1 and prepare the response to the Committee. I commend the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts undertook a massive task in regard to income maintenance programs. A tremendous amount of research was undertaken and I thank the staff of the Committee for their energy and dedication. In particular I must acknowledge the work of Mr Tom O'Brien who did much of the research on the discussion paper. We decided to produce a discussion paper because we realised fairly quickly that there was much to comment upon and we also appreciated the difficulty of making specific recommendations in this area. We came to the conclusion that what was needed was a discussion paper which would lead to further analysis of the problem of the massive income maintenance programs which have developed over the years.

SPEECH.PARA: Some concern must be expressed that many programs do not have sufficient legislative support. We have heard people in this place talk about delegated legislation. I think that we now ought to accept that we should be prepared to look at delegated financial responsibility which is not supported by legislation . The Committee decided that it should produce a discussion paper rather than a report. We wanted to present the massive amount of material and information in a form that would lead to substantial further investigation of the problem. Having reduced the material to a readable form, we now expect that the responses of the various departments involved will lead to further investigation at some future date which may enable if not this Committee, perhaps another committee, to make some firm recommendations.

The amount of moneys spent on income maintenance, as Senator Maguire pointed out, is massive. The cost of administration involved in applying these moneys is also massive and one gets the impression that administration is not properly co- ordinated and is expensive when compared with the total moneys which reach the recipient. There needs to be a considerable amount of administrative change in order to reduce these costs.

We found that, where legislation gave the direction, the programs were much more effectively administered. One must give some credit to the Department of Social Security and to the Department of Veterans' Affairs in that they have a definite goal in mind. That goal has been defined by legislation which has been to their advantage. The problem arises in the areas where flexibility has been needed and where moneys have been applied by executive determination. Programs are set in motion, moneys are expended and no further evaluation of the need for and the level of that type of support has been made. I commend this document as a very important document. It is, I believe, the first attempt to make an assessment of the level and the cost of income maintenance.

A suggestion has been made in this report that we ought to be looking at another means of supplying support to the needy and the underprivileged within the community and that we ought to give them a guaranteed minimum support, a minimum income. That is a problem which needs substantial investigation on the part of governments. In order for governments to investigate the problem substantially, I believe that committees of the Senate can do substantial work to assist whichever government may be in power. I further commend the report and I reiterate that much credit needs to be given to the staff and the secretariat of the Public Accounts Committee for the massive task which they engaged in and for the result which has been brought before the Senate today.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PASSENGER FARES AND SERVICES TO AND FROM TASMANIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.
