DEBATE.TITLE: BANK ACCOUNTS DEBITS TAX LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
TAXATION ADMINISTRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983]
Debate resumed from 18 November 1983, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President , may I suggest that the Senate have a general debate covering the Bank Account Debits Tax Legislation Amendment Bill and the Taxation Administration Amendment Bill.
—Is it the wish of the Senate to have a general debate covering the two Bills? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Bank Account Debits Tax Legislation Amendment Bill. It is necessary to amend the legislation in this way because of doubts that were expressed about the constitutional validity of giving the banks the right of recovery of this tax from account holders. The amendment has our support. We understand the reason for it, although it has not been subjected to litigation. We understand that the constitutional validity question has been raised. Therefore, we would not wish to hold up the amendment. I take this opportunity to make one or two comments about the operation of the bank debits tax.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand this tax, it is currently under review by the Government. I place before the Government that one of the problems it should consider in reviewing the operation of the tax is the interrelationship of this tax with the financial institutions' duties tax in the various States. New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania and South Australia have levied a financial institutions' tax . It would seem to me that there ought to be some rationalisation between the States and the Commonwealth with regard to the operation of these similar taxes. I think it may be appropriate for the Commonwealth Government to investigate whether there ought to be the establishment of some uniform approach or at least some arrangements that would operate better for those who are required to pay tax on financial negotiations. I think this could improve the efficiency of the collection of the tax. It would certainly be a welcome relief to the users of cheque accounts and other financial instruments throughout Australia. That is just one area. I hope that in the current review which the Government is undertaking some attention can be given to this matter.

Another problem that could be considered in this context is that the States' financial institutions duty attracts bank account debits tax as the States' charges appear as debits on cheque accounts. Often financial institutions' duty of only a few cents attracts bank account debits tax. That is one of the details which, I am sure, will be subjected to the review I mentioned.

The other matter to which I draw attention, and which was mentioned by the shadow Treasurer in the other place, was the matter of exemptions that can be given or should be given to charitable and non-profit organisations. The former Treasurer conceded that when he introduced the original legislation he made an error in judgment. He had sought a method of exempting charitable and non-profit organisations. On the advice of the Commissioner of Taxation he relied upon the exemption precedent available in the stamp duty legislation of the Government of New South Wales. That has not brought all of the exemptions that we would have considered appropriate or that we expected would be covered by the clause that he had inserted in the original proposal. Again, as the operation of the bank debits tax is under review, I think it would be timely to look at the exemption of charitable and non-profit organisations to see that they do not suffer the imposition of the tax in a way that was certainly not intended when it was introduced.

I am sure that a number of other matters will be subjected to the review. I hope that it will not be long before we see some reaction from the Government to the review of the tax that was introduced as one way of raising revenue. The former Treasurer acknowledged that it was not a perfect way of imposing tax, but it was a means of collecting further revenue for the Commonwealth. We have run into the fact that some of the States have used similar methods of raising revenue for their own purposes. With those brief comments, on behalf of the Opposition I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

The Taxation Administration Amendment Bill is supported by the Opposition. We have noted the arrangements under the system which has been proposed by which summonses will be served by ordinary post and, after conviction, a procedure will be followed which will enable the defendant to be advised by ordinary post of conviction and the amount of the fine and 21 days will be allowed for payment of the fine. The other provisions within the Bill raise no objections in our minds. We believe that in the purpose of administration it is a useful amendment that can be introduced at this stage. It is one that has our support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — The original bank account debits tax legislation was introduced last year by the previous Government. At the time it was roundly criticised by those who are now in Government. The present Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, who represented the shadow Treasurer in this place at that time, described the tax as 'inequitable, discriminatory, inflationary and counter-productive'. Indeed, he moved a motion to that effect when the legislation was presented to this Parliament by the previous Government . I supported that motion. When this Government came to power I reminded Senator Walsh, during the first week of the parliamentary sitting, what he had said about this legislation. I asked whether a review of the legislation in certain respects could take place. I followed that up with a question on 18 May 1983 specifically zeroing in on the problems affecting supporting bodies associated with non-profit schools. My question on 18 May was directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, the Minister for Energy and Resources. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it not a fact that the Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Act exempts debits made to accounts in the name of non-profit schools but this exemption does not extend to support bodies associated with the schools? Is this not a tax on the efforts of such organizations as parents and friends organizations which are designed to provide educational aids for the schools which are exempt under the Act? If so, what does the Government intend to do about it?
Senator Walsh replied to that question in the following manner:
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Legislation governing the bank account debits tax provides exemptions for debits to accounts of certain organizations, including non-profit schools, colleges and universities. A debit to a cheque account operated by these bodies is exempt from the tax provided the debit relates to a transaction carried out wholly and exclusively in furtherance of the objects of the body.

Debits made to a cheque account operated in the name of a support body of a school or college, such as a parents and citizens association or other parent body, do not come within the ambit of the exemption which the law currently provides.

The Government has undertaken to review the operation of this tax, including the appropriateness or otherwise of the exemptions contained in the law, after it has been in operation for approximately 6 months. Many representations have been received from school support organizations and other non-profit bodies in the community seeking exemption from the tax and these will be carefully considered in the course of the review.
In the second reading speech by the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) on the Bank Accounts Debit Tax Legislation Amendment Bill, he said:

The legislation was enacted in 1982 and the former Government announced before the election last March that 1 April 1983 would be proclaimed as the date of commencement of the tax. Following the election, the necessary formal proclamation was made, but we, as the new Government, announced that the operation of the tax, including the appropriateness or otherwise of exemptions, would be reviewed after approximately six months. That review is now in course and an announcement will be made after the review has been completed and the Government has taken decisions arising out of it.

Of course, you realise, Mr Deputy President, that six months has elapsed since 1 April and still the review apparently has not been completed as promised. I would have liked to see this legislation come before us together with the results of the review and the Government's decisions. A number of organisations are experiencing a burden and should not be experiencing a burden. I have mentioned supporting bodies such as parents and friends organisations of schools . But there are other organisations such as the Girl Guides Association and the boy scouts organisations. To exemplify the situation in which those organisations find themselves, may I read a letter I received from the Girl Guides Association of Tasmania which expresses very succinctly, the problems that it is experiencing. The letter, in part, states:
The Girl Guides Association, soon to celebrate its 75th year of voluntary service to the youth of Australia, is, by the very nature of its membership structure, severely disadvantaged by the Act.
The Association has always encouraged all units and divisional bodies to use cheque accounts as a method of security for the public monies that they handle.

Some idea of the considerable number of cheques written daily by all sections of the Association, and on all of which this Debits Tax is currently paid, can be gauged from the fact that in Tasmania alone there are 210 Guide units operating throughout the State and with 73 Districts, 17 Divisions, 9 Trefoil Guilds, 76 Local Associations (parent support groups), not to mention the State Executive and its associated committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know all that?
—I am reading a letter from the State Secretary of the Girl Guides Association, Mrs Ann Breeze. The letter continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Cheque accounts are operated at all these levels.

Since Guide units meet each week, there is a considerable flow of public monies both upwards and downwards within the Guiding Movement (e.g. unit quota payments to higher bodies, executive payments to units for specially needed assistance); and also payments of monies outside the movement (e.g. hall rentals, equipment purchases, donations to charitable organisations).
The letter finally states:

The Girl Guide Association is a voluntarily run, public, non-profit organisation, primarily serving the youth of this State, and of course Australia . We are sure that, at least in spirit, organisations such as ours would have been excluded from this unique tax in the minds of its legislators.

I am sure that is true. As was indicated by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle this morning, it appears it was a mistaken impression on the part of the previous Treasurer, who acted on advice, that these sorts of organisations have been caught. The sooner we release them from the burden the better. If that is the experience of organisations in Tasmania we can multiply that 10 times for the rest of Australia.

Another organisation that is committed by its charter to service to the community-in fact, its motto is 'Service above self-he profits most who serves best'-is the Rotary organisation. That organisation has been caught by the bank account debits tax. I have copies of letters sent to various Rotary Clubs by the Australian Taxation Office-the Rotary Clubs of Glenorchy, Devonport, South Launceston, Launceston, Hobart, New Norfolk, Georgetown, Longford, Kangaroo Bay, Rosetta, Lindisfarne and Newnham. I have a letter from the past governor of Rotary, Jock Geeves, who expresses the issue quite succinctly. Having forwarded a copy of the program of Rotary, to which all clubs must subscribe in their constitution, he points out the following:

You will note that the Ideal of Service is the foundation of the organisation, and this Ideal of Service is invariably translated by Rotary clubs into charitable and educational projects, with millions of dollars being raised and spent throughout the world annually by Rotary clubs.

I am aware of the work that Rotary does in the various fields of charitable activity in Tasmania. I am sure that the Taxation Office is somewhat circumscribed in what it can do, having regard to the tight guidelines which qualify, in its view, a public benefit institution. So I believe that some legislative action needs to be taken quickly so as to relieve these bodies of the burden that is now recognised to be unjustly falling on their shoulders.

I am disappointed that the review which was promised to take place within about six months of the date of operation of this legislation-namely, 1 April 1983-has not been concluded. I hope that it will be concluded rapidly and that legislation will be brought down. In the meantime, I propose to support any amendments that would relieve organisations, which are likely to receive majority support in the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to honourable senators for their general support of the legislation. The thrust and purport of the legislation was summarised by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in her remarks on behalf of the Opposition. She very carefully drew attention to a number of considerations about inconsistencies and anomalies which have arisen in relation to State taxes of a similar kind and the situation of the Federal legislation. She confined her remarks to the legislation in question, although she could have made a very long speech, has she wished to do that, illustrating all the analogous situations which exist in terms of State charges, Commonwealth charges, and so on, which I agree will have to be addressed by governments in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Other than that, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle really drew attention to the fact that this Bill is designed to redress the possibility of a technical defect in the earlier legislation regarding the imposition of the burden of this legislation on banks or their customers. The effect of the legislation is to provide for joint and several liability of the banks and the customers-that is all that it does-to overcome a situation of possible constitutional invalidity, although that is no by no means certain.

Other honourable senators have used the presence of this Bill in the Parliament to draw attention to a number of situations which have arisen in respect of various groups and to a number of representations that they have received from various groups, such as Girl Guides and Rotary, as mentioned by Senator Harradine, which feel aggrieved by the imposition of this tax. All I would say about that is that the review which has been foreshadowed, both earlier this year and in a series of responses to questions asked by people such as Senator Harradine, is well advanced, and that these matters are all appropriately matters for consideration within the scope of that review. I am advised that the Government is likely to be able to bring forward a response to that review early next year. At that time, the adequacy of the review and its recommendations or lack of recommendations will be a subject of discussion in the Parliament. That will be an appropriate time to move amendments if any particular group feels aggrieved as a result of perceived inadequacies in that review.

If at this stage amendments were proceeded with to satisfy a particular group, all that would be happening would be that additional ad hockeries would be introduced into the legislation. This legislation is not doing anything but attempting to grapple with the technical problem, as I said earlier, and it is not the appropriate vehicle for honourable senators to use as an opportunity to advance the cause of particular interested groups in an ad hoc way. Senator Harradine was, I think, recognising that when he said that he was advocating the cause of particular groups but that those groups could be multiplied probably across the Commonwealth and that there may be a wide variety of others. The Government approaches the question in that way. The review is well under way. The appropriate time to deal with that question is at the time of the Government 's response to the review.

Otherwise, in respect of the Taxation Administration Amendment Bill, I thank honourable senators for their support or acquiescence. This is a very practical and sensible measure. One of the most attractive things about it is that it alleviates what I regard as a very onerous burden on police forces. That is important, because they have the gravest difficulties as it is in carrying out a very unpalatable job on many occasions, and to have police forces involved in the serving of tax summonses and so on seems to be totally outmoded and to be bad from the point of view of bodies such as that. The Taxation Office will now only be availing itself of a facility of which many other organisations and groups throughout the community have availed themselves at a much earlier stage of history. I thank the Senate for its general support of the Bill. The Government will certainly note the comments made. They have, of course, already been made in the context of the review which is taking place of this the first major piece of legislation subjected to an amendment here today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, clause 4, before paragraph (a), insert the following paragraph:
'(aa) by inserting after ''university'' in sub-paragraph (a) (vi) (C) of the definition of ''excluded debit'' in sub-section (1) '', or a voluntary school support organization,'';'.

I do so despite the fervent plea by the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Senator Button) because I believe there is a very serious anomaly which has been recognised by all political parties, by the previous Treasurer, by the present Treasurer (Mr Keating) and by honourable senators who have spoken today, and which is currently quite seriously affecting the voluntary school support organisations. I do not wish to drag out the debate on this matter. Honourable senators have indicated that a number of organisations deserve the same sort of reprieve as this amendment would give to the voluntary school support organisations. But I simply believe that this is a group which is in jeopardy at present in many areas of Australia and which needs every bit of relief which can be given to it to allow it to continue and to provide under extremely difficult conditions the services to the children in our community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. It does so, firstly, because this is not the appropriate mechanism for making a change of the kind sought by the Australian Democrats. This Bill is one to overcome a technical problem in the legislation. As was said in the second reading speech, the Bill is not intended to pre-empt the promised general review of the tax. That general review of the tax is under way. What I am in a sense appealing to Senator Jack Evans to understand is this: He is concerned about this little constituent group-a very important constituent group-but Parliament would look silly if, on the basis of his subjective judgment, it were to seek to amend the legislation in the way sought. I am certainly not prepared to make the judgment in this chamber, and I hope nobody else is, that parents and citizens associations are more aggrieved or more damaged by this legislation than Meals on Wheels, the Boy Scouts Association which Senator Harradine mentioned, the Guide Dogs for the Blind Association, or any other--
—Credit unions.

—Credit unions, as Senator Georges says, or any other organisation which is aggrieved or may be aggrieved by the application of this tax. The Government has said that those matters will all be reviewed. That review involves making a series of relative value judgments. When the review is completed, the response will come back to the Parliament and then people such as the Australian Democrats will have an opportunity to say that the value judgments of the review are in their opinion wrong and that they would like to substitute their view for the view adopted by the comprehensive review which will take into account the views and opinions of all the groups concerned about and affected by the tax. That is the appropriate opportunity to do that. I do not dissent from the view that the voluntary associations associated with schools are very important. But, in the absence of the report of the comprehensive review, I am not in a position to say, and I honestly do not believe that other senators are in a position to say, that the burden imposed on those associations is of a qualitatively different nature from the burden imposed on others by this tax.

SPEECH.PARA: Hundreds of representations have been made to honourable senators on behalf of various organisations, and of course made to the review. To amend this legislation to exempt one particular group of organisations from the tax without considering the claims of many others according to the same set of criteria is to reduce this Parliament to a piecemeal populist institution which, on the basis of off the cuff value judgments, determines that one group is more aggrieved qualitatively and is more adversely affected than another group. As I have said before, the review is under way and it will report early next year. Then is the time to deal with these matters, not in a technical Bill.

There is a further reason for opposing the Australian Democrats' amendment. It is not clear what the expression 'voluntary school support organisation' means. For example, it does not appear to cover support organisations connected with colleges, universities or other educational bodies. Nor does it seem to cover organisations not connected with a particular school but only those concerned with promoting the interests, improvement and advancement of particular forms of education. It does not cover those. I mention these examples simply to bring home the point that was mentioned earlier that it is a piecemeal ad hoc amendment and these things often create more problems than they solve. I repeat that the Government will examine all these matters and will report to the Parliament in the course of its response to the review. For those reasons, I urge the Senate to oppose this amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983 is a major Bill. It proposes 43 amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, some of which are of very considerable importance. The Senate may wonder why so many amendments, many of them perhaps of not such an important character, have been proposed to this legislation at a time when a major review, known as the tripartite review, is being undertaken of the Act. Indeed, I will be suggesting that some of the amendments to which the Opposition is opposed would be better left until that review has considered the problem and reported. I think the Parliament could then better consider some of these matters. However, the Opposition, despite the fact that there is this tripartite review, does support most of the amendments contained in this Bill. In fact, I believe the major amendments are ones that were the subject of initiatives by the present Opposition when in government last year.

SPEECH.PARA: One major proposal was put forward in a Bill introduced by Mr Viner, when he was Minister, in March of last year, and another by Mr Macphee, when he was Minister, in October last year. These proposals are certainly supported by the Opposition although we do have an amendment in one respect. The first proposal provides for joint sittings of federal and State industrial tribunals, and the exercise in certain cases of federal jurisdiction by State tribunals and vice versa. It is designed to, and undoubtedly will, improve greatly the much required co-ordination among Australia's industrial tribunals. As I said, the proposal was introduced into Parliament last year, but its passage was not completed before the election. The second major proposal is for the rationalisation of the Public Service Arbitration Act and the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and for the vesting of the Public Service Arbitrator's jurisdiction in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. That amendment was introduced by Mr Macphee in October last year. That principle certainly has the strong support of the Opposition. I think it has been our policy for some time when in government that that should be achieved, and so the Opposition certainly welcomes that proposal.

I believe they are the major purposes of this legislation. Although as I have said there is a total of 43 amendments, many of them are rather minor in nature and I do not propose to go through them. What I do propose is to mention some of the problems that the Opposition has with this legislation and on which we will be moving amendments. The first deals with the vesting of the Public Service Arbitrator's jurisdiction in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Opposition is concerned that this Bill will confer a greater power on the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission than is presently exercised by the Public Service Arbitrator. That relates to the area of appointment and promotion in the Public Service.

The existing provisions did put a brake on Public Service jurisdiction concerning these matters and by removing it, of course, there will be duality between the Public Service Board and the Commission in relation to Public Service recruitment and promotion. Ultimately it will take out of the hands of the Parliament, which has laid that responsibility on the Public Service Board, the control of Public Service staffing practices. The Opposition believes these matters should still remain with the Public Service Board, and that principle should not be modified in any way simply because the Public Service Arbitrator's jurisdiction is now incorporated in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. So we will be proposing an amendment to deal with that matter.

We also believe the provisions in the Public Service Arbitration Act concerning powers in relation to stand-downs and the result of stand-down orders, which are spelt out in some detail in the Public Service Arbitration Act and which were incorporated in the legislation that Mr Macphee introduced, were carried over into the proposal that, when in government, we made for this rationalisation. Those provisions set out quite clearly that where an employee has been stood down he is not entitled to salary or allowances, long service leave, recreation leave and so on. I think this does accord with the principles which we debated in the Senate several weeks ago. We believe there are certain conditions relating to Public Service employment which are not necessarily the same as those in private employment. The Public Service does have certain special duties and obligations to the community. It has, as a result, certain privileges and protections such as tenure, very adequate superannuation and so on and there should be a corresponding higher obligation by members of the Public Service than would be expected from people in private employment. So the Opposition believes those provisions which emphasise that should also be included in the transfer of jurisdictions.

The Opposition is also concerned about some provisions in the legislation concerning the registration of organisations and the effect that this will have on the position particularly of owner-drivers. When in government we, subject to some qualification regarding the extended definition of 'employee' in certain State Acts, implemented legislation in 1977 to seek to prevent the coercion of owner-drivers into membership of the federal union, the Transport Workers Union. In fact, it has transpired that as a result of that legislation a number of members of the federal union are not eligible to be members but in fact have continued to retain membership. Certain problems have arisen from that, admittedly; nevertheless, they remain members in defiance of the will of this Parliament and that legislation. This Bill proposes to validate the continuation of those memberships. It does not reverse the policy of the 1977 legislation as such, but it does validate the continuation of membership of those people who have remained on the books and have voted in elections and so on. So this is a proposal which does change that situation, and the Opposition believes it is wrong in principle.

The situation in respect of owner-drivers generally is certainly a very vexed one. We do not believe there should be any extension of the provisions which enable owner-drivers to be members of the Transport Workers Union, be it a State or federal branch. The nature of the amendments contained in the Bill seems to be contrary to that policy. In New South Wales there is special provision for the registration of separate associations of owner-drivers and that would seem to be a much better approach than the previous one of extended definitions of ' employees' and thereby giving opportunities for recruitment and pressures and coercion to be placed upon owner-drivers to join unions of which they do not wish to be members. The result of that in the past has been that numbers of these people have, by the same methods, become members of the Federal union, even though that Federal union cannot give them service because they cannot be covered by Federal awards. The Opposition is very concerned about the extent to which coercion has been brought to bear on these people over the years, and we do not agree with any further extensions of a situation which may facilitate that sort of coercion being brought to bear.

The Industrial Relations Bureau in its last report drew attention to the very great problem that this has created and the lack of success that the Bureau had in being able to solve it. In fact, it did not seem to be able to do much about it at all. The inadequacies of the existing legislation in relation to these matters-to prevent coercion, to provide for conscientious objections by these people-are most unsatisfactory. We believe that this is the proper area for consideration by the tripartite committee and that these matters would be better discussed in this Parliament after that committee has reported. We are opposed to any of the provisions in this legislation which seem to perpetuate or even enhance those problems.

Another matter which concerns the Opposition is that this legislation amends the provisions for disqualification from office for offences that have been committed by officials or people who seek to become officials of unions. These provisions were introduced last year by Mr Macphee on behalf of the then Government. The Opposition believes that, except in one respect, the provisions should not be altered at this stage. Again it is a matter which the tripartite committee can look at, and perhaps it can make some further recommendations on it. To the Opposition, the piecemeal way in which the proposed changes are made in this Bill does not appear to be justified.

The principle is certainly retained in these changes. They do not seek to remove the notion of offences disqualifying people from becoming officials of unions, but they seek to remove a number of offences from that category. It is difficult to see what justification there is for that except in regard to recklessness in conduct which leads to a conviction for violence. The Opposition accepts that that is justified because the circumstances in such a case do not necessarily relate to obligations that are relevant to the exercise of responsibilities as a union official.

Some of the other offences that are sought to be amended, such as failure to comply with an order of the Federal Court or direction by the Federal Court to observe rules of the union, or failure to lodge with the Industrial Registrar details of moneys held by an organisation, or failure to lodge details of loans or donations, all seem to be matters which are highly relevant to the responsibilities of a union official and we believe that they should not be removed as disqualifications from the holding of union office. As I said, these few matters will be the subject of specific amendments which have been circulated, but apart from them the Opposition supports this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983. As with some of the previous industrial relations legislation introduced by this Government, this Bill represents a move to streamline the operation of trade unions and constitutes an important element of our prices and incomes accord. Before I go on to deal with some of the major components of the Bill I take this opportunity of pointing out to the Senate some of the aims and logic behind the accord. As the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Willis) pointed out in the other place on 16 November, the accord provides the basis upon which this country can have a sustained economic recovery, a recovery which will give us growth in employment and a chance of getting unemployment down. In criticising the accord the Opposition is clearly out of touch with most business leaders. Recently the Director of the Confederation of Australian Industry, Mr Bryan Noakes, said that a tremendous amount of good work had been done in putting together the prices and incomes accord. The policies outlined in the accord quite rightly seek to maintain the living standards of wage and salary earners while at the same time creating a stable industrial relations environment which will form the basis for any lasting economic recovery. The accord details a whole range of policy matters, including of course the amendments we are now debating, and matters relating to industrial development, technological change, occupational health and safety and education. It would not be a bad idea if Opposition senators took a close look at the Government's report on its initiatives in the area of the prices and incomes policy, which lists no fewer than 65 decisions or announcements relating to areas dealt with in the accord.

SPEECH.PARA: I now turn to some of the individual components of the Bill we are debating. As a former Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation of Australia I am pleased that these changes will finally be put into practice, because some of the existing legislation in this area has been a source of frustration for the trade union movement for a number of years. There are basically six major elements of this Bill and I will mainly deal with those relating to Commonwealth -State co-ordination, terms of office, common rules provision and casual vacancies. It needs to be said, of course, that part of this legislation consists of measures which were introduced by the former Government but which were interrupted by the double dissolution. I refer to the proposals for greater co-ordination between Commonwealth and State industrial systems and incorporation of the jurisdiction of the Public Service Arbitrator within the jurisdiction of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

As the Minister pointed out in his second reading speech, the measures contained in this Bill have all been thoroughly examined by the National Labor Consultative Council and have its complete support. The proposal for greater co- ordination between Commonwealth and State systems will remove some of the inflexible arrangements which presently exist. These measures are essentially those contained in the Conciliation and Arbitration (Complementary Industrial Relations System) Amendment Bill 1982. The changes will enable the two industrial systems to work in harmony to resolve industrial disputes, and will result in a much more highly effective operation.

I turn now to the proposal concerning the term of office of union officials. Under the existing rules if a union official's term of office expires before the proposed date of his retirement, he must either stand for re-election and serve only part of that term, or retire early. This problem of unions running two elections one after the other and forcing many older officials into what is often a distressing situation for them has been a source of concern within the trade union movement for many years. This legislation allows for union officials who are due to retire within 12 months of the end of the scheduled term to remain in office until their retirement. The common rules provisions contained in this Bill will also be welcomed by the trade union movement in that they will remove certain anomalies that have also been a constant source of frustration. Under the existing provisions workers doing certain tasks within a particular territory do not receive changes in conditions or benefits at the same time as other workers doing similar tasks. These changes will end these delays and simplify the procedures in relation to award variations.

I refer now to the amendment concerning the filling of casual vacancies. As the legislation now stands, casual vacancies must be filled by an election, irrespective of the remaining term of office. Naturally, this results in a lot of unnecessary expense for unions and has been a cause of concern within the trade union movement for many years. Under the amendment set out in this Bill, a casual vacancy can be filled without an election for the full term of the previous officer's term if that period does not exceed 12 months. Where the period does exceed 12 months, the vacancy may still be filled casually for a period not exceeding three-quarters of the original period. It seems to me that this is a very sensible and realistic provision and it will most certainly be welcomed by the trade union movement.

Another example of the Government's desire to simplify and rationalise procedures in the industrial relations area is the section of this Bill which repeals the Public Service Arbitration Act 1920. The proposals contained in the Bill give the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission jurisdiction over employment matters within the Public Service or Commonwealth authorities. One important area of difference between this and previous legislation is in the area of stand-down provisions. This Bill does not contain provisions relating to the types of orders that may be made by the Commission in relation to the stand- down of employees. However, it needs to be stressed that this does not stop Public Service employers from obtaining stand-down orders. This is certainly consistent with the Government's general approach to industrial relations management.

One final area I mention briefly concerns clause 23, which amends section 132F of the principal Act by reducing the range of offences under which people can be barred from holding office. Under these amendments, people can be barred only if their offences relate to matters specifically involved with union elections or to serious offences of violence or robbery, which seems to me to be fairer and more realistic. These amendments are long overdue. They will result in a streamlining of the industrial relations processes and will contribute greatly to the creation of a stable industrial environment.

This is yet another fine example of the Government's consensus approach at work . It is certainly no coincidence that in our first nine months of office the level of industrial disputation in Australia has fallen dramatically. The latest figures on strikes released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics have shown that the level of industrial disputation is now at its lowest level for something like 12 years. Working days lost during strikes in August were the lowest since surveys began in 1970. As the report pointed out, the fall in active worker unrest has occurred across all major industry sectors. This Bill represents another step by this Government towards the creation of an efficient and fairer industrial relations system. It is a credit to the Government that it has acted so quickly in bringing in this legislation. I have much pleasure in supporting the Bill and commend it to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — This afternoon we are debating the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2). It is an omnibus Bill with 43 amendments dealing with various sections of industrial relations. As Senator Durack has already said, the previous Government had drafted many of the amendments in this proposed legislation. The legislation was not passed prior to the election, and we had no disagreement with it. However, there are areas of the current legislation to which we are in complete opposition. Senator Foreman said, I think, that all the amendments were supported by the National Labour Consultative Committee. That statement is not accurate. Perhaps it supported the majority of the amendments, but it did not support the repeal of the offences for which people can be debarred from holding office.
—Well, it should have.
—Senator Georges is not a member of the NLCC and it has other views. As an Opposition, we certainly share its views.
—It has led to all sorts of harassment in the industry.

—We will come to that matter at a later stage and Senator Georges can interject then if he so desires. Although the Opposition is happy about handing over to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the Public Service Arbitrator's jurisdiction, I believe that the Government has gone too far. It has handed over to the Arbitration Commission sections of administration dealing with appointments of officers, employment, reappointments and promotions. Indeed, it has taken out of the hands of management of the Public Service all those things with which management rightly deals. I do not believe that the Public of Australia feels that the government of the day or a private employer has not the right to make the promotions and appointments that it thinks fit. To take these matters out of the hands of the Public Service is quite ludicrous.

SPEECH.PARA: We have recently debated those sections of the Public Service and Statutory Authorities Act dealing with the provisions of no work as directed no pay and the stand-down clauses that were repealed during that debate. The Government now seeks to repeal section 70J of the Public Service Arbitration Act, which section makes it clear that Commonwealth public servants who are stood down during strike action are not entitled to salary, wages or allowances during that stand- down period and that the stand-down period was not to be counted for purposes of recreation leave, sick leave or long service leave. I repeat the comment that I made at the time of that debate, namely, that public servants are in a very special area. They are very protected employees and I believe they bear a responsibility to the taxpayer who pays their wages. I believe they should not go on strike. They create tremendous problems in the servicing of the public when they go on strike. They create great disabilities when they go on strike. I refer, for example, to the strike by staff of the Department of Social Security which put pensioners and their financial positions at risk. However, I suppose now that the Government has already repealed those sections, this proposed change is in line with its thinking. We also object to those stand-down clauses being taken out on the ground of continuity.

In regard to clause 22 (1), which seeks to amend section 132 of the principal Act, the intention of the Liberal Government's measure of 1977 was to legislate in two areas: First, to ensure that owner-drivers, who are self-employed people, where possible should not be forced to join the Transport Workers Union of Australia; secondly, to bring the legislation into line with that of the various States in regard to employee eligibility for union membership. The position in every State is different-the position in New South Wales is different from that in Queensland, South Australia or Western Australia. The position in Tasmania is quite different from that in all of the other States. The New South Wales legislation was amended in 1979 and this has created a problem for the Transport Workers Union-no one else. The New South Wales legislation enabled owner-drivers to join their own association. It allowed for the registration of associations of contract drivers, carriers and employing contractors. I believe that this was a very good thing but also owner-drivers were no longer deemed to be employees. As such, they were no longer deemed to be eligible for membership of the Transport Workers Union, but they have stayed on in that capacity.

Clause 22 perpetuates a problem that we have had ever since the 1977 legislation was passed. The owner-drivers have been coerced and, in my State, actively intimidated, to become members of a union that cannot service them. At the moment the union is having a dispute with owner-drivers who are carting oil. The owner-drivers who belong to the union are facing a situation in which their union is having a dispute with other owner-drivers. They go to their union and say: 'Come on, what can you do for us?' and are told: 'There is nothing we can do for you'. Of course it cannot do anything for them. The dispute underlines the impossibility of owner-drivers ever belonging to the Transport Workers Union . I believe that the New South Wales legislation also made it possible for the Transport Workers Union to set up an association of contract drivers. As I understand it, because of the situation that I have just described, there is a terrible mess. It cannot fail to be so when one side of the union is fighting the other. Therefore, there is no way in which the Opposition could support clause 22 (1).

Clause 22 (2) seeks to validate the union membership of those who, before the 1977 legislation, were eligible for membership of the Transport Workers Union and may have continued in a so-called voluntary capacity as members. There is no way in which anyone would be silly enough to pay union dues when he could not be serviced by a union. Membership is not undertaken voluntarily but rather as the result of intimidation on the part of the union. Indeed, in Tasmania a situation arose in which employees, owner-drivers, came to me and said 'what can we do about this? We are being coerced to join the Transport Workers Union'. I gave them a copy of the legislation and told them that they were not eligible for membership, that the union could not service them in any way and they should just go to it and say: 'There is the legislation; it is not legal for you to seek our membership'. When that occurred, the intimidation that went on was quite appalling. It is of no use for such people to go to the police and tell them what has occurred. The union will deny it. It is one man's word against another. The intimidation means that, because people are concerned for the welfare of their families, they will join the Transport Workers Union. By supporting clause 22 (2), we would be perpetuating that sort of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if they wanted to join? Would you deny them the right to join ?
—They have their own union or association, which they can join.
—What if they want to join the Transport Workers Union and not some bogus organisation?

—As I have just tried to explain to the Senate, Senator Cook, there is no point in joining a union that cannot give them any service or legally look after them. They must pay $85 in Tasmania to join a union that cannot do anything for them. When a dispute occurs, they say, 'You are my union; I am paying $85; what can you do for me?' and the union says: 'Nothing; we are in dispute with you'. Those exact words were used to the owner-drivers in Tasmania last week: 'There is nothing we can do for you; we are indeed in dispute with you'. Why on earth would anyone want to pay $85 a year for that sort of service? If Senator Cook has any questions at all about the matter he should go down to Tasmania and find out the situation; it is quite appalling.

SPEECH.PARA: When I discussed this in front of Senator Harradine in committee-with industrial relations officers of the Transport Workers Union present-the statement was made: 'That cannot happen in Tasmania; we would not do that'. I asked whether they would investigate and report back to me and they said that they would not. Of course they would not. They know very well what goes on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are you?

—I am a representative of the Tasmanian constituents who are being intimidated. I asked whether they would investigate my allegations. They said that they would not. They know that it goes on but have no intention of doing anything about it.
—What about those who desire to join the union?

—I have already answered that. There would be no one who would pay $85 a year for something that could not provide them with any legal service- none at all. The union cannot look after them. They have their first dispute and the union says: 'We cannot help them'.
—There are more ways of representing the membership than that of getting an award.

—Fine, then why is Senator Harradine, why is every union representative saying: 'If we allow voluntary membership of unions, people who are not union members should not get the award'? They never talk about anything else-'They should not get the award increases that the union worked so hard to get'. They know that that has priority.

SPEECH.PARA: I come now to the question of repealing disqualification from holding office, something with which the NLCC does not agree. It is interesting to see what an array of offences is to be taken out of the legislation. I will be interested to hear from the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Senator Button) at the Committee stage how the removal of the word 'reckless' is to be applied to behaviour in picket lines. While I acknowledge that there may be occasions on which such behaviour could occur unintentionally, I would be interested to know how, if the word 'reckless' is to be removed, we are to cope with certain behaviour in the picket lines. A number of serious, prescribed offences which debar people from holding office are to be removed. To mention a few, I refer to failure to comply with an order of the Federal Court under the prescribed offences section, an offence which carries a maximum penalty of $500, and failure to comply with the order of the Federal Court on the observance of organisation rules in respect of secret ballots. Other offences include the failure to comply with a direction of the Federal Court on the observance of rules of the organisation, failure to lodge with the Industrial Registrar details of money held by an organisation, failure to lodge with the Industrial Registrar details of loans or donations over $1,000 and so on. I believe the offences in regard to the unauthorised collection of moneys and the failure to keep audited financial accounts are very serious. Perhaps the most serious offence is that of falsely representing oneself in an application under the Act as a member of an organisation. This offence, indeed, entails a period of imprisonment. Those offences are to be taken out of the Act.

Senator Foreman said that consensus had been reached on this matter. To me the Government seems to be supporting deceit within the union movement. I believe the removal of provisions that previously debarred people from holding office will create great problems for the honest union member. I am greatly concerned that the Government is willing to allow officers who have already refused to comply with court orders, who have made false representations and so on to become executive members of unions. Senator Foreman spoke about the lowest strike record under the present Government. He failed to mention, of course, that that lowest strike record is accompanied by the highest unemployment record . I believe that in many instances these two things go hand in glove. I will speak further on this Bill during the Committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In many respects the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1983 is a remarkable piece of industrial relation legislation, remarkable because its introduction has not been accompanied by loud banner headlines and because it has not been roundly condemned or supported by one group or another. There have been no newspaper advertisements, stoppages or complaints about it. In fact, the legislation before us is remarkable in that it is widely supported. Some of the provisions of the legislation are, of course, supported by the provisions of the prices and incomes accord and by the decisions of the National Economic Summit Conference. Most of the provisions are supported by the National Labour Consultative Council , that tripartite body of government, unions and employers. The legislation includes, of course, items introduced by the previous Government and supported by the Australian Labor Party which were not able to be carried through the last Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Nearly all of the propositions in this legislation have been thoroughly canvassed. A remarkable degree of consensus has been achieved. In those areas where consensus has not been reached there has been a willingness to accept the compromise proposal that has been put by the Australian Government in this legislation. I suppose one can remark wryly that although bodies have been able to maintain their policy positions in NLCC discussions their preparedness to accept the legislation as it has been presented to the Parliament is perhaps an indication that they are not at all disatisfied with its contents. I think it is appropriate to say, therefore, that this legislation again demonstrates, as Senator Foreman rightly said, that the Government's course of pursuing consultation instead of confrontation is the right course. This once again demonstrates that the Labor Party is better at industrial relations than the Opposition. It demonstrates that the Labor Party has the ear of the unions, the respect of employers, and that because of its own philosophical background it knows this field and that it is a better industrial relations Government than the Liberal-National Party. As the time is now 12.45 p.m., I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 November 1983, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take the occasion of this first reading debate to pay a tribute to a great Australian novelist, playwright and essayist, Katharine Susannah Prichard, the centenary of whose birth falls on 4 December this year. There has been a resurgence of interest in literature and the arts of the 1930's, and one name emerges with special relevance in 1983. I refer to that of the author most read and best known of Australian novelists, Katharine Susannah Prichard, who in private life was Mrs Hugo Throssell, wife of Western Australia's first Victoria Cross recipient in World War I. Her son, Ric Throssell, is returning to Australia from London where he has been Director of the Commonwealth Foundation at Marlborough House. As literary heir of Katharine Susannah Prichard he has been invited to attend the centenary arrangements made by the Fellowship of Australian Writers under the presidency of Mr Brian Dibble, head of the School of English at the Western Australian Institute of Technology.

SPEECH.PARA: The Western Australian branch of the Fellowship of Australian Writers has commissioned Australia Post to produce a special post marker to be used at the Claremont Post Office in Western Australia on 5 December only. In addition, a commemorative envelope has been produced. This is printed with a new 30c stamp with the coat of arms of Western Australia and a design incorporating a portrait of Katharine Susannah Prichard. A quality philatelic collectors item, this envelope is available from the Fellowship of Australian Writers in Western Australia. Murdoch University has prepared an exhibition of letters, books and memorabilia to be opened on 4 December in the foyer of its main library. The exhibition will be there for a long period, culminating in Open Day 1984.

A program of events to mark the centenary of Katharine's birth includes fixing of a bronze plaque on the Throssell home at No. 11 Old York Road, Greemount, where almost all of the writings of the author were completed and where she died in 1969. Translated into hundreds of copies in very many languages, including Byelo-Russian, Rumanian, Latvian, Chinese, Italian, German and Hungarian, her trilogy of the gold fields, the Roaring Nineties, is probably the best known of her works among international readers. Novels, poems, short stories, plays, an autobiography and biographies by known contemporaries number hundreds when counted with articles in current journals and items of reportage from the journalist-before-the-novelist. A noted radical writer, she drew commentaries from far and wide beyond the boundaries of her own country as well as within it. In a work published in Australia in 1975 by Angus and Robertson, written by her son, Ric Throssell, a complete list of such bibliography appears as appendices and is invaluable. The title, derived from one of her poems, is Wild Weeds and Wind Flowers.

Katharine, all her long life, wrote to her son regularly when he was serving abroad with the Department of Foreign Affairs, when he was living in Canberra or when he was on service in Papua New Guinea. Those letters are invaluable evidence of the strong tie between mother and son and furnish the fabric of his biography. Katharine Susannah guarded jealously her son's rare visits to their home in Greenmount. The book that he wrote flows over the years of the life of this precious and revered author, and reveals more of her personality than have all her volumes of writing. She ordered all unpublished manuscripts to be destroyed on her death, wanting to be known only by those standards or authorship which she set herself.

The centenary of her birth will honour the woman, the activist, the author and the member of intimates who set standards for Australian literature in its own right, divorced from the trammels of British colonialism. Katharine Susannah Prichard was a true Australian and proud to claim the title of an Australian realist author. Late last year I had the honour and the privilege of launching a collection of Katharine Susannah Prichard's previously unpublished essays and speeches collected by her son and published by Wild and Wolley. Having read this book, I found myself for days wondering constantly how this or that current event would affect her. During her lifetime, I had the honour of meeting Katharine Susannah on several occasions. I know that, as an activist and a feminist, she would have been inevitably distressed by the ascendance of libertarian economism in Australia over recent years, its regressiveness, its naked, crass social Darwinism and its lack of humanity and compassion. I know that she would have written, spoken and agonised against the threat of nuclear war and against the growing impoverishment of poor nations and peoples while the rich get richer. I think, like me, she would have been delighted with some progressive aspects of late twentieth century politics and perhaps diverted to read, as I did recently in a newspaper, an account of a by-election in England in which it was stated that one candidate had perhaps an unfair advantage of a blooming six-month pregnancy! There have been changes-some good, some bad, some catostrophic-to the society that she so aptly described in the course of her long life. Australians, women particularly, must take heart and courage from her writing, but more importantly from the radiance, the sincerity, the passion and compassion which permeate all of her works.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In recent weeks considerable attention has been paid to the fact that Cruise missiles have been placed in Western Europe. I think it is useful, since world attention is now focused on this new and dangerous weapon, to raise this issue here in the Senate as a matter not only of information but also of analysis. Cruise missiles are basically small unmanned aircraft armed with both nuclear and conventional explosive warheads. They are able to be launched from planes, submarines, ships or ground vehicles. They are undoubtedly very accurate missiles. In fact, it is estimated that they are able to hit a target within 100 to 300 feet after a 1,500 mile flight, which is extraordinarily accurate. They are relatively inexpensive, costing something of the order of $2m each.

SPEECH.PARA: Undoubtedly, these missiles bring a new dimension to the arms race which may be such as to threaten an end to any effective arms control in the future. I think it should be understood that these weapons are unique to the United States. No other nation in the world has comparable weapons. I have no doubt that the Soviets are developing similar weapons, but they do not have them at the moment. That they are probably developing them could be drawn from the institutional insanity of the cycle of escalation which afflicts this world. The United States in its current plans, and with the agreement of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries, will within the next three years encircle the Soviet Union with some 5,000 Cruise missiles carrying nuclear warheads. Another 4,000 conventionally armed Cruise missiles are being planned. These will be identical in appearance to their nuclear counterparts. This is where problems will undoubtedly arise in the future. Verification, which is essential to any arms control, will no longer be possible through the established satellite monitors. Close physical inspection will be required in order to distinguish a conventionally armed Cruise missile from a nuclear armed Cruise missile.

Cruise missiles are seen by the Soviet Union as first-strike weapons. Their ablity to fly at less than 200 feet, hugging the terrain, makes them elusive targets that probably can easily evade current Soviet defences. The Cruise missiles which are currently being deployed in Europe are only one of three types of Cruise missiles, the other types being the sea-launched Cruise missile and the air-launched Cruise missile. The air-launched Cruise missiles are already abundant in the United States Air Force and the placement in B52 bombers of some 1,700 more Cruise missiles will soon be completed. Once the installation is completed, the original programs will be replaced and the advanced Cruise missile which is currently undergoing trials will be introduced. Of course, the advanced Cruise missile incorporates new stealth technology which will render its operation almost invisible to radar.

The United States Navy has plans to acquire some 4,000 sea-launched Cruise missiles by 1990. These will be deployed on surface ships and submarines. The danger with the surface-launched missiles is that they are only 20 feet long and can easily be deployed on merchant vessels or on fishing trawlers. Such deception will undoubtedly promote additional fears and will feed the Soviet paranoia in relation to the West. The ground-launched missiles, those which are now being deployed in Europe, have a destructive power of 10 to 50 kilotons. This is equivalent to one to five Hiroshima-sized bombs on each missile.

These weapons which are currently being deployed in Europe-the current target for the ensuing year is 464 ground-launched Cruise missiles and 108 Pershing 2 missiles-are, I believe, being deployed on false premises. As Senator Chipp said yesterday, these missiles are not needed as a response to the Soviet SS-20 missile-as is now the accepted conventional wisdom. The United States deployment of Cruise and Pershing 2 missiles began before the SS-20 appeared on the scene. These missiles were not a response to the SS-20. The Soviets have now grasped the excuse to escalate again the deployment of their own missiles in Eastern Europe. It is a fact that since 1959 the Soviet Union has had the capacity to devastate the whole of Western Europe with nuclear weapons. The SS-20 missile is part of a modernisation program that replaces old missiles with the original intent of not increasing the total number of weapons. The original operation in which the Soviets were engaged would not have changed the military situation in Europe. The Kremlin has now moved from that position and has used the Cruise missile as an excuse for its own escalation in Western Europe.

The extra 570 new nuclear warheads which are currently being deployed will certainly upset the parity of nuclear arsenals that exist in Europe at the moment. The North Atlantic Treaty Organisation and the Warsaw Pact have some 6, 000 nuclear warheads each. That includes the SS-20 in the Warsaw Pact total, but it does not include the new placements of the United States and NATO forces. The 6,000 nuclear warheads on each side certainly explain very clearly the concern and fears in Europe that a third world war and any nuclear engagement would lead to the destruction and total devastation of Europe. The Soviet walkout from the intermediate range nuclear missile talks in Geneva was extremely serious. I believe it was an unacceptable act on the part of the Soviet Union. I believe it is an illustration of the intent on both sides to escalate further the nuclear arms race. For the sake of the world an agreement must be reached. The inflexibility of the United States and Soviet Russia in relation to this holds the rest of the world to ransom.

Large scale Cruise missile deployments have probably extinguished for the first time the rather faint hopes that people had of successfully controlling at this stage the current nuclear arms race. The problem was foreseen very early on. At some stage it was forseen that the problem would escalate out of all proportion. I think that time is now. Basically, the way out has been known for a long time. In addition to the now stalled INF negotiations there should be an attempt to combine those negotiations with the ensuing strategic arms reduction talks which , luckily, are still in progress. I believe the concentration which has been placed on the super-powers' intercontinental missiles is certainly useful from the point of view of the United States and the Soviet Union, but in no way allays the fears of Europe. I think that the combination of those talks could provide a larger and much more workable framework for negotiation and agreement. I think that by keeping the talks separate both countries are contributing in many ways to the continuation and escalation of the nuclear arms race.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has appointed an Ambassador for Disarmament. I think that all Australians support that initiative and would support the work that the Ambassador is doing. I believe that in many ways we need to go beyond that. That could very well be seen merely as a token gesture as to where Australia stands in relation to disarmament. I believe that without some bold initiatives from countries such as ours future generations, if there are future generations, will be able to blame us. It is at this point basically that any turning point, any attempt to limit nuclear weapons, must be made. Essentially I believe the deployment of the Cruise has done two things: Firstly, it has put into the whole proposition an extremely dangerous and new weapon. Secondly it has put in a weapon which has the potential of not being able at any stage in the future to be incorporated into a general agreement or arms limitation. That seems to be an advance beyond anything that we have had up to now.

As many people have expressed to me in recent weeks, it seems as if we as a race are on a slide into inevitable destruction. I believe this problem really reduces all other problems that we face to mere insignificance. Without initiatives and constant effort on the part of our Government I believe we are not playing our role as an important nation in the world to prevent the ultimate catastrophe.
Debate (on motion by Senator Grimes) adjourned.
Sitting suspended from 1.07 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is it a fact that the employment of 100 additional taxation valuers has been approved as part of the implementation of the proposed assets test? Is it a fact that these positions are to be full time because the Australian Taxation Office argued that there would be additional work to justify them in the future? In view of Senator Grimes's acknowledgment in Labor Essays that, to be consistent, those who argue for an assets test could also promote a wealth tax--
—Have you read my book, too?

—It does not read quite as well as his, actually. Does the employment of these full time valuers indicate that a wealth tax, such as the capital gains tax so strongly advocated by Senator Button, is in the pipeline?
—It does not indicate anything of the sort. It is a ridiculous chain of logic on which Senator Messner has embarked. I do not propose to answer the question beyond saying no.
—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I would like to know, therefore, what the additional valuers will be doing in the Taxation Office?
—Order! That is not a supplementary question.
—It is part of my original question.
—Order! I regard a supplementary question as one which seeks additional information.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. In yesterday's House of Representatives debate on the pensions assets test, Mr Peacock cited an example of an age pensioner with $60,000 in cash from the sale of her home who he says, would be severely disadvantaged by the pensions assets test. This cash would, he said, reduce her weekly pension from $85.90 to approximately $43. Will the Minister comment on the accuracy of these allegations?

—Mr Peacock, as usual, betrays flaws in logic and mathematics in his statement during the debate which I noted in reading Hansard today. Under the proposed assets test, the lady in question would receive $44.65 a week in pension plus $10 a week in supplementary rent assistance, a total of $54.65 a week. If the proceeds of the sale of her home were invested in, say, Australian Savings Bonds at 11.75 per cent, her investment income would be $7,500 a year or $135.60 a week bringing her total weekly income to $190.25 a week. Mr Peacock's calculations appear to assume that she would earn no income whatsoever from the substantial sum of money she had to invest. I hope that, in assuming that, Mr Peacock is not advocating that we actually maintain the situation where people put large sums of money in interest free deposits.
—There would be tax involved, though.

—By contrast, Senator Chipp, under the current pensions income test, that investment income which she would receive would reduce her pension to $33.10 a week and entirely wipe out her supplementary rental assistance. She would be $21.55 a week worse off than under the proposed assets test. I now turn Mr Peacock's question on himself. I ask: Is he prepared to face the fact that this lady will be $21.55 a week worse off under his Party's policy of repealing the proposed assets test than she will be under the proposed assets test. I think in this sort of situation and in others Mr Peacock may believe he is scoring political points but, in fact, he is adding unnecessarily to the anxiety of people in the community such as the lady he mentions.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the income deprivation elements of the proposed assets test. Are all pensioners to be subject to the five-year retrospective review of the disposal of income and assets which is to take place in 1988? What is the expected cost of such a review? How many additional staff would be expected to be required to undertake it?

—I am not clear about the exact point of Senator Lajovic's question. Certainly, in order to have an income deprivation provision one must have a provision which accounts for the fact that people cannot deprive themselves of income before reaching a pensionable age and therefore artificially manipulate the system. We cannot do that retrospectively nor do we intend to do it retrospectively. It would mean that, in 1988, provided the pensions assets test had been in for that length of time, there would be such a review of new applicants. I cannot tell Senator Lajovic at the moment exactly how many extra people that exercise would require. One would think that it would not require any more than the people who have been employed to administer the assets test until 1988. However, I will look at the details of Senator Lajovic's question in Hansard and make sure that I give him a more detailed reply.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. Have any decisions been made that would improve the financial viability of the Australian National Line, particularly in relation to the shipping of cargo to Europe?

—A month or two ago I read a report with respect to proposals to give the Australian National Line greater access to the European market. I am advised that negotiations have been underway for some time between the European shipping conference and the Australian National Line with a view to Australia getting a more equitable share of the trade that flows between that part of the world and Australia. I understand that those negotiations have led to an agreed decision being made that the ANL will be able to participate more in that process of increased trade than hitherto. Senator Childs asked about the financial viability of ANL. Naturally, of course, if ANL gets increased trade between Europe and Australia, its financial viability will be considerably enhanced. That is a very desirable position from the point of view of the Australian Government and Australia's exporters because, if we do have a more viable shipping organisation, and if we are able to place it on a better financial basis, clearly, it will require less subsidisation from the Australian taxpayer as well as improving and making a success of an important public facility.

—Has the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs received a submission from a group of South Australian women pointing out the problems facing mature age women engaging in part time study? Does she agree that these women face problems additional to those faced by other students, particularly as far as finance is concerned? Does she agree that it is very difficult for these women to cover the costs of their education relating to such things as books, travel, child care and so on when they do not qualify for the tertiary education assistance scheme and when they are not able to claim education expenses as a tax deduction for the simple reason that they do not earn any money themselves, being solely dependent on their husbands? Does the Minister see any need to amend the present system to remove existing anomalies such as those affecting married women returning to part time study, by, for example, extending TEAS to cover part time mature age students or altering the taxation system so that one spouse can claim a deduction for the education costs of a non-working partner?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received the submission to which Senator Haines referred, from a group of mature age women students in South Australia. I shall ensure that it is directed to the Tertiary Education Commission, and to the Office of Status of Women for consideration of the proposals that the women make in it.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is very well aware of the difficulties experienced by mature age women, without adequate financial resources, in attempting to undertake study. The guidelines for money that we made available for extra participation in tertiary institutions this year specifically stated that women were one of the groups we hoped that institutions would respond to and assist in whatever way they needed to have increased access.

The question of child care is a very difficult one for women in this situation. I have directed the Tertiary Education Commission to review its previously announced policy of not making tertiary funds available for child care, because in our Government's view access to campus based child care is often essential if women are to be able to undertake further studies. I am awaiting a reply from the Commission on the child care issue.

With regard to the specific proposals, such as extending the tertiary education assistance scheme to women who are part time students or, indeed more generally, to part time students, the whole question of TEAS is being reviewed within my Department. There are very many anomalies in the application of TEAS, as I am sure every honourable senator will realise. The only problem, I suppose, for the Government is that any removal of those anomalies will result in more Budget outlays. In our first Budget we had an extremely difficult situation with which to come to terms and thus were unable to increase very significantly the amount of money available for expenditure on TEAS. However, I believe that the needs of these women will be examined by the TEAS review.

Similarly, the Economic Planning Advisory Council is currently considering anomalies in the taxation system, and I believe that that would be an appropriate area to which to direct the question of increasing or changing eligibility for tax rebates in a way that might assist these women.

The Government wishes to support the efforts of women who are trying to get themselves more training and qualifications, and it is looking across the range of policies by which it might be able to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Attorney-General to the Keystone Cops activities of the Australian Secret Intelligence Service in its exercise at the Sheraton Hotel in Melbourne last night. Is it a fact that ASIS is a body which is not regulated in any way by a legislative charter? Is it also a fact that ASIS is accountable neither at law for its actions nor in its financing? Did Royal Commissioner Hope , in the report of the Royal Commission on Intelligence and Security, find that ASIS had from time to time acted illegally, but did not recommend procedures to stop such activities?
