Despite the inadequacy of Mr Justice Hope's then response, and in the interests of accountability of security organisations, will the Minister and the Government urgently consider the establishment of a legislative framework to control the activities of ASIS?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the best way in which I can answer at least the preface to Senator Bolkus's question is by reading into the Senate record the substance of an answer that has just been given in the House of Representatives by Mr Hayden, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, whose ministerial responsibility this mercifully is. When I use the expression 'I', I am to be taken to be referring in this concept to Mr Hayden, but at the same time I make it clear that I fully endorse Mr Hayden's sentiments in this respect, because the Government, while it will strongly defend legitimate security activity, is not in the business of defending the indefensible. The statement is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members will be aware that last night a particularly nasty and, as far as I am concerned, intolerable incident occurred at the Sheraton Hotel, Melbourne. That incident arose from an Australian Secret Intelligence Service training exercise. I should make clear from the start that that incident took place without my knowledge, without my authority, and certainly without my consent. This applies to all other members of the Government. I have promptly put in train action to have a high-level investigation conducted into all aspects of this matter. I will come back to this point in a few seconds.

The scenario for the exercise I refer to entailed the lodging at the Sheraton Hotel of a 'hostage' under guard by two supposed strong armed men. The trainees in question had been instructed to rescue the supposed agent and take him to safe custody, meanwhile neutralising the two supposed guards. The emphasis of the exercise was the use of deception and subterfuge to gain control of the supposed hostage. Instead the trainees chose a violent attack on the room of the hotel in which the supposed hostage was held under guard. There followed involvement of the trainees with the hotel management and guests at the hotel including use of force on the part of the trainees. It is clear to me that the exercise was either poorly conceived, poorly put into operation, or both. The trainees were not authorised to use and should not have used force or pretended force against hotel property, members of the public or hotel staff.

The explanation provided by the Director-General of ASIS shows that no prior arrangements were made with the Victoria Police or the hotel management. I believe that the exercise should not have been conducted without such arrangements being in place with the approval and full knowledge of those two authorities. I have expressed in the clearest terms imaginable-
I believe this bit-

to the Director-General of ASIS my extreme condemnation of the exercise. I make no excuses for-in fact I have only the sternest condemnation of-the conduct of the exercise to the point of the hotel manager's intervention. Nonetheless, at that point of intervention this unjustifiable behaviour should have ceased. Certainly the hotel management staff or bystanders should not have become involved in the exercise and the trainees should have desisted from further participation and asked for the police to be called. The Victoria Police were called to the scene of the incident last night and subsequently arrested several of the trainees, who were later released after questioning.

I have been in contact with the Victorian Premier, Mr John Cain, and have apologised about this incident. I continue to maintain contact with him on this matter. I have been in contact with the New South Wales Premier, Mr Neville Wran , to seek approval for an immediate and full investigation to be conducted into this matter by Mr Justice Hope, who is currently conducting the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. The New South Wales Government has given its approval for Mr Justice Hope to conduct that inquiry. Mr Justice Hope has been contacted and has undertaken to commence investigation into this matter promptly, and tomorrow the first initiatives of that investigation will be under way. I hope for an early report on the matter, and of course, bearing in mind any obligations about classified security matters which might come up, the report will be made available to the Parliament. Justice Hope has been asked to explore all aspects of this exercise including the way in which it was prepared and developed, the manner in which it was put into operation, the general conduct of all people associated with it, and whether any person exceeded his proper authority in relation to this matter. It is my understanding that the current terms of reference for the Royal Commission which Mr Justice Hope is conducting are sufficient to allow him to conduct this inquiry. Justice Hope has ensured that this inquiry will be dealt with with the greatest dispatch.

In a more general way I have instructed that the whole question of ASIS training be reviewed without delay. Quite clearly specific guidelines need to be drawn up laying down firm rules including a requirement for prior consultation with other authorities or other people likely to become involved in or have some proper concern about particular training projects. The matter of firearms, which the trainees were carrying during last night's exercise but without live ammunition, will also be attended to. On a more substantial level Mr Justice Hope has also been asked as part of the more extensive inquiry he is conducting into ASIS to consider also these matters.

Let me conclude by saying that the Government regards last night's incident as thoroughly inexcusable, in no way seeks to excuse it, and certainly will not condone it. Naturally I have been in close contact with the Prime Minister on this matter and will continue to report to him on developments. As a matter of courtesy I will ensure that the Opposition Leader is also advised of any relevant developments in this matter.

I was further asked by Senator Bolkus: Is it a fact that ASIS is not regulated by any legislative charter? That is so. I was further asked by Senator Bolkus: Is ASIS not accountable at law for any of its actions? That is not so, and for anything that it does within this country it is accountable to the law in the same way as is any other organisation or citizen. That is a matter that is being considered now by the Victorian authorities, with whom the capacity for launching prosecutions, if appropriate, lies.

I was further asked by Senator Bolkus about financing and whether ASIS is not accountable for its financing. In that respect, the ASIS budget is part of the larger budget for the Department of Foreign Affairs, and there may be no direct accountability in the way that there is for the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation, which is a separately established statutory organisation.

Whether or not ASIS should have some legislative charter of its own is clearly one of the matters that will be addressed by Mr Justice Hope in the second part of his inquiry already in train, as well as, no doubt, these quite deplorable events that I have retailed today.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the fact that, under the income deprivation provisions of the proposed assets test, non-pensioner spouses of pensioners will be treated, in fact, as pensioners. Does the Sex Discrimination Bill presently before the Parliament set out to eliminate, as far as possible, discrimination against persons on the grounds of sex or marital status in the area of the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs? Does the Minister agree that the classifying of non-pensioner spouses in this way is discrimination on the grounds of marital status, and how is this action justifiable in the light of the provisions of the Sex Discrimination Bill?

—The answer to the first part of Senator Walters's question is that if she reads the Sex Discrimination Bill she will find that the application of the Social Servies Act is excluded from the Bill. Secondly, I do not believe that the matter she has raised is an example of sex discrimination at all. It is a matter of limiting as much as possible people's capacity to circumvent either the income test at the moment or the assets test in the future, should that assets test pass into legislation.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I did not say sex discrimination; I was referring particularly to discrimination on the ground of marital status. While the Minister said it is all right to discriminate on the ground of marital status in the social security legislation, he said he did not believe the matter I raised was discrimination on the basis of sex. I am talking about marital status.

—Dear me, it must be pedantics day today. I said it is my understanding that the Sex Discrimination Bill presently before the Senate excludes that Bill from applying to the Social Services Act, whether the discrimination is on the ground of the sex or marital status. I am sorry if I used the shorthand 'sex'; that is the shorthand reference in this place to the Bill. I correct that in a pedantic way and say that on the grounds of sex or marital status the Act is excluded. Therefore, to the first part of Senator Walters's question, whether this is contrary to the Sex Discrimination Bill, my answer is no, because the Social Services Act is excluded from such application.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. What is the Government's reaction to the result of the recent bond tender, reported in today's Press, which confirmed further falls in interest rates?
—It is appalled by the money supply figures.

—This is obviously a very sensitive subject. Is the Government now looking to reductions in home mortgage interest rates charged by the private banks, particularly in view of the fact that the private banks did not match the recent half per cent reduction in home loan interest rates recently made by the Commonwealth Savings Bank?
—The Government is pleased with the interest rates situation resulting from the bond tender of 29 November.
—How is the money supply?

—I might say, for Senator Chaney's edification, that the question I have just been asked was not a dorothy dixer; I was not aware of it coming. However, I am grateful to Senator Maguire for making the opportunity available, by his question, to provide a very limited reaction and say that the Government is content with the response to the bond tender of 29 November. The results are very satisfactory and confirm the general decline in interest rates which has been taking place. I simply make the additional point that many interest rates have already been lowered. Prime overdraft interest rates have gone down 2 1/2 per cent since the end of March and home loan rates have been reduced by 0.5 per cent, I am not sure when but within the last few weeks. Of course, the Government would be pleased to see these rates come down further and we are hopeful that that process will continue to take place. Insofar as any further ramifications of the honourable senator's question are concerned, I will obtain a more detailed answer from the Treasurer and advise him.

—Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate agree with the Prime Minister's view, reported in today's Australian newspaper, that uranium is unimportant as an issue in the Northern Territory? Is this extraordinary opinion a reflection of Mr Hawke's disregard for the very real concerns of Territorians, who are faced with the loss of hundreds of millions of dollars of job creating investment in uranium mines, and Aboriginal traditional owners in particular, who have been robbed of millions in expected royalty payments and who must now continue to exist on government handouts?

—I am not aware of the statement made by the Prime Minister but I assume that it was made in the particular context of saying that a number of things are important to Territorians in the course of the election campaign which is now taking place and having regard to their general view of the future of the Northern Territory. Senator Kilgariff has taken it upon himself to take a very subjective view of what the feelings, as he puts it, of Northern Territorians are on these matters. I do not think he is necessarily the most astute judge. Senator Kilgariff came into this Parliament representing the National Country Party, representing the feelings of that party, and once he got in this Parliament he changed from the Country Party to the Liberal Party. Whose feelings was he representing then?
—You are wrong.

—Senator Withers says I am wrong. He has come to life, after seven years of silence in the Senate, to tell me I am wrong, I suppose on a point of detail. The point is that Senator Kilgariff came into this Parliament under one set of colours and changed to another. Whose feelings was he representing then? I do not know whether his subjective judgment about this matter is right or wrong. It is probably no better than the Prime Minister's. I would have thought that a whole range of issues would be relevant to the people in the Northern Territory in the coming election. I cannot make the same sort of value judgments about that which Senator Kilgariff purports to make.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. It has recently been brought to the attention of the community at large that there is a connection between the past use of a drug, which was a synthetic oestrogen known as diethylstilboestrol, or DES and genital tract abnormalities and cancer. Has the Minister taken any steps to publicise this matter or to provide special diagnostic centres?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Hearn says, the drug diethylstilboestrol, or DES has long been known to be associated with the development of adenosis of the vagina or adenocarcinoma of the vagina in the offspring of women who have taken it during pregnancy. In the 1940s, largely, this substance was used for all sorts of things including, incorrectly, for the prevention of miscarriages, the suppression of lactation and a couple of other uses not associated with pregnancy. So this association has been known for some time and the drug is no longer used for these purposes. For years there has been considerable publicity about this connection. As far back as 1972 the Drug Evaluation Committee in Australia made this known to doctors, and I can remember that in 1975 and several times since there has been considerable information on it in medical literature. I doubt that there is a doctor in Australia who is not aware of this association. In Victoria, largely as a result of the activities of an organisation called DES Action, a conjoint program organised by the Victorian Government in co-operation with the Royal Australasian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists has established a referral clinic at the Royal Women's Hospital in Melbourne. An excellent booklet has been produced for doctors in Victoria which has had an distribution even beyond Victoria. In New South Wales a similar clinic operates at the King George V Memorial Hospital in Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: In the other States, largely because of lower population, less comprehensive action has been taken. The establishment of central referral clinics such as this is always a difficult thing in the medical profession, as anyone knows who is associated with them, and it is a particularly sensitive issue, I can assure honourable senators, amongst gynaecologists. The problem of the association of these diseases with the use of this drug is primarily one of detection, diagnosis and treatment. The drugs are not used in this way any more. Although it is an important problem from the point of view of all those individuals who may be affected and from the point of view of receiving early treatment, it is worthwhile remembering that, from memory, only seven cases of this form of adenocarcinoma have been reported to the Drug Evaluation Board. That does not mean they are the only cases but they would be a large proportion of the cases. There are also a few cases of adenosis of the vagina. So although it is a very important condition I would not like to give the impression that it is a very widespread condition or the incidence was large in our community. I repeat that that does not put down the importance of what DES Action, the Victorian Government, the New South Wales Government and the College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists are doing. Since the early 1970s there has been any amount of publicity given to this subject both directly by governments and through the medical literature; so, as I say, I doubt that there is a doctor in this country who is not aware of this potential problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate whether it is a fact that the review of the Australian system of tariff preferences, which commenced in December last year and which the Minister promised would be completed by June this year, is now completed. Is it also a fact that the submission from the Department of Industry and Commerce on the review is meeting opposition in Cabinet from the Minister for Trade and the Minister for Foreign Affairs? Will the Minister now inform the Senate when the Government's long awaited decision on this very important issue will finally be announced?

—It is true that the system was the subject of a review which commenced in December last year. I am asked whether I promised it would be completed by June. I am not sure that I was as precise as that, senator, but I certainly gave some indication that it would be finished as quickly as possible, and I thought by the middle of this year. The review is now completed. It is true that there is opposition to the findings of the review. I am not able to say precisely when the results of the examination of the review report will be complete and a decision announced. I think in part it is likely to be dependent on overseas visits made by certain Ministers in the near future.

—Has the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters seen a report in the Canberra Times headed: 'P.S. Compo Bill over $100 million'? This article is based on the annual report of the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation tabled yesterday, which points to a 33.1 per cent increase in payout in the last year. Can the Minister say whether this report is troubling to the Government and what steps will be taken to reduce this figure? In particular, will there be promotion of occupational health and safety measures to reduce accidental, injury and ill health in the Public Service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the report to which Senator Crowley refers but the contents of it have been drawn to my attention, and particularly the fact that the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation has estimated an increase of 33 per cent in payments under the scheme. I do not at this moment know the reason for this. That would require an examination of the report, I take it, and I will try to obtain a more detailed answer for Senator Crowley on the reasons for that very substantial increase in payments. Senator Crowley further asked if the Government was concerned about this. I speak only for myself, but I am sure I can say that of course the Government has to be concerned about this. I am also asked whether there are any steps being taken by the Government to try to redress the cost and damage which has been done by these increases in payments. Specifically I was asked whether the occupational health and safety proposals of the Government will assist in reducing the burden of compensation payments. Let me say that it is the Government's hope and belief that greater attention to occupational health and safety will assist with the reduction of compensation burdens not only under the Commonwealth legislation but also under the legislation of the various States. This is an issue which has been neglected by governments-I am not making a political point when I say this-for far too long in the face of enormous evidence of rising costs, industrial accidents and industrial illnesses in respect of which little has been done.

ANSWER.PARA: The proposals of this Government in respect of occupational health and safety, and particularly the proposals to establish a national occupational health and safety commission, are a very important step forward in trying to tackle this issue. That commission, of course, will work in conjunction with State authorities. As I say, whilst no overnight or magical solution can be found to these vast expenditures in relation to industrial accidents and work associated illnesses, it is a first and very positive step which we believe will bring results for the benefit of the Australian community in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Minister for Communications seen a Press release in the Sydney Daily Tele- graph of Saturday, 15 October which is headed: 'ABC Chief calls for school sex training'? Mrs Wendy McCarthy, the Deputy Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation said: 'Schools should introduce masturbation training programs for teenagers'. She also said: ' It would help them to become better sexually adjusted'.
—Are you against that?

—Yes, I am. She also said: 'It was time that masturbation was treated sensibly and taught by special teachers in schools'. Can the Minister inform the Senate if this is the official policy of the ABC? Does the Government endorse Mrs McCarthy's views? If the Government does not endorse the views of Mrs McCarthy will the Minister reprimand her for making these statements, as he did with her predecessor Professor Leonie Kramer? If the Government does not support these views and finds them offensive will the Minister give the Senate a categorical commitment that Mrs McCarthy's name will not be put forward as the commissioner for sex discrimination?

—Mr President, I am fascinated by the honourable senator's interest and concern about this topic. I must say that while he was asking the question I was wondering what his own view was, but as it comes in the form of a question of course it is my responsibility to say what the Government's position is in relation to this matter. First of all let me say it is not the Government' s position to interfere in the program content of the ABC. It is not our function--
—When did you change your view on that one?
—I changed my view on that one after I was chastised by Senator Walters. It was only after Senator Walters said a few words in the Senate about it that I changed my view.
—You really left yourself open.
—Are you talking about the last incident or today?
—Order! I ask the Minister to answer Senator Boswell's question.

—For the enlightenment of Senator Boswell, Miss McCarthy has denied that she said any such thing and said that the allegation to which the honourable senator referred is nonsense. That is my understanding of the matter. But, irrespective of whether she said that, it is not the Government's business to interfere in ABC program making. That is the position adopted by the Government.

—Has the Minister for Industry and Commerce seen newspaper reports of statements made by Mr Arthur Dunkel, the Director-General of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, during his visit to Australia? In particular, has the Minister seen reports of references by Mr Dunkel to the level of Australian tariff protection, his warnings about anti-dumping legislation and his support for unilateral Australian action to lower protection? In view of these and other comments attributed to Mr Dunkel, can the Minister assure the Senate that any anti-dumping measures that this Government contemplates would not be surrogates for general protection? Is it true that the question of protection cannot be addressed by concentrating only on tariffs and ignoring non -tariff provisions? Should Australia unilaterally lower its protection levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked about remarks attributed to the Director-General of GATT, Mr Dunkel, as reported in the newspapers following a speech he gave to the Australian Chamber of Commerce in Melbourne. I had the opportunity of meeting with Mr Dunkel last night for an hour and a half. One of the first observations which he made was that some of the Press reports of what he allegedly said were somewhat inaccurate. He went on to make the point that he will address the National Press Club next week. In the course of his address to the National Press Club he will distribute a written copy of what he has to say on these particular issues. That will be the text to which people can refer. Senator Cook asked me first about Australia's anti-dumping legislation. As the honourable senator will be aware, a number of proposed changes to that legislation were announced a few weeks ago.
—It is too slow.

—I inform Senator Watson that one of the changes announced was to speed up the process of dumping complaints. The Government does not see dumping as a matter associated with the protection debate generally. Dumping is a process for dealing with unfair trading practices and it is recognised by GATT anti-dumping legislation. The Australian legislation is consistent with its obligations under the GATT.

ANSWER.PARA: I was asked also whether I have any comments about non-tariff barriers which are imposed by various countries. The Department of Trade, as I understand it, has compiled a very comprehensive list of various non-trade barriers which are operated by countries other than Australia. Australian tariff and the system of protection operating in this country are relatively open. However desirable it might be considered to be one way or another, it is relatively open compared with many of the measures adopted by other countries. The Director-General of GATT is quite aware of that fact and is very much aware of the non-tariff barriers which are applied by other countries. Finally I was asked whether Australia will adopt any unilateral reductions in tariffs or protection measures . That is a question which I cannot answer and which for very obvious reasons I would prefer not to answer. It is subject to a variety of negotiations, both international and local. It depends on a wide variety of factors, and whether a decision would be made to do that at any particular time is something which I certainly cannot prejudge. Of course, it is a question to which the Government constantly has to give consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Education relates to the overflow meeting of parents in Sydney on 7 November protesting against the education policy changes of the Labor Government.
—Boring.
—Boring.

—I am interested in the interjections opposite. In view of the release in the last 48 hours of a detailed analysis of schools represented by parents at the meeting, I ask the Minister: Why did she deride those attending the meeting as being just an elitist group representing the narrow interests of some group 1 schools? Will she now acknowledge that among the 280 different schools represented by parents at the meeting, were parents from 130 group 3 Catholic schools? Will she now accept that the meeting represented the widest group of parents from the widest group of schools ever to come together in Sydney to protest about the education of their children?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure what Senator Peter Baume wants by way of reward or accolade for his efforts in--

ANSWER.PARA: Government senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Peter Baume was heard in silence and I ask for the Minister to be heard in silence.

—Obviously, Senator Peter Baume regards his participation in that meeting as the zenith of his parliamentary career and wants to keep drawing attention to it. He has not had such a big crowd before or since. If there were indeed representatives of 280 schools there, and some of them from category 3 schools, I presume that they were the ones who were cheering Mr Mulock because Mr Mulock and I are both responsible for increased funding to those schools. I just do not know how long I have to say what I have said almost daily in this chamber and to the media. The funding policies of this Government are more generous to the non-government sector than were the funding policies of any previous government. The increase which was achieved for the vast majority of schools in the non-government sector was substantial. The security and forward planning capacity that was given to the non-government sector by such matters as the increase in capital, the special allowance for new places in new schools in the non-government sector, the capacity to forward commit up to 70 per cent of capital funds, and the decision of this Government to give supplementation for wage and salary increases put the non-government sector on a much firmer footing in respect of Commonwealth funding than ever before.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it a fact that there existed a strong household relationship between the head of the Department of Foreign Affairs, Sir Peter Henderson, and the previous South African Ambassador, Mr John Oxley? Is the Minister aware of allegations by senior Foreign Affairs staff that this friendship led Sir Peter Henderson to breach the Fraser Government's South African policy? Did Sir Peter Henderson conceal these breaches from the Fraser Government?
—I have no idea whether there is any substance in the suggestions made by Senator Primmer. I will refer them to the Minister for Foreign Affairs to see what answer he may wish to make.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and refers to proposed Medicare advertising. I understand that country and non-daily newspapers are not to be used in the advertising schedule. Is the Minister aware of the significance of the country and non-daily newspapers to the smaller towns in the dissemination of information? Would the Minister take up the issue with the Minister for Health with a view to ensuring that country newspapers are included in the advertising campaign for Medicare?

—Being a country boy myself, I am well aware of the importance of country people and country newspapers. I will make inquiries as to whether the Medicare advertisements will be carried in country newspapers and if they are not why they are not. When I have that information I will make sure that Senator Bjelke-Petersen gets it soon after.

—Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations been drawn to the problems facing the Longreach Shire Council in relation to the forced lay-off of 50 per cent of the Shire's work force? Following the beginning of an early wet season in western Queensland work has been halted on the construction of two weirs that were being financed by money saved under the wage pause. Seventeen workers have been stood down because of the early wet season. Will the Minister consider urgently a submission put forward by the Longreach Shire Council under the Commonwealth Employment Program to upgrade roads and gutters in the main shopping centre in the town of Longreach and take any steps necessary to allow the Shire to re- employ those 17 workers laid off because of the early wet season?

—I am not aware of the specific problem that Senator Jones raised with me. In the terms in which the question is couched, the proposition that is advanced sounds eminently reasonable. I will certainly make urgent representations to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and ask him to give early consideration to the representation of the Longreach Shire Council.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. Is it the Government's intention to reduce further the assistance available to university residential colleges, following the recent reduction of 25 per cent, from $1 to 75c, per day per student? Will the Government give consideration at some future time to offsetting this disadvantage, particularly to non-metropolitan students, by increasing the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly the policy of this Government to increase the TEAS allowance as rapidly and as generously as economic circumstances permit. As I said in reply to an earlier question, the whole area of TEAS is under review with a view to removing some, at least, of the anomalies. I recognise that students who have to travel to universities, who do not have universities within their areas, are in a particular situation of need with regard to TEAS. That situation is not very satisfactorily accommodated by the present regulations.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the reduction in the subsidy of I think $9 a week to residential colleges within universities, the Government is aware that students who live in colleges are at this stage the only students who have their accommodation needs subsidised by the Commonwealth. There are enormous areas of need for assistance in accommodation for students who do not have access to colleges, who cannot afford to be in them. So the Tertiary Education Commission is reviewing the whole area of accommodation needs of students.

We expect in the next Budget to make some sort of subsidy arrangements which will give an equitable share of available Commonwealth funds for this purpose to students, whatever their accommodation circumstances are.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Why does not the Government initiate its review before acting in such cases, which would cause hardship to non-metropolitan students?

—The decision to which Senator Watson's question referred was a Budget decision. As he will be aware, the timetable that the early election allowed the new Government to develop a Budget in simply was not enough for it to institute major reviews and obtain results. The decision is, I believe, defensible, although we are always willing to listen to cases of hardship and to bring those considerations to the attention of the Tertiary Education Commission .

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of the recent visit to New Caledonia of the French Secretary of State for Overseas Territories? Can the Minister inform the Senate whether any new proposals for independence in the territory were made during the visit?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has noted the announcement last week in New Caledonia by the French Secretary of State for Overseas Territories, Monsieur Georges Lemoine, of proposals for a new statute for New Caledonia which he made during that visit. The proposals envisage a period of five years during which a substantial degree of internal autonomy will be exercised within the territory, followed by an act of self-determination, the details of which have yet to be worked out. It is envisaged that the new statute will be enacted by the French National Assembly in the first half of 1984.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government will continue to watch developments in New Caledonia closely. As is well known, Australia is committed to the independence of New Caledonia, determined according to the wishes of its inhabitants. Our main concern is that independence, which we see as inevitable, should be achieved peacefully. The Government has noted Press reports that Monsieur Lemoine had, following his visit to New Caledonia, commented that Australia should not interfere in New Caledonia. Monsieur Lemoine told a senior official of the Department of Foreign Affairs, during a stop-over in Sydney, that he wished to thank the Government for Australia's moderating role at the South Pacific Forum, which he had found to be helpful to France's efforts in New Caledonia. So there is no question of any bilateral difficulties arising over this rather sensitive issue at the moment.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: IMPORTED LIGHT COMMERCIAL AND FOUR-WHEEL DRIVE VEHICLES

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware of the article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 28 November on the subject of limiting the number of imported light commercial vehicles and four-wheel drive vehicles? Will he confirm the accuracy of the report that the Federal Government is expected to move early next year to limit imports of light commercial vehicles and four- wheel drive vehicles? I ask that in light of the apparent confirmation of that view by the Deputy Prime Minister in the House of Representatives yesterday.

—I am not aware of the article in the Sydney Morning Herald. If it says that the Government will limit the import of light commercial vehicles early in the new year, or something of that kind, it is not an accurate report because the Government has made no decision about that matter. Of course, the Government is not in a position to make a decision about it. We have referred that question to the Industries Assistance Commission. The report of the Commission will not be available until 14 December. We have also referred that matter to the Car Industry Council for consideration. It has been asked to give a view on the question on 14 December also. There is a departmental commissioned consultancy investigation into this matter. When we get the findings of that consultation we will be in a better position to make decisions about the issue raised in Senator Chaney's question and referred to in the Sydney Morning Herald .

—I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer, which reflects the facts as they have been published by him before. Has he had a chance to see the answer given by Mr Lionel Bowen in the House of Representatives yesterday? Does he agree that it seems to suggest that the matter is one on which the Government already has a clear view?

—I have not seen the answer and I certainly could not, between the time of Senator Chaney's original question and that of his asking the supplementary one, form an opinion on what Mr Bowen said. I have not seen Mr Bowen's answer, but my answer is that, irrespective of what Mr Bowen said, the Government has not deliberated and made a decision on the matter.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MR BRUCE BOND: STATEMENTS ON ASSETS TEST

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Social Security, refers to my question and his answer yesterday about Mr Bruce Bond and his use of Australian Broadcasting Corporation and other stations to broadcast his opposition to the assets test. Has the Minister seen Mr Bond's reported response in today's Sydney Morning Herald, accusing the Minister of being the gutless junior Senator from Tasmania? Has Mr Bond any grounds for his agitation? Has he actually denied what he has been accused of? Is it not true that Mr Bond does run a service as an investment adviser and that he conducts meetings, sometimes with the assistance of the ABC, for which people attending pay fees and at which he gives what may be called investment advice, yet he purports to deny this accusation by saying that he has a strict rule about not giving private financial advice?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention was drawn to the remarks by Mr Bond, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning. Being a sensitive soul, I was touched to the quick by them. I can understand his calling me the junior senator from Tasmania because of my youthful appearance.
—You're spunky, too.

—Thank you, senator. That interjection is now recorded in Hansard . I do not quite understand the word 'gutless'. I have been on a diet for months trying to reduce that section of my anatomy. If he is referring to my courage or lack of it, all I can say is that I am sure the two other ex-Ministers for Social Security in this place can say that one thing that Ministers for Social Security in this country are not is gutless. They have to face all sorts of people in all sorts of circumstances.
—You have the Order of the Sydney Town Hall.

—Senator Chaney and I have faced massess in the Sydney Town Hall and come out unscathed. However, as Senator Coates points out, when people use colorful language and unfortunate personal expressions such as this it usually means that they are trying to avoid the things that have been put to them. I said of Mr Bond: First of all, he appears on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation as an investment counsellor; secondly, he is paid a considerable fee for doing so; thirdly, he uses his position on the ABC to oppose Government policy, and again I have no objection to him doing that provided that when he enters the political arena he does not get upset when one of the people in the political arena bites back at him, as happened yesterday; fourthly, I said that I believed that he was unnecessarily worrying the people who rang him by his remarks about the assets test and in urging them to ring their members of parliament. Since yesterday I have made a check on the sorts of things Mr Bond has been saying, and in fact any reasonable person could only say that he is deliberately feeding the anxiety of the people who ring him.

ANSWER.PARA: My only remark is this: Mr Bond is in fact an investment counsellor. He does in fact benefit considerably by the inequities which exist in the social security system and the taxation system. He takes advantage of his highly paid position on the ABC to put his political views over. If he insists on doing that and what I call abusing his position, he must expect a response from people in the same political arena. I have no intention of allowing Mr Bond's unkind words about me from stopping me pointing out what he is up to, and I will continue to do so in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question of the Minister representing the Minister for Health follows the answer he gave Senator Hearn earlier in Question Time today on the subject of diethylstilboestrol. Is the Minister aware of recent publicity on the incidence of cancer in the children of women to whom DES was administered during pregnancy, notably the television current affairs program 60 Minutes, which indicates that a large number of Australian children, particularly girls, have become cancer victims as a result of this drug? Does the Minister agree that the figure of seven cases he quoted as being notified to the Drug Evaluation Committee is therefore clearly a hopelessly unreliable figure to depend on as a means of measuring the incidence of cancer in DES children and that the program of publicity he outlined by governments and through the medical literature must be concluded to be an abysmal and tragic failure? In view of the importance of early diagnosis of cancer if there is to be successful treatment, will he undertake to urge the Government to undertake an extensive program of open publicity to educate the children of women who were prescribed DES during pregnancy to have early health checks, a program similar to advertising programs in the United States of America?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not like to give the impression, and I believe I tried not to give the impression in answering the question from Senator Hearn, that I treated this subject with anything less than seriousness. I agree with Senator Martin that early diagnosis is important and that early treatment is also important. I am very much aware of the fact that children of mothers who were given DES and who were therefore exposed to DES in utero or during lactation are in fact more prone to the adenocarcinoma of the vagina and adenosis of the vagina to which she refers. I made the point that in fact considerable publicity has been directed to the medical profession and to the general populous in Victoria and, to a lesser extent, in New South Wales in recent years through the very good work of DES Action. In saying that seven cases were reported to the Drug Evaluation Committee I made the point that that may be an underestimate. I still think it is wrong to give the impression, as I believe the impression was given in certainly one program I saw-I am not sure whether it was 60 Minutes- that there is a sort of raging epidemic of this condition. In fact, not all children exposed to DES in utero or during lactation will develop the condition. I think what we need to do, as Senator Martin says, is make the potential condition known not only to doctors but also to potential victims of the condition.

ANSWER.PARA: I answered a question on this subject from Senator Haines a couple of months ago and sought from the Minister for Health just what was considered likely to be developed in this area in the future. I will do so again. I cannot recall just what action was announced by the Minister then. I wish to emphasise again that I do not think that this is an unimportant condition. I do not believe one should play down this at all. By the same token, I do not think we should give the impression that every daughter of every women who was pregnant in the 1940s and the early 1950s should believe she is likely to get one of these conditions. It is just not so.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1982-83
Debate resumed from 29 November 1983, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unless some other honourable senator is anxious to speak on this matter I propose again to seek leave to continue my remarks and to adjourn the debate. This matter would then become and order of the day and we could discuss the report at some later time. There is no wish on the part of the Opposition to prolong General Business unnecessarily. There are matters I wish to address on the next item that is listed for discussion, namely the annual report of the Uranium Advisory Council. At the same time I would be reluctant to see this matter slip away without honourable senators being given the opportunity to debate it further because very important matters are dealt with in the report. Since no one else seems to be poised on the edge of his chair, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1982-83
Debate resumed from 29 November 1983, on motion by Senator Martin:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —By arrangement with Senator Martin, I have received the call to speak on the report of the Uranium Advisory Council. I speak on this report in the context of the Uranium Advisory Council having ceased to exist since none of the members were reappointed when their commissions expired at the end of June. I think that in a formal sense the Chairman still holds office. It is important that the Senate note that this body which was set up following a recommendation of the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry is no longer available to the Australian Government. It is no longer available to the Parliament or to the Australian people to advise us on the highly contentious areas which do take up a great deal of debating time in this place and in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, it is important to note that the Council was set up as a multi-disciplinary body which would be available to deal with these matters. Its composition is of interest, I believe. The Chairman, Sir Richard Kingsland, is a retired public servant. The Alternate Chairman was the Chairman of the National Energy Advisory Committee and the Council comprised a senior lecturer in economics, a couple of conservationists, a professor of moral theology, an Aboriginal who is the director of the Bureau of the Northern Land Council and who is, I think, currently an Australian Labor Party candidate in the forthcoming Northern Territory election. I refer to Mr Wesley Lanhupuy. The Council also included Dr Letts, who is the Director of the Conservation Commission of the Northern Territory and who is, I think, campaigning in an independent capacity in the same election; Professor Parsons, who is President of the Academic Board of the University of Queensland; a mining consultant and a former dean of the Faculty of Medicine at the University of New South Wales in Sydney.

I suggest to the Senate that this group brought very great experience and a great range of disciplines and skills to bear on the problems on which it was asked to advise. The function of the Council was:

. . . to advise the Minister for Trade and Resources with regard to the export and use of Australian uranium, having in mind in particular the possible hazards , dangers and problems of and associated with the production of nuclear energy-

The Council was charged with the duty to prepare and furnish a report to this Parliament. I think it is a matter of very great regret that we have now lost the services of this Council, which was recommended by the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry. I think it is not hard to see why the Council has been disbanded by this Government. If we look at the range of papers presented in this report, we find that the Council directed itself to concerns about Aboriginal land rights and uranium. It directed itself to the possible problems involved in in situ leaching as a method of mining uranium, something which was proposed in two of the prospects in South Australia. It concerned itself with environmental evaluation methods and the environmental effects of fossil fuels, and so on. We are left in the dark as to what will replace the services of this body.

If one were to look at the advice given by the Council, it is quite clear why the Government would not welcome some of it, because it makes very disparate reading in the light of the decisions which this Government has taken in the short time it has been in power. In regard to sequential development, the Council said:

The Council has reviewed the issue of sequential development from time to time, coming to the view that it seemed unnecessary for the Government to intervene by imposing further controls over the uranium industry. Members noted that, particularly in the Northern Territory, the combined effect of the environmental regulatory requirements and the need to obtain Aboriginal agreement before development takes place, has produced de facto sequential development.
In another part of its report the Council stated:

Australia's possesses around 18 per cent of the world's identified low-cost uranium reserves and the Council accepts that there will be market opportunities to enable more Australian mines to develop in the 1980s.

The Council suggested that the mineral potential of Kakadu National Park be assessed before the final declaration of the second stage of the National Park. So we had this multi-disciplined group of people, with a lot of expertise, putting forward views which really raise significant queries about a number of decisions taken by the present Government. I do not believe that it is in Australia's interests that this Council should have ceased to exist, as it has done this year. I welcome the fact that we will have an opportunity to debate this report further and in more detail at some later time. I assume the debate will be adjourned this afternoon. I think my speaking time has now expired, so I can say nothing further, but I wish to pay tribute to the very useful work which has been performed by this Council. I hope that the Government might reconsider what I think is a decision against the dissemination of publicly useful information and against the provision of material to the public which would enhance the quality of public debate in Australia on this important subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as the Uranium Advisory Council went and could go, because of its constitution and charter, it did a useful job. The Australian Democrats expressed concerns from time to time that it could no prevent diversion of uranium into use for nuclear weapons, it could only detect such a diversion or any lack of safety and report on it. What good is that? Once a diversion is detected, it is too late. Sometimes I wonder what good it is to know that uranium is already on its way to being used to make a nuclear bomb. There is very little comfort in being told that.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of what Senator Chaney has so adequately said, I wish to confine my remarks to the Australian Atomic Energy Commission. The UAC urged the previous Government to provide a new legislative framework for the AEC's research establishment. Such a review needs to be wider than the UAC recommended. The Atomic Energy Act as a whole is a draconian piece of legislation which needs to be substantially redrafted. In fact, the kinds of provisions in this Act are mind boggling. For example, as honourable senators know, the Act renders people liable to a heavy fine or a prison sentence of up to 20 years in the event of hindering or obstructing uranium mining. Search and arrest are permissible without warrant. The burden of proof is on the defence. The accused can be convicted on the basis of conduct or charter which suggests disloyalty, even if the offence cannot be proven. Evidence of the defendant's past and guilt by association are all admissible, contrary to all the principles of justice. I will read into Hansard the infamous section 47 (a), which states:
On a prosecution of a person under paragraph (a) of section 44, section 45 or section 46-

(a) It is not necessary to show that he was guilty of a particular act tending to show an intent to prejudice the defence of the Commonwealth and, notwithstanding that no such act is proved against him, he may be convicted if, from the circumstances of the case, his conduct, or his known character as proved, it appears that he acted with intent to prejudice the defence of the Commonwealth-

I do not know of any more draconian provision in any Act on the statute books of this country. I do not know of any greater invasion of civil liberties than this . The Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry recommended that the Atomic Energy Act not be used as the legislative basis for uranium mining, but the Fraser Government ignored that advice. In 1977 it introduced the repressive amendment I have just read. Since 1980, again as part of the Fraser Government's manic desire to develop uranium mining and the nuclear industry, an interdepartmental committee has been examining the legislation required to regulate and control any nuclear industry. Senator Sir John Carrick, the predecessor of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), announced on 5 June 1982 that the Fraser Government 'foreshadowed far reaching changes to Commonwealth legislation on nuclear matters'. No such changes eventuated before 5 March of this year.

We believe that this Government should make the Parliament aware of its intentions concerning the changes which have been recommended to the Atomic Energy Act. The Democrats believe that this Act needs to be reshaped drastically to remove its repressive elements and to remove the substantial conflict which exists between the promotion of uranium mining and the regulation of uranium mining. It is wholly inappropriate for legislation to defend the interests of mining companies conducting profitable operations at the expense of civil liberties. We implore the Government to have an urgent look at this weakness in the legislation, which even the Fraser Government acknowledged when it was in office.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1982-83

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Some brief comment about the report of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation was alluded to in Question Time today. I wish to make some comments on the paper because of the quite horrific evidence that is contained in it. I do not find it quite so horrifying that compensation payouts have increased by 33 per cent, although I think that is a very large percentage increase. But that represents dollars spent. The facts in this report that quite stagger me are the figures listing the number of people who are injured, totally incapacitated or killed while working for the departments or authorities under Commonwealth jurisdiction.

On page 26 of the report it is listed that, in 1982-83, 106 new deaths were reported in total among the 544,000 employees covered by the Compensation ( Commonwealth Government Employees) Act. Three hundred and seventy-five deaths are listed as being in continuation, which means that the compensation considerations are in continuation. A total of 481 people died during their employment. Most of those deaths occurred while the people were on duty. If we look to a breakdown of the figures, we find that 316 of those deaths-that is, those that happened last year-and were in continuation, happened to employees within Commonwealth departments and 160 to employees in Commonwealth authorities . I guess Senator Kilgariff would be pleased to know that only five people died in the Northern Territory departments.

Apart from noting those deaths, I think the other significant reportage here is that some $70m is paid out by way of compensation to people who are judged to be totally incapacitated. Again, I think that such an entry in a report can be passed over quite lightly. What it means is that those people will never work again. I think that is a matter of great seriousness. Not only do we need to look at it in terms of how we can reduce enormous costs-$100m plus in payout of compensation-but also we must be careful not to overlook the measure of human misery associated with the many people who die or become totally incapacitated in the course of their employment in the Commonwealth Public Service and authorities. I know that the report uses the term 'total incapacity' to describe not only those who are medically judged as unable to work, but also those who are able to work only in an area in which there are no jobs. I presume it means that some people could lose an expertise and there would be no other comparable area of employment for them. But, by and large, I think the report is referring to people who are judged totally unable to work.

I wish to draw attention to some comments in the report which appear under the heading 'Training and inspections'. Many words in the report are devoted to an analysis of the training and inspection which the departments provided to look at the whole problem. Essentially, the report addressed the lack of facilities and administrative procedures within the departments. Seminars were conducted, which are very important, I argue, for delegates and persons located outside the Commissioner's office who are actively involved in processing claims. The principal reason for the training and upgrading of people in this area is the enormous delay in processing claims. Over the last year an average of two-thirds of claims were processed within 12 weeks. However, a large number of claims had not been processed within 12 months.
As well as the delays there were other administrative weaknesses, including incorrect determinations of claims leading to incorrect payments. It was reported:
. . . frequently claims were approached with something less than a complete impartiality;
the system does not lend itself to automatic processing;
adequate statistics in the important field of occupational injury and disease are not easily obtainable.

I believe that is the only time the words 'occupational injury and disease' are mentioned. Much of this report is devoted to upgrading the facilities and the personnel who could then go through the business of processing compensation claims. That is very important. I would not want to be understood to be denigrating that part of the work, but the emphasis is devoted to fixing the problem after the accidents, the deaths and the injuries have occurred. The line in this report that I think needs to be expanded in the next while is the important business of proper collection of data about occupational injury and disease and a further emphasis on prevention and the planning of job and work situations so that occupational injury and disease do not even happen. If I had $100m to spend, I would much rather spend it on preventive processes in the departments than on paying people who are injured or dead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Crowley, I wish to comment on the 1982-83 annual report of the Commissioner for Employees Compensation. It is unfortunate, as I think Senator Crowley has very adequately pointed out, that the attention that this report has received in the media has concentrated on money costs-the cost to the Commonwealth of workers' compensation payouts. That is a major aspect. It costs the Commonwealth $100m to meet compensation payments for employees who have suffered accident or injury in its employ. However, Senator Crowley pointed to the real heartbreaking story that never made the headlines, that is, the human misery, the cost of human accident, sickness, disease and disablement. That is a cost that is not measured in dollar terms, but it is a very serious cost. It is a cost which I believe the Commonwealth, like any employer, has a basic and fundamental responsibility to address. The Commonwealth has over half a million employees. If we take the compensation bill of $1,600,000, the obvious question is: How can the Commonwealth, as an employer , reduce that, save money and thus be able to allocate more expenditure to well meaning, important and necessary programs?

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things that can be said straight off, as Senator Crowley has pointed to, is that by making a bold investment in accident prevention and occupational health the Government can save itself the cost of compensating for failures because of accidents and/or work circumstances that cause ill-health. I do not know that it is possible to eradicate all of the $1m, but it is certainly possible to reduce a lot of that amount. The only way I believe that can be done is by diverting funds to accident prevention and safety. The pity about workers' compensation debates is that they do tend to concentrate on money costs. The knee-jerk response is that because costs are high we must reduce benefits. As I have said, prevention is the way forward. It is unfortunate that the Commissioner does not have the wider responsibility that I think is necessary for any compensation body.

There are three areas of concern, not one. The first is prevention; the second is compensation-where prevention has failed-and the third is rehabilitation of workers so they can return to the work force where they are able to be rehabilitated. It is important, I think, to look at all three areas and not concentrate on just one. If we start at the beginning and look at prevention, the costs can be severely reduced. If we also contribute to rehabilitation, people who are now thrown on the scrap heap of industrial life can return to a meaningful role in the work place.

It is unfortunate that public debates in Australia tend to rail against the number of man days lost to industrial disputes. That takes the headlines, that takes the debate in this chamber and that takes a huge legislative effort by the Government. If we look at the man days lost and damage done to the national productivity because of accidents, we find thay are invariably higher, the damage is much deeper and the loss of productivity greater. Yet this field attracts little attention. It is not a field attended to much in debate. It passes almost unremarked on in the media. We have got our priorities wrong. Our priority must be directed towards lowering the accident level, saving lives, preventing injury and disablement and encouraging people to be safe in the work place.

This report makes a number of quite important points in the tables, but we have to dig deeply for them. In 1973-74, 441,000 people were employed by the Commonwealth Government. The number of accidents was 31,000, which meant about 7 .09 per cent of employees suffered accidents. Last financial year 9.51 per cent of employees suffered accidents, so the incidence of accidents is on the increase. If we look at the costs in money terms, something I am loath to do but nonetheless the report makes the point, in 1973-74 it cost $27 per accident. According to the report it now costs $184 per accident, which is an increase in money costs much higher than the level of inflation. There are a number of recommendations in the report for change, mainly dealing with delays and the correction of a number of identifiable weaknesses. I think those changes should be made and supported. I also think the whole trinity, prevention, compensation and rehabilitation, should be attended to in one authority.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1982-83

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Very briefly, I refer to one or two matters in this report. The Repatriation Review Tribunal was established by the Liberal-National Party Government in 1979 . The Repatriation Legislation Amendment Act came into force on 28 October 1982. The significant thing that I believe needs to be observed is that at least two important recommendations in that legislation have had success in their early stages, in the first year of operation under those provisions. Constantly the appeals and application area in this field has been very slow in being attended to.

Two of the provisions to which I refer and which need to be observed are that, in the first place, the Tribunal was given the discretion to give oral reasons for its decisions; and, secondly, the Tribunal was to await instruction that the applicant was ready to proceed before calling on a case. As a result, cases have been heard much more promptly than was the situation in the past. Consequently it is of importance to note that in 1982-83 there has occurred the first occasion on which the number of applications has been fewer than the number of solutions or approvals by the Tribunal. This certainly is a step in the right direction because there has built up, over the years, a great deal of frustration over a continuing pile of applications and unheard or delayed appeals. The objective of the amendments in 1982 was in some way to overcome this delay and in some way to reduce the continuing pile of unheard appeals. It is interesting and I think important to note that on this occasion the report reveals that the solution to part of that problem has been found.

This Tribunal provides an independent review of decisions made by the Repatriation Board, the Seamen's Pensions and Allowances Committee and the Repatriation Commission. It comprises, of course, a panel of three. It has power to observe, naturally, the evidence of past circumstances and any new evidence that may be brought before it. There is also the power of appeal to the Federal Court of Australia on matters relevant to law. Incidentally, the Tribunal is somewhat more informal in its manner of hearing and is not bound by the technicalities, legal forms and rules that so strictly applied formerly. These changes have been seen to be moves in the right direction and, together with the admission of oral reasons, which are given of course forthwith, and written reasons which are given within two weeks of the hearing's conclusion, the whole program has been significantly quickened.

I make these few observations on the working of this Tribunal under its latest form and suggest that the provisions that have been put in place are working and that, for the first time in many years, some progress is being made in the resolution of these appeals.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 May 1983, on motion by Senator Teague:
That the Senate oppose any aid from Australia to Vietnam so long as Vietnamese military forces are occupying Kampuchea and Laos.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave the first half of my speech on this subject in May. Those who are unfamiliar with the practices of this Parliament might think that somewhat strange. The debate is on a motion by Senator Teague:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate oppose any aid from Australia to Vietnam so long as the Vietnamese military forces are occupying Kampuchea and Laos.

I remind the Senate of what I said at that time. In the first half of my contribution I said that the debate was about economic development aid; for a number of reasons, I supported such aid to Third World developing countries; I was not too concerned by the political colour of the relevant regimes; the Liberal Government was giving such aid to communist Vietnam, but the aid program was cancelled on 21 January 1979 upon Vietnam's invasion of Kampuchea; it was cancelled as part of a strong response by Australia and other Western nations to the invasion-Japan, Denmark and Britain cancelled, I believed, at that time; by mid-1979, as I understood it, all but Sweden had cut off foreign economic aid.

Circumstances since the time of the invasion do not appear to have changed a great deal. Vietnam, despite experiencing such withdrawal of economic assistance and the continual diplomatic efforts of many countries, remains in occupation and maintains the Heng Samrin Government which it installed. My Party's position has been that the aid which was cancelled as a protest upon invasion should not be re-instituted whilst the occupation continues.

In summary, I believe the reasons for that to be: Such aid can only encourage Vietnam's intransigence; security fears are held by certain countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations, particularly Thailand, which shares a common boundary with occupied Kampuchea; there is a fear that the occupation of Kampuchea by a pro-Soviet force is threatening to China and, therefore, contrary to the stability of the region-I speak of the encirclement theory, China being concerned by possible encirclement by Soviet or Soviet-backed regimes; and the expansion of Soviet influence by the concessions that must be given by Vietnam regarding Soviet military bases for nuclear submarines and long range aircraft in return for military aid in Kampuchea is against not only the regional security interests but also East-West security interests.

I know that it is possible to take-and, in some ways, to take legitimately-a contrary position on this matter. It can be said that aid by the West will lessen the dependence of Vietnam on the Soviets and that that is in the West's best interests. It can be said that Thailand is not militarily threatened by Vietnam, and that in fact, if there is a military threat-and we have witnessed border incursions-it arises from the support of and supply of Cambodian resistance groups in the border region. It can be said that the Cambodian people , although clearly not liking the presence of traditional enemies, would rather that presence remain than a return of the murderous Khmer Rouge regime. It can be said that China's supply of arms to the Khmer Rouge and its militaristic stance on Vietnam's northern border give Vietnam reason to believe that withdrawal from Kampuchea and its replacement with a pro-China government would threaten its security.

I appreciate that all these positions can be maintained, and with some credibility, and I think that indicates the complexity of the position. Those who seek peace for humanitarian reasons, for reasons of regional security, and for even wider security reasons therefore have a very difficult task. Not only are we looking at a region of historical enemies; we are also now looking at a centre of great power rivalry. Kampuchea is now, regrettably, where East meets West, certainly as far as fighting between communist forces and the non- communist forces of Son Sann and Prince Sihanouk is concerned, such forces being supplied in part by the West. It is also an area now where Sino-Soviet interests clash-Chinese supported and supplied Khmer Rouge forces against Soviet supported and supplied Vietnamese. This again tends to indicate the great difficulties faced by those who wish to influence change in the region for the better.

In relation to the specific question which is the subject of this motion, what a government must consider, in this case a responsible Australian government, is whether a change of policy to renew aid, whilst the position of the occupation remains basically unchanged, will help or hinder resolution of the difficulties that I have outlined. The approach of Foreign Minister Hayden appears to have been to attempt to obtain greater credibility with Vietnam and then, I think, to give him some credit, to act in the role of an honest broker. He may well have wanted to do this by resuming aid, which is in accordance with Labor Party policy, but this was found too internationally difficult to be carried out unilaterally; so, alternatively, he adopted a different approach to indicate a change of stance. He approached the matter from a diplomatic point of view. That change of position was indicated in ways which to some not familiar with the foreign affairs world might appear somewhat subtle but which to those who are so familiar, are obvious-by, for example, changing Australia's position with regard to sponsoring the annual United Nations motion condemning the occupation of Kampuchea and by failing to condemn the invasion in speeches in which such condemnation is traditionally included. So by diplomatic means he attempted to achieve the same object as would have been achieved by unilaterally renewing economic and development aid to Vietnam.

The effect has been twofold. First, it has been to disappoint ASEAN which, although it may have different internal views as to the future dangers from Vietnam and China, is certainly united when Western regional countries take an overtly more favourable stand towards Vietnam and its occupation. Secondly, the effect has been to disappoint China, for reasons of its perception that Vietnam is a threat, as I have previously outlined. The overall effect is that Australia has now a greater credibility with Vietnam-I think. I hesitate because I think that credibility was building under the previous Government through different methods. I reflect upon the family reunion agreements which had been negotiated and concluded before the former Government lost office. On the one hand, the Government may have gained this greater credibility with Vietnam; but, on the other hand, it has done so at a considerable cost, that of losing credibility with our allies; in other words, giving the Government and Mr Hayden the benefit of good motives, it has shown bad judgment, and exactly the same thing would have happened if we had resumed aid to Vietnam. The sum of aid would have been so insignificant as not to affect Vietnam's reliance on the Soviets, and we would have similarly lost credibility with ASEAN and China.

What do we want? Clearly, without dispute, I think we want Vietnamese troops withdrawn from Kampuchea and Cambodians to be given an opportunity freely to determine their own destiny. That is the ASEAN position and an ASEAN goal, and that is what we should be pursuing. The ASEAN policy so far has failed. As credible friends, behind closed doors and not on the world stage, we could have been urging some changes of direction in that policy. For example, Vietnam clearly will not withdraw whilst there is a likelihood of a pro-China Khmer Rouge victory. It will clearly not be bled white, as has been previously suggested. Therefore, it will not withdraw whilst the Khmer Rouge is being supplied by or through ASEAN. I am not convinced that that part of the unofficial policy of ASEAN is desirable. If that is the Government's view, within the club or the friendship it could have been urging change. But it is no good now. Not surprisingly, ASEAN no longer wants our views. We want to see a lessening of tension between China and Vietnam. We may have been able to assume a role, but certainly that is not the case now because in this area we have, as I have indicated, lost the confidence of China.

We want to see less dependence by Vietnam on the Soviets but any package aimed at obtaining that goal had to be multinational and clearly heavily involve ASEAN and China. One suspects that if we cannot maintain the confidence of ASEAN in this area we will be regarded more cautiously by the major Western nations, and therefore there appears to be little role for us now in the development of such a package. Therefore, Mr Deputy President, the Labor Government in this difficult area sought to become a major player. It chose to treat diplomacy as if it had become a card game and it chose a difficult card game. The Foreign Minister chose to do diplomatically that which he could have done by renewing unilaterally development aid, but the effect was the same. The effect was that he was blundered out of the game. What that indicates is that the policy of the former Government not to resume aid while the occupation continued was correct. Regrettably, as a result of the Government's bad judgment, it will now be more difficult for us to contribute to a change for the better in the future in a region that honourable senators must agree has suffered for far too long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Some eight senators have participated in this debate, which began on 5 May when I moved:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate opposes any aid from Australia to Vietnam so long as Vietnamese military forces are occupying Kampuchea and Laos.

I believe just as strongly today as I did when this motion was first moved that the Senate should adopt it. Although, besides myself, only Senator Lajovic and Senator Sir John Carrick from New South Wales, Senator Kilgariff from the Northern Territory, Senator Hill, my Liberal colleague from South Australia, Senator Georges from Queensland, Senator Elstob, also from South Australia and Senator McIntosh from Western Australia have spoken to the motion, there has been wide interest in this matter of Australia's relations with Vietnam and the problems of Indo-China. They have been expressed not only in this debate but also, of course, by the way in which all of us have taken an interest in the foreign policy statements of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and in the toings and froings with the Association of South East Asian Nations. Some of the time ASEAN has mistaken the intentions of the present Labor Government with regard to Indo-China and all of us have tried to seek a solution to the vexed problems of Indo-China.

In this debate, as in Australia at large, we all have the view that Vietnam's troops in Kampuchea and Laos should withdraw.
