It is still the case, six months after this debate began, that there are 180,000 Vietnamese troops or thereabouts , in Kampuchea and 45,000 Vietnamese troops in Laos. All sides of this chamber agree that, firstly, we should work towards those troops leaving Kampuchea and Laos and, secondly, that the people of Kampuchea and Laos should be able to be free to determine their own government, free of the constraints of force of an occupying power-or, indeed, free of such a minority insurrectionist revolutionary and hateful power as the Khmer Rouge. These views are commonly held in this chamber and about the country.

But more than that, as has been expressed in this debate, all of us are looking to the time when Australia will contribute humanitarian aid to Vietnam. No one disputes that Vietnam is a poor country. It happens, I think misguidedly, to spend the great bulk of its national product on military armaments. The Government of Vietnam is gripped with a security phobia, a security anxiety, which has been the result of a whole generation of its leaders being preoccupied with security and war. We should take every practical step to try to broaden the concerns of the Vietnamese Government and try to gain, by its own decision, a more usual, smaller spending of the resources of its people on armaments- especially armaments that are being directed against the neighbouring countries it is occupying.

I think there has also been reflected in this debate, from all sides, a preference that Vietnam not be so dependent upon the Soviet Union. A number of honourable senators have referred to the enormous dependence that Vietnam now has on the Soviet bloc and on the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance, or COMECON, generally. The area of difference in the debate is that Government senators have placed such an emphasis on wooing Vietnam away from total dependence on the Soviet Union that they have urged a renewal of humanitarian aid to Vietnam by Australia. So we are starting to see some further access by Australia, some credibility for Australia's dialogue with Vietnam, in these other concerns. I repeat that all of us would like to see the situation return whereby it is possible for us to offer some humanitarian assistance to a country which has complex difficulties and considerable poverty. Where members of the Opposition differ from the remarks of Senator Georges, Senator McIntosh and to some extent Senator Elstob is that we believe, as this motion requires, that aid to Vietnam from Australia should be available only after Vietnamese troops are withdrawn from Kampuchea and Laos.

There was also a difference of opinion in the debate in regard to the extent to which Government members are prepared to listen to and give full account to the views of our neighbours in ASEAN, China, Japan and the United States. It is the Opposition members who have emphasised the importance of listening to our neighbours and taking account of their views in accordance with the support that we have urged for this motion. The Government has been much less conscious of the views of our neighbours and has been prepared to go to on extravagant missions, attempting to initiate a new way, at the expense of Australia's relations with ASEAN, in particular, but also at the expense of Australia's relations with the United States, China and Japan.

Whilst the Opposition speakers in this debate have deplored the extent of the military occupation of Kampuchea and Laos, there has been little reference to this by Government speakers. Rather, they have emphasised the hateful regime of Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge, and the millions of Kampuchean people who were massacred during their period of government. They have so emphasised this point- a point which again all of us agree with as none of us in Australia wishes to see such a hateful, extreme and murderous communist regime come to power again in Kampuchea-that it would almost excuse the Vietnamese occupation. Senator McIntosh went very close to saying that he noted that the Vietnamese occupation of Kampuchea and Laos prevented a resurgence of the Pol Pot regime, and he implied that the Pol Pot, Khmer Rouge force would bring more sorrow and more suffering to the people than the occupation of Vietnam. In this respect, I think he is probably right, but they are not the only two options. So I reiterate, as a Liberal senator, that there ought to be some middle path which excludes both an occupying force from Vietnam and any ease for the Khmer Rouge to reassert itself in Kampuchea.

I conclude this summary of the debate by referring to the aid that the Whitlam Government began to Vietnam, with public support in Australia, and which was continued and increased by the Fraser Government. The Australian people wish to respond to the humanitarian needs of their neighbours and seek to have a major Australian development assistance program in South East Asia and in the Pacific region. At the present time, we are rather critical and wanting to assist, whether we are achieving our objectives in development assistance programs in our region. But, certainly, the Australian people supported the Whitlam Government and the Fraser Government initiatives to give such humanitarian assistance to Vietnam. All of us alike, I repeat, look to the day when that may continue because there is undoubted poverty and undoubted need to which we may offer assistance to help to solve.

Senator Hill rightly referred not only to the poverty of Vietnam, as Senator Elstob did, and the call that that leads to in the Australian community in considering how we can help that poverty, but also to the trade that is generated by an assistance that we may give that develops a capacity for trade in Vietnam. He also rightly referred to Australia having access to Vietnam and to Vietnam not being isolated in its dependence upon the Soviet Union. These sentiments and arguments which I now repeat only reinforce the view that all of us in the chamber, as expressed in this debate, look to the time when we may see Australian aid resumed responsibly in humanitarian aid programs to Vietnam. But the essential judgment-and it is a vexed question-is: When is the time? I repeat that the Fraser Government's aid program ceased in January 1979, on the day when the Vietnamese armies occupied Kampuchea. I believe that the Senate should now support this motion by affirming that, as long as those troops remain in Vietnam , we will not see that development aid program returned. We look to the time when Vietnam will withdraw all of its troops which are now occupying Kampuchea and Laos. Immediately upon such withdrawal we look to the Senate reinforcing the view that the Australian Government will then renew development aid assistance to Vietnam. I call upon all honourable senators to support the motion.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Teague's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to reform and modernise the law relating to certain contracts of insurance so that a fair balance is struck between the interests of insurers, insureds and other members of the public and so that the provisions included in such contracts, and the practices of insurers in relation to such contracts, operate fairly, and for related purposes.
Bill presented and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Bill I am introducing today is to reform and modernise, on a national basis, the law relating to contracts of insurance. These measures were foreshadowed in a joint Press statement that I issued with the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 17 October 1983 in which we announced the Government's intention to introduce legislation to implement the major recommendations of the Law Reform Commission's report on insurance contracts. I will outline, for the benefit of honourable senators, the background to the need for reform in this area and some of the principal reforms proposed. A detailed description of the provisions of the Bill is contained in the explanatory memorandum which has been circulated to honourable senators for information.
The need for reform

In September 1976, the Australian Law Reform Commission-ALRC-was given a reference by the then Attorney-General which required the Commission to report upon the adequacy of the law governing contracts of insurance. This reference resulted in two related, but self contained, reports from the Commission. The Law Reform Commission, in its first report on insurance agents and brokers , ALRC 16, dealt with the rules applicable to the conduct of insurance intermediaries. That report was completed in 1980. The former Government failed to implement the recommendations in ALRC 16, notwithstanding the clearly demonstrated case for the regulatory control of insurance brokers. The Australian Labor Party has, however, long recognised the need for these reforms and, as shadow Attorney-General, I introduced the Insurance (Agents and Brokers) Bill 1981. This Bill, based squarely on the draft Bill appended to ALRC 16, was subsequently passed by the Senate though not by the House of Representatives. The recent spate of broker insolvencies has further underlined the urgent need for controls and the Government is now working towards the early introduction, by the Treasurer, of legislation that will build on the private member's Bill that I introduced when in opposition.

The second report of the Law Reform Commission on Insurance Contracts, ALRC 20, was completed at the end of 1982. A commitment to give immediate priority to the consideration of this report, with a view to the early implementation of its major recommendations, was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in the Labor Party policy speech on 16 February 1983 and by me in launching the Party's business regulation policy on 24 February 1983. The Law Reform Commission reported that reform of the law relating to insurance contracts was long overdue . The case for reform was stated succinctly in paragraph 16 of ALRC 20:

Insurance contracts are subject to a bewildering variety of laws. First there are principles and rules developed by the judges. Superimposed on these rules are statutes of the Imperial, State and Commonwealth parliaments. The Imperial Acts are expressed in archaic and obscure language. Many of the problems they were destined to remedy were different from those of today. State intervention has generally been piecemeal and sporadic. In some cases, it has been limited to particular types of transaction and has been enacted on a uniform basis. In others, individual States have passed legislation applying generally to deal with particular insurance problems. In many of these cases, the legislation dealing with insurance contracts has been restricted to the field of life insurance. It, too, has given rise to anomalies and uncertainties which need to be corrected.

The Law Reform Commission recommended the making of a national law regulating insurance contracts that would be superimposed on, and effect reform of, existing laws. The Government has accepted this recommendation for the following reasons:
Insurance, other than State insurance within the boundaries of the State concerned, is a specific Commonwealth power. This industry is now organised on a national basis.
The Government accepts the Law Reform Commission finding that insurance contracts are subject to a bewildering variety of laws which have given rise to anomalies and uncertainties.
These existing laws have not kept pace with social and economic developments in the community.
The level of complaints from dissatisfied policy holders shows that there is a need for change.
Public consultation

The insurance industry and other interested groups and individuals were extensively consulted by the Law Reform Commission in preparing its report. The Government proposes, however, to let the Bill lie on the table to enable public submissions to be made on its detailed provisions. It also proposes to hold consultations with the insurance industry and consumer and other relevant groups before passage of the Bill. Public submissions should be sent to the Business Affairs Division of my Department by no later than 3 February 1984.
State insurance

Because of limitations on the Commonwealth's constitutional powers with respect to insurance, the Law Reform Commission recommended that the legislation should not extend at the outset to State insurers or to co-insurance involving a State insurer except to the extent that the insurance extends beyond the limits of the relevant State and, further, that the Commonwealth should consult with the States about the application of the legislation to intra-State insurance activities. The Government has decided that it would be undesirable to apply the legislation at the outset to only part of the activities of the State Government insurance offices. Instead, I have written to the Attorneys-General in each State and the Northern Territory seeking to gain their agreement to the application of the Commonwealth legislation to both intra and extra-State insurance activities.
Content of Bill
The basic purpose of the Bill is:

to improve the flow of information from the insurer to the insured so that the insured can make an informed choice as to the contract of insurance he enters into and is fully aware of the terms and limitations of the policy; and
to provide a uniform and fair set of rules to govern the relationship between the insurer and the insured.
As recommended by the Law Reform Commission, the Bill will not apply to:
reinsurance;
medical and hospital insurance written by any organisation registered under the National Health Act 1953;
workers' compensation and compulsory third party insurance; and
insurance to which the Marine Insurance Act applies.
Some of the more important reforms in the Bill are set out below.
Standard cover contracts

Existing law does not regulate the terms of insurance contracts and so does not provide for minimum cover. Clause 35 of the Bill provides that regulations may prescribe the standard cover to be given by certain classes of contract. The Law Reform Commission recommended that those classes should include motor vehicle, houseowner's, householder's, sickness and accident, consumer credit and travel insurance. Should the insurer seek to provide less than the minimum cover provided by the standard cover, for example, by excluding liability for loss caused by earthquake, he will be required under Clause 36 of the Bill to prove first that he gave notice to the insured, or that the insured knew, that he would be entitled to a lesser cover.
Notification of unusual terms

The present law is based on an assumption that the insured and the insurer are on an equal footing. Consequently, the insurer is not required to advise the insured of any particular terms in the contract. Clause 38 of the Bill recognises that the insured is often less well-informed than the insurer and accordingly requires the insurer to give the insured a written statement of the effect of any terms not usually found in contracts of insurance providing similar cover. Should the insurer fail to do so, he will be unable to rely on that unusual term. If he has not already done so, the insurer, upon receiving a written request from the insured, must give the insured a written statement setting out all the provisions of the contract. The insurer will be subject to a penalty of $5,000 should he fail to give the statement.
Reasons for cancellation to be given

Under present law, an insurer may cancel a contract or refuse to renew it without giving reasons to the insured. This can give rise to great hardship when the insured tries to arrange alternative cover. Clause 75 of the Bill requires the insurer to give the insured a written statement of his reasons should he cancel a contract or refuse to renew it.
Non-disclosure and misrepresentation

Contracts of insurance require that both the insurer and the insured display the utmost good faith. The Bill recognises this but mitigates the common law rule that an insurer may avoid a contract whenever the insured fails to disclose , whether innocently or fraudulently, every material circumstance which he knew an insurer would regard as relevant in assessing the risk. This rule imposes too strict a duty on the insured and, accordingly, clause 22 of the Bill provides that the insured's duty is only to disclose those facts which he knew, or which a reasonable person in his position would have known, to be relevant to the insurer's assessment of the risk.

Only fraudulent misrepresentations by the insured will entitle an insurer to avoid the contract, clauses 29 and 30 of the Bill. A court will be empowered under clause 32 of the Bill to diregard that avoidance if it would be harsh and unfair not to do so. Should the insurer choose not to avoid the contract or should the misrepresentation or breach of the duty to disclose be innocent rather than fraudulent, the insurer's liability will be reduced by an amount which represents the loss suffered by the insurer by reason of the misrepresentation or breach of duty. Furthermore, clause 60 of the Bill will enable the insured in these circumstances to cancel the contract as regards future liability.
Insurable interest

As the law now stands, an insured must, under most contracts of insurance, hold an insurable interest at the time of the execution of the contract. In the case of contracts of general insurance, he must also hold an insurable interest at the time when loss occurs. The Law Reform Commission took the view that in most cases of general insurance these rules were based on historical accident rather than on any clear legislative policy. Clause 18 of the Bill therefore provides in effect that an insured may enter into a contract of general insurance even when he does not have an insurable interest in the subject matter and that he may recover under the contract provided he has suffered economic loss by damage to, or destruction of, the subject matter. Under clause 19 of the Bill an insured will still be required to have an insurable interest at the time he enters into a contract of life insurance or a contract providing for the payment of money on the death of a person by sickness or accident.
Privity of contract

At common law, the doctrine of privity of contract will generally mean that a third party who is not the insured but who it is intended should be covered by the insurance contract, is in fact unable to claim. In State jurisdictions, the common law has been modified so that third parties can recover at least as far as compulsory third party insurance is concerned. Clause 48 will further modify the law. It will permit a third party, who is specified or referred to in a contract of general insurance as the person to whom the cover extends, to recover his loss from the insurer. Clause 48 will also make a similar modification to the doctrine of privity of contract in relation to a contract of life insurance. To a certain extent this modification has already been in operation by virtue of section 94 of the Life Insurance Act 1945. Section 94, however, is much more cumbersome, difficult to interpret and limited in its operation.
Subrogation

Unless expressly excluded by the terms of a general contract of insurance an insurer is subrogated, that is, substituted, to any rights the insured has against a third party in respect of loss or damage to the subject matter of the insurance contract. The right of subrogation does not exist in relation to contracts of life insurance or to the usual forms of personal accident insurance . The Law Reform Commission considered that the insurer's right of subrogation was not appropriate where the issue of double indemnity is not likely to arise. Consequently, clause 65 of the Bill provides that the insurer is not entitled to be subrogated to the insured's rights against a third party who:
has a family or other personal relationship with the insured or, in the case of a motor vehicle insurance, had his consent to use the vehicle concerned; and
is not himself insured.

As recommended by the Commission, the insurer will have no such right of subrogation where the insured's rights were against his employee, clause 66. The Commission concluded that such a right can damage industrial relations and thus runs counter to the reasonable expectation of both employers and employees that the employer and his insurer will bear the risks attendant upon employment.
Proposals in Law Reform Commission Report not taken up in Bill

The Law Reform Commission recommended that an insurer should not be able to cancel a group of general insurance policies without the approval of the Insurance Commissioner who would have to have regard to the insurer's financial position and its risk exposure if the group of policies was not cancelled. Furthermore, it recommended that the Insurance Commissioner and the Life Insurance Commissioner should have wide powers to compel the withdrawal of misleading insurance documents. These will not be provided for in the Bill which is to be self-regulating. The Treasurer will consider both these proposals separately.

A number of other recommendations of the Law Reform Commission, which do not relate to the law governing terms and conditions of contract, will also be dealt with separately. I will briefly outline the more important of these recommendations:

Reviewing insured's complaintsInsurers and industry associations should be encouraged to develop more effective procedures for reviewing complaints made by insureds and to investigate the possibility of introducing an industry-based system of review, such as those developed in the United Kingdom, recommendation 66;
Insured's priorityIn the case of an insurer who becomes insolvent, consideration should be given to whether insureds should be given priority over other unsecured creditors, recommendation 71;

Investment controlsThe Insurance Commissioner should have the power to require an insurer to reduce its level of investment in any category of investments where that level of investment puts at serious risk the insurer's ability to meet actual and potential claims under existing or future contracts, recommendation 72;
Guarantee schemeA guarantee scheme should be established providing protection up to 75 per cent of claims not exceeding $200,000 per property or $1m per liability claim, recommendation 75;

Role of Insurance CommissionersThe Life Insurance Commissioner and the Insurance Commissioner should have power to order an insurer not to appoint or replace a manager who has been found guilty of an offence against the Life Insurance Act 1945, the Insurance Act 1973 or any other law in respect of conduct relating to insurance or dishonest conduct, provided that the offence is one which, in the opinion of the relevant Commissioner, renders the person unfit to be a manager or director of an insurer, recommendation 74;

Consideration should be given to empowering either the Life Insurance Commissioner or the Trade Practices Commission to enforce legislation prescribing the manner in which life insurance policies should be replaced and information concerning their replacement provided to the insured, recommendation 14;

DiscriminationPending an overall review of discrimination in areas of Commonwealth responsibility, the Human Rights Commission should have jurisdiction to receive and investigate complaints in respect of discrimination in insurance on the grounds of sex or marital status, physical or mental handicap, recommendation 77. This recommendation will be further considered in the course of the Government's review of human rights and anti-discrimination law and machinery.
Jurisdictional issues

The draft Bill attached to the Law Reform Commission's report does not contain any provision relating to jurisdiction. However, the Commission recommended that State and Territory courts should continue to exercise original jurisdiction to determine cases concerning the rights and duties of parties to a contract of insurance. The Government has accepted this recom- mendation.

The Law Reform Commission made no recommendation regarding appellate jurisdiction. The Government has decided that, due to the fact that the Bill does not create new causes of action but will modify rights and liabilities under the general law of contract as applied to some contracts of insurance, appellate jurisdiction will vest in State Supreme Courts. Appeals from Territory Supreme Courts will be to the Federal Court consistently with appeals in other matters.
Financial impact statement

The Bill is concerned with the law applicable to terms and conditions of contract and will be self-regulating. It will not provide for any additional powers and controls to be vested in any public official such as the Insurance Commissioner. The Bill will therefore have no impact on Government revenues.
I commend the Insurance Contracts Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Telecommunications (Interception) Amendment Bill 1983 is necessary to allow the Attorney-General to consider any request from the New South Wales Special Commissions of Inquiry for information relating to the Commission, or intended commission, of a serious criminal offence which has been obtained by the lawful interception of telecommunications. Honourable senators will be aware that three separate inquiries are being conducted in New South Wales, under the Special Commissions of Inquiry Act of New South Wales 1983 and constituted by Mr Justice Cross. In particular, he is required to report whether there is evidence warranting the prosecution of any person for any offence arising out of the matters referred for inquiry.

The Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979, which empowers a judge to approve telephone interception by the Australian Federal Police where relevant to a narcotics investigation, places stringent restrictions on the communication of information so obtained. Where information relates, or appears to relate, to the Commission, or intended commission, of an offence against the law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory, being an offence punishable by imprisonment for life or for a period of not less than three years, the Commissioner of the Australien Federal Police may communicate it to a member of the Australian Federal Police for the purposes of investigations into the offence, or to an officer of the police force of a State or Territory, as the case may be. The Act also provides that such information may be given in evidence in specified prosecutions and certain proceedings under the Customs Act 1901. The Act does not, therefore, authorise the communication of information obtained by an intercept to Mr Justice Cross, either by the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police or by an officer of the New South Wales Police Force to whom any such information had been communicated.

The Government is of the view that, in circumstances such as these, the public interest in proper law enforcement and co-operation with the States in law enforcement matters outweighs the concerns of privacy involved in the enlargement of the circumstances in which such information can be communicated, but that proper safeguards must be observed. It therefore proposes this amendment to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 to allow the Attorney-General in certain circumstances to communicate information obtained by the lawful interception of telecommunications to the Cross Inquiry. First, there must be a request for specific information. The Attorney-General must then consider, if any relevant information exists, whether it is relevant to the purposes of the inquiry, and whether it relates, or appears to relate, to the commission or intended commission of an offence against the law of the Commonwealth, a State or Territory punishable by imprisonment for life or for a period of at least three years.

If these requirements are satisfied, and if the Attorney-General is satisfied that it is appropriate to do so, he may then communicate the information to Mr Justice Cross. The Attorney-General may, when communicating any such information , impose conditions as to the use that may be made of it. It is envisaged that conditions would generally relate to preserving the confidentiality of the information for reasons such as the protection of current Australian Federal Police investigations. Finally, the Government thinks it proper that whenever the Attorney-General communicates information to an inquiry, he should, subject to the need to preserve the confidentiality of the information and the need to avoid prejudice to reputations, report to Parliament that he has done so, and advise Parliament of any conditions imposed by him on the use of the information . I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LIVE-STOCK SLAUGHTER (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) VALIDATION BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to enact legislation to validate the payment and collection of amounts under the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Act 1979 and the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Collection Act 1979.

The Charge Act was amended by Part VXII of the Export Control (Miscellaneous Amendments) Act 1982 with effect from 1 January 1983. The title of the first Act and the definition of 'abattoir' in section 4 of that Act were amended to reflect the repeal of the Exports (Meat) Regulations by the Export Control ( General) Regulations made under the Export Control Act 1982 also with effect from 1 January 1983.

The new definition of an abattoir in the Charge Act requires that premises used for the carrying on of operations in connection with the slaughter and dressing of animals from which meat intended for export is obtained be prescribed. In the event such premises were not prescribed. Fees within the maximum rates of charge set under section 6 of the Charge Act and prescribed by regulation have continued to be collected since 1 January 1983 notwithstanding the failure to prescribe premises. Those maximums and the operative rates of charge prescribed in regulation 3 of the charge regulations were increased in the context of the Budget with effect from 1 October 1983.

The charge regulations have been amended to prescribe premises that are registered premises within the meaning of the Export Control Act 1982 for the purposes of the definition of 'abattoir' in section 4 of the Charge Act. The Bill will overcome a technical deficiency in the legislation which has become apparent. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kilgariff) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The major purpose of the Bill is to amend the Insurance Act 1973 to strengthen the minimum financial standards to be observed by insurance companies authorised under the Act and thereby contribute to improving the financial position of the industry. It will also seek to effect certain other improvements in the existing system of supervision of those companies. This Bill represents, in the main, a consolidation of the Insurance Amendment Bill 1982, introduced into Parliament on 29 April 1982, and amendments to that Bill which were introduced into Parliament on 9 December 1982. I think it will be appreciated by all concerned with the industry that the amendments proposed in this Bill are both urgent and necessary and I would not dispute with those who might argue that a strengthening of the supervisory arrangements is long overdue. In very large part the provisions of the Bill are of a bipartisan nature and they are clearly in the interests of industry stability and the insuring public. They have been strongly supported by successive insurance commissioners and have the support of insurance industry organisations representing general insurance companies.

The main strengthening of the Act will arise from the provisions in the Bill concerned with increasing the minimum paid up capital and solvency requirements to be met by general insurance companies. These increases will be subject to appropriate phasing-in arrangements as provided for in Part III of the Bill. The Bill also contains amendments to improve the existing supervisory machinery. Some of the more important changes within this latter category are concerned with increasing various monetary amounts in the Act, including financial penalties, to bring them into line with present day conditions; provision for improved requirements relating to accounts; more comprehensive quarterly returns ; and measures to facilitate the revocation of authorisation under the Act where a company is withdrawing from the industry. In view of the Government's decision to retain the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation the provisions concerning the sale of the Corporation that were incorporated in the 1982 Bill, introduced by the previous Government, are no longer necessary and have been omitted from the current Bill. The Government has carefully considered the provisions of paragraph 15 (1) (d) of the 1982 Bill which would limit the extent to which premiums held by insurance intermediaries would be treated as assets of an insurer for solvency purposes.

Following decisions taken by the Government and announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 17 October 1983 to introduce legislation to regulate insurance brokers and agents, the Government has decided not to proceed in this Insurance Amendment Bill with the provisions reflected in paragraph 15 (1) (d) of the 1982 Bill. I should add, however, that it is the Government's intention to seek to incorporate provisions dealing with the practice of extended credit in the proposed legislation for regulation of insurance brokers and agents. It is the Government's intention that that legislation be introduced later this year and that it will lie on the table until the Autumn sittings 1984 to afford interested parties an opportunity to comment on the legislation. I would also like to draw to the attention of the Senate the prospect of further amendments to the Insurance Act, which, for certain reasons, have not been incorporated in this Insurance Amendment Bill.

Work has been continuing on the formulation of possible proposals to amend the Insurance Act 1973 in relation to the activities of mortgage insurers. The issues involved are complex and likely to take some time to resolve. Accordingly the Government has decided not to delay introduction of the amendments contained in this Bill until those issues are resolved. The Government is aware of, and shares the concerns resulting from, the failure of Bishopsgate Insurance Australia Limited. It is also conscious of the proposals that have emerged from various quarters for amendments to the Insurance Act and improvements in the supervisory arrangements with a view to minimising the risk of future occurrences of this type. In considering such proposals it is important to appreciate that the primary purpose of the Act is the establishment of a system for the prudential oversight of authorised insurance companies with a view to ensuring that the industry operates on a sound financial basis and is one in which the public can have confidence. The system requires compliance with certain minimum standards, and is directed at ensuring a company's ability to meet its liabilities. However, no matter how well devised any system might be it cannot wholly prevent fraudulent practices, although the Insurance Act and other areas of legislation dealing with business standards and practices, such as the companies code, should of course seek to minimise as far as is practicable, the opportunities for fraud. The circumstances surrounding the failure of Bishopsgate are being closely studied by the Government. This examination is taking into account the efficacy of possible new measures, their practicability in administration and associated costs and bearing in mind the need to balance the community benefits deriving from any new legislation with the interests of maintaining an efficient industry. It will be our intention to consult with the States, industry and other interested groups in the near future on this and other insurance matters. Following those processes it would be our intention to bring forward appropriate amendments at the earliest opportunity. My comments dealing with processes following on the Bishopsgate collapse in no way detract from the urgency of the amendments now proposed in this Bill. Indeed, recent developments in the industry point to the need to strengthen the provisions of the Act. These amendments do that and I commend the Insurance Amendment Bill to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The main purpose of the Bill is to amend the Life Insurance Act 1945 to strengthen and improve the existing supervisory machinery of the Act and to overcome certain difficulties experienced by the Life Insurance Commissioner with its administration. The more significant provisions of the Bill are those which would amend the Act to allow for the imposition, by either the Treasurer or the Commissioner of conditions on registration, and to empower the Commissioner to exercise specified controls over certain forms of investments made by life offices. The Act currently does not provide scope for the Commissioner to register a company subject to conditions. It does however, contain a number of provisions relating to investigations of life companies and empowers the Commissioner to issue such directions to a company in respect of its life insurance business as he thinks necessary in the light of an investigation. In effect this is a power to impose conditions on the continued registration of a company which has been the subject of an investigation. The processes concerned with undertaking an investigation can be very time consuming and in some circumstances it may not be in the best interests of policyholders to defer action pending the outcome of an investigation. To overcome this problem the amendments will allow for conditions to be imposed, either at the time of initial registration of a company, or on a previously registered life company without prior resort to formal investigation procedures. Comparable provisions are contained in the Insurance Act 1973. The conditions to be imposed will be subject to appropriate appeals provisions and must be consistent with the Act's basic thrust of supervising life offices with a view to ensuring their ability to discharge their liablities to policyholders. The amendments relating to control over investments will empower the Commissioner to exercise control over certain forms of investments made by life offices in related companies and in trust schemes. In addition, there will be a requirement for the provision of data on such investment activities to facilitate the process of supervision. In developing these controls, the Government has sought to preserve a balance between allowing companies adequate freedom in their investment decision-making and in maintaining industry stability in the interests of the insuring public.

The controls envisaged in the Bill involve some changes to certain unproclaimed amendments to section 39 of the Act contained in the Life Insurance Amendment Act 1977 introduced by the former Government. The amendments take account of earlier problems raised by the industry and they do not envisage any restrictions on investment in subsidiaries and in other life companies. However, restrictions on investments in parent or holding companies and investments in companies with the same parent or holding company are considered essential by the consumer for the protection of policyholders. The restrictions on investments in trust schemes, without the prior approval of the Commissioner, to 5 per cent of the assets of a statutory fund of a life company represents his concern that life offices should avoid situations where a significant part of a company's assets are given to some other institution to manage or invest.

In addition to the important changes I have described, the Bill will provide for the inclusion of a minimum paid-up capital requirement of $2m in respect of companies seeking registration under the Act. The purpose of this amendment is to give legislative backing to a requirement now set by the Life Insurance Commissioner under his registration guidelines. It is relevant that a legislative requirement of this nature is contained in the insurance Act 1973. The Bill will also effect a number of administrative changes to the Life Insurance Act including a provision to extend the effective period for furnishing of the Commissioner's annual report to Parliament from three months to five months. Both the present Commissioner and his predecessor have found the current period to be unrealistic and the longer period will allow more reasonable time for the preparation of relevant statistical material. Other administrative changes are concerned with improving the Commissioner's access to the information and documents needed in carrying out his supervisory responsibilities and with including provisions designed to encourage people wishing to carry out the functions of an actuary under the Act to seek qualification through the Institute of Actuaries of Australia rather than an overseas body.

Finally, the opportunity has been taken to seek inclusion in the Act of rights of appeal against various discretionary actions and decisions available to the Commissioner under the Act; changes to the appeals mechanism to bring it into line with other Commonwealth legislation and to effect a number of formal amendments to take account of current legislative drafting practice. Taken together, the thrust of the proposed changes is to overcome difficulties faced by the Commissioner in carrying out his task of prudential supervision of the life insurance industry.

I would also like to take this opportunity to foreshadow the possible introduction next year of further amendments to the Life Insurance Act. The Government has under consideration a number of other suggestions by the Commissioner for administrative improvements to the Act which have not been sufficiently developed for inclusion in this Bill. In addition, a working group, comprising officials and representatives of the life insurance industry, has recently completed a comprehensive review of the Act. It is expected that the examination of the recommendations of this working group and the Commissioner's further proposals will form the basis for a further Bill which it is intended be put before the Parliament at the earliest opportunity. We will also be considering whether any changes to the Insurance Act developed in the light of the failure of Bishopsgate Insurance Australia Limited might also be reflected in the Life Insurance Act. I commend the Life Insurance Amendment Bill 1983 to honourable senators.

Clause 23 (Persons entitled to enrolment and to vote).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — When the debate concluded yesterday I was raising the issue presented by sub-clause (6) (a), which states-

SPEECH.PARA: by reason of being of unsound mind, is incapable of understanding the nature and significance of enrolment and voting;

We may well here have perpetrated criteria in relation to one group of citizens that are different from those applying to other groups. It is not terribly difficult to suggest that when the wording in the original Act simply read 'of unsound mind' the level of understanding of mental illness was such as to lead to the lumping together of all such categories under that term. I believe that we have come a long way in the last 60 or 70 years, but here we may be perpetrating something of that understanding. Later on in the legislation we actually read the questions that are put to a person who appears at a polling booth. Essentially, the test that is put to an elector in the polling booth is: 'What is your name? Where do you live? Have you voted before in this election?'. I believe that test does not go anywhere near the test that is suggested here- that a person be capable of understanding the nature and significance of enrolment and voting. We never ask a person who turns up at a polling booth whether he or she understands the nature and significance of the action being undertaken. What we may very well be doing here is continuing to impose a more stringent test. Presumably that test will be applied to people in institutions. That is the crux of the point that I am making. My worry is that we will single out a group of people, that group which is in mental institutions or in hospitals for a similar reason, and apply to it a test of quite a significant nature, yet not at the same time apply a similar test to ordinary citizens who appear at a polling booth.

I admit that I am unable to suggest ways around it but I believe that the matter is still worthy of study. I will be interested in the Government's response concerning whether it could look again at the matter so that, at some time in the future, we may be able to go beyond what we have here- which is an advance on the old legislation-to language that will bring us closer to a situation in which the two groups of people concerned, those who are in mental institutions and those who are outside of them, will not be subjected to significantly different tests in relationship to their rights as citizens in casting a vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the comments made by Senator Macklin, may I simply indicate that the expression used in sub-clause 6 (a)-'by reason of being of unsound mind, is incapable of understanding the nature and significance of enrolment and voting'-is one which finds its way into the measure as a result of a number of legal opinions and interpretations given over the years as to the proper meaning of the simple expression 'unsound mind' which appeared in the former Act. The real substances of the clause is in the gloss, namely, the reference to being incapable of understanding the nature and significance of enrolment and voting. It may be that the drafting could have proceeded in such a way as to use just that language, without reference to the phrase which I take it Senator Macklin finds unattractive, but one really needs both legs of the double in order to have a whole legal concept. The best advice of the draftsmen is that, taking into account the way in which this phrase has been interpreted over the years, in such case law as there has been, this compendious expression is the best available to communicate, in a way which makes it clear that it is not intended to be offensive, the concept that needs to be communicated in legislation. So while we take to heart what Senator Macklin is saying about the importance of linguistic description in these respects, we do not think that in this context we can do any better. We will try harder next time.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.

''; or (ea) in a case in which there is no Subdivision for enrolment for which the person can apply in pursuance of paragraph (c), (d) or (e)-the Subdivision with which the person has the closest connection,''.

These amendments arise from the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. This legislation attempts for the first time to come to grips with the issue of the itinerant voter. I think that again this represents a significant reform because basically for the first time we have attempted to come to grips with the fact that Australia has a very large number of people who are itinerants and who have been deprived of the right to have their names placed on the electoral roll. I congratulate the Government for picking up this anomaly. Proposed new section 39C (1) (c), (d) and (e) set out the subdivisions in which such persons will enroll. However, some genuine itinerants may still not come within the scope of this provision. I refer to a person who was not born in Australia and who has never had an entitlement to enrol in as much as he does not have a residential qualification or a next of kin. I think that there would be a significant number of people in Australia such as Vietnamese who do not have a next of kin. The purpose of my third amendment is to ensure that people who do not fall within the categories listed in the legislation can apply to enroll in the subdivision with which they have the closest connection. I have designed my amendment in that way so that we do not, for example, get a situation in which 500 university students decide to enrol in a particular electorate. They would not be able to do so under paragraphs (c), (d) or (e). I believe the situation would be left open for abuse if we eliminated paragraphs ( c), (d) or (e). I imagine that only a small number of people will not satisfy the criteria laid down in th elegislation. However, I think they are entitled to be on the roll. I believe that my third amendment would prevent any significant abuse by people moving in and out of the electorate for certain purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Page 58, clause 27, proposed new sub-section 41A (1), lines 11 to 14, leave out the proposed sub-section, insert the following sub-section:
'' '(1) Any person who- (a) is 17 years of age;
(b) if he were 18 years of age would be entitled to have his name placed on the Roll for a Sub-division in which an election is to be held; and

(c) will attain the age of 18 years after the time specified in sub-section 43 (4) for the cessation of alterations to the Rolls and prior to the date of the election, may send or deliver a claim to have his name placed on the Roll for that Sub-division to any Divisional Returning Officer.'.''.

Honourable senators will be aware that the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform addressed this problem briefly on page 110 of its report. It recommended that a system of provisional enrolment be introduced. The Opposition accepts completely the desirability of people who are of an appropriate age and who wish to vote being able to vote. If certain people turn 18 years of age and qualify to vote during the run up to an election, the Opposition has no objection at all to their being able to enrol and to vote. This amendment merely seeks to institute this arrangement by a slightly different process. It seeks to enable certain 17 year olds to enrol. We think the way to do that is the way set out in the amendment which is to provide that those who are going to turn 18 before polling day but after the date of the close of the rolls should be able to make provisional enrolment beforehand.

TALK.START.PARA: —How will they know?

—The rolls will be required to be left open for a certain amount of time after the election has been announced. That is my understanding of the legislation. During that time we think it is entirely appropriate that those who are 17 but almost 18 years of age should be able to make provisional registration so that they will be able to vote in that election. We see no merit in the opening up of rolls for the general provisional registration of a number of 17 year olds. We think it can be done. Provided that the rolls are open for a period, those 17-year olds who are almost 18 will be able to enrol under the provisions which we have now set out. We have provided that any person who is 17 , who if 18 would be able to have his name placed on the roll, and who will attain the age of 18 years after the time specified in section 43 (4) of the Principal Act for the cessation of alteration to the rolls, may send or deliver a claim.
—I suppose you have a mind that someone who will be 18 in six or eight months may change his address and the records may be therefore fairly well out of date.

—Because many young people are fairly itinerate, that is correct. We understand what the Government is seeking to achieve. We believe that this amendment will achieve it. We believe, because of the interest which was shown before the last election, that the compaction of times, which led to the unfortunate early closing of the rolls then, should not be able to disenfranchise people. We commend this amendment as achieving what we think the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform was seeking to do, but it does not open up the rolls to general provisional registration. We really cannot see that a case can be made out for recommending that as a superior course of action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Government will not support this amendment. I can understand what is troubling Senator Peter Baume, because I heard the shadow Minister of State, Mr Steele Hall, speak at more length on this problem. I must say that he appeared to be a little more paranoid about the question than does Senator Peter Baume. To encapsulate the Liberal Party amendment, I point out that its acceptance would mean that people who were 17, but were to turn 18 before an election day, would have something like a week to get on the roll. Under the current proposal, the moment they turn 17 they can apply to be on the roll. They would then be put on the roll and that roll would be printed. But they will not appear on the certified roll unless they have attained 18 on the election day.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems to which Mr Steele Hall alluded was that people already on the roll would therefore claim a vote even though they had not turned 18. But they will not appear on the certified roll. I think that is an important point. Why put them on the roll at all? Why not just hold their cards at the Australian Electoral Office? I think Senator Peter Baume answered that in effect when he said that people move. It is best to put them on the roll, then they have to change their address when they move. My main reason for opposing the Liberal amendment is that there will be a fair bit of pressure on the staff in electoral offices in the five working days before the roll is closed. The roll is closed seven days after the issue of the writs, but that is really five working days. Many other people will rush in to change their address because they have moved. This will put an additional work load on the staff in that period, which I regard as unnecessary. We are living in the age of computerisation where it is very simple to print a roll which will indicate when persons will turn 18 and when they will officially come on the roll. I think that is a much more civilised way of doing it. I oppose the amendment moved by Senator Peter Baume.

SPEECH.PARA: (16) Page 73, clause 42, at the end of proposed section 58N add the following sub-section:

'' '(3) Where a political party is de-registered under sub-section (1), that party, or a party that has a name that so nearly resembles the name of the de- registered party that it is likely to be confused with or mistaken for that name , is ineligible for registration under this Part until after the general election next following the re-registration.''.

The problem that arises here is one in relation to registration and deregistration of a political party. If one were to look at proposed new section 58N of the Bill, one would find voluntary deregistration provisions to cover a political party which has been registered then seeks to deregister on a voluntary basis. Proposed new 58P contains compulsory provisions in relation to deregistration which would come about, within a period of four years a party has not endorsed one candidate at an election. If one were to look at those two clauses, one would see that a conflict could arise.

The scenario could be that a political party-I will take a name which might be useful in the electorate-has registered the name 'Social Democrats' because a party overseas has done rather well under that name. If this party had not in fact endorsed any candidate and did not intend to endorse candidates and was running out of time, presumably, if it were smart, it would simply voluntarily deregister and within the same day register again under the same name. Providing it could fulfil all of the criteria, it would be able to do that. I suggest that would effectively frustrate the compulsory provisions outlined in proposed new section 58P. The amendment that I have moved will simply reiterate in a proposed new section 58N (3) what appears in proposed new section 58P (2), so the provisions there remain identical.

If one were to look at proposed new section 58P (2) one would find that it states that where a political party is deregistered, a party which has that name or one which nearly resembles that name and it is likely to cause confusion, that party cannot reregister until after the general election next following the deregistration. I think that that would then put voluntary deregistration on a par with compulsory deregistration and will mean that an Act will not be passed the provisions of which could easily be subverted and got around. I think it is important that we do not put Bills through this Parliament whose provisions can be so easily manipulated, because I think they bring the legislative process into disrepute. I have therefore moved the amendment circulated in my name which would bring the voluntary deregistration and the compulsory deregistration clauses together so that they would operate in unison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the problem raised by Senator Harradine is important. As I understand it, Senator Harradine will be caught by proposed paragraph 58P if, in fact, he does not stand a candidate. If he does not stand a candidate for the Damn All Party, which he says he will register, within the period of four years immediately following its registration, he will be compulsorily deregistered and will not be able to re-register that very interesting party's name until after the next general election. He will be caught up, not by my amendment, but by the Act itself. All I am suggesting is that where a party wishes to dissolve and get rid of its name, so that that name is released back into the general field so somebody else can use it-there are strict provisions to avoid confusion and so on, as there should be-that party ought not to be able to use that quite legitimate deregistration process to subvert the compulsory process of people getting hold of names and tying them up for ever more so that nobody else can use them. If one looks back over the history of politics in Australia one discovers some very interesting elements that may have arisen in relation to the Australian Labor Party, for example, in Victoria in the 1950s and the ownership of the name there. It seems to me that we need both the voluntary and the compulsory elements, but they ought to be compatible and one ought not to be able to subvert the other.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (17) Page 81, clause 42, lines 37 and 38, leave out proposed paragraph 58Z (4) (c), insert the following paragraph:
'(c) the Commission is satisfied, after making such enquiries as it thinks appropriate of the registered officer of that party or otherwise, that the candidate is so endorsed.'.
(18) Page 81, clause 42, at the end of proposed section 58Z add the following sub-section:

'(6) A reference in sub-section (4) to the registered officer of a political party shall be read as including a reference to any person nominated by the registered officer of that party to be a deputy registered officer of that party for the purposes of that sub-section by notice in writing, specifying the name and address of the person and signed by the registered officer, lodged with the Commission, not being a nomination that has been cancelled by notice in writing, signed by the registered officer, lodged with the Commission.'.

Amendment No. (17) relates to the problem concerning the registered officer. If one looks at the Act, one sees that a registered party has a registered officer. Under the Act this person becomes a very previous commodity. From what I can understand, there seems to be only one registered officer in the whole of the country. I think that person should not be allowed out of doors, because if anything happens to that person in the run-up to an election there will be an enormous problem. The reason is that if the registered officer changes and one cannot get the signature of the person who is currently registered one has to go through a series of technical details and one has to do so within a period of seven days and in writing. I believe those technicalities need to remain in the Act. The reason for that is fairly obvious. If there is a problem within a political party we do not want somebody waltzing in off the street and suggesting that he is now the registered officer of that political party. There has to be a mechanism for due process in the changeover from one registered officer to another.

The crucial problem that I see arising, and it is one which could afflict any political party at any time, could occur during the period when an election has been called and we are getting our candidates. This registered officer has to sign the candidates' forms or the electoral commissioner has to satisfy himself by way of discussions with the registered officer that the candidate who is purporting to be a Liberal, Labor or Democratic candidate is indeed such a candidate. My worry really concerns emergency situations such as death, illness or where, for example, the officer has gone on an overseas trip and is unobtainable or not able to be contacted if a sudden election is called. In essence, this could really destroy a political party's chance of winning an election, because it could not have any candidates registered as candidates of that political party. It seems to me that to put so much of our democratic process into the hands of one person is slightly frightening.
My amendment No. (18), I think, will avoid the problem by the part which reads:

A reference . . . to the registered officer of a political party shall be read as including a reference to any person nominated by the registered officer of that party to be a deputy registered officer of that party for the purposes of that sub-section by notice in writing . . .

What I would imagine would occur in this context would be that the registered officer of the Australian Democrats in Australia would nominate in writing a deputy registered officer of the Party in each State. I think that would probably bring this part of the Act in line with a later section of the Act where the registration, for the purposes of funding, is at a State level. I looked, first of all, at going down that track with this amendment, of making there be registration in each State, but I think that would disadvantage new parties which had just got off the ground and which could not generate 500 members in more than one State; it would not be able to get over that magic number. I believe this may be the optimum way out of the problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the amendments are acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Opposition opposes clause 42 dealing, as it does, with the registration of political parties. We believe the registration of political parties is the keystone of the Government's intention to introduce public funding of political parties. It represents the first time that there has been an intrusion of government and public administration into political parties with the assistance of taxpayers' money. The Government says that registration is necessary because of public funding and the list system of voting. I understand that is a logical statement, but it is evident from polls which have been taken publicly that the Australian public does not want public funding of political parties. It is also apparent that anyone who possesses registration of a party will enjoy very clear advantages and that registration of itself will confer an asset upon a party. Quite clearly, if this Bill is passed, those parties wishing to have their candidates listed on the ballot paper will have to register. We understand that, but we think it is not correct. We think it is a retrograde step. I indicate that we oppose the clause in its entirety.

—I am indebted to Senator Baume for continuing the ritual in this respect. I think it was very much a ritualistic response at this point. The Government's contributions to this ritual have been made on so many occasions that it is hardly necessary to repeat them, except to say that the registration of political parties is not sought only in the context of public funding but also, of course, in the context of showing party affiliations on ballot papers, a worthwhile reform in its own right, quite apart from the public funding issue. Maybe Senator Baume can bring himself to contemplate supporting clause 42 on that basis if not otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — In view of the circumstances that have arisen today and in view of other aspects of this legislation, I now oppose the clause.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the clause, as amended, be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses 43 to 51-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 52 (Mode of nominations).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 87, clause 52, lines 15 and 16, leave out ''by adding at the end thereof the following sub-sections:'', insert ''-
(a) by omitting paragraph (b) and substituting the following new paragraphs:
'(b) be signed by not less than 100 persons entitled to vote at the election for which the candidate is nominated; or
(c) (i) be signed by not less than 6 persons entitled to vote at the election for which the candidate is nominated; and
(ii) be accompanied by a deposit, made by the person nominated or by some person on his behalf, of the sum of-
(A) in the case of a person nominated as a Senator-$500; or
(B) in the case of a person nominated as a Member of the House of Representatives-$250,
in legal tender or in a banker's cheque';
(b) by adding at the end thereof the following sub-sections:''.

This amendment refers to the amounts to be deposited for the nomination of a senator or a member of the House of Representatives. The rationale for raising the amounts of money is, of course, to attempt to stop frivolous candidates from running. However, I think it has been quite clearly said that it solves the problems of the frivolous poor but is not too effective against the frivolous rich. I disagree with the increasing of the amounts of money, as does my party. The situation really ought to be rectified in some other way. The proposal that I put forward presents an alternative for a person nominating for election: He may seek the signatures of not fewer than 100 persons who are entitled to vote at the election for which he has nominated as a candidate. Effectively, what that would do is to say that instead of a monetary nomination, it is a representation from the electorate that this person has support within the electorate. After all, that seems to me to be more appropriate than the payment of an amount of money. It means that the person could be expected to have some degree of support within the electorate. I take as an example a person from, say , the Unemployed Workers Union who may find that the amount of money upon which he is required to call here would be some months payment of the unemployment benefit, if he could accumulate that. If that person could gain the signatures of 100 people in the electorate, he ought also to be able to nominate.

I understand that if I move directly against the $500 and the $250 provision, it would be a useless activity. I am also aware of the discussions that took place in the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform about this matter. It was a very interesting debate. But I still press the point I raised at that time . That is that some alternative ought to be offered to those who are unable to find the increasing amounts of money that it seems will be imposed for nomination, and that we should eliminate once and for all that final element in the democratic process, dating back to the last century, of property being a prerequisite for parliamentary nomination and selection.

TALK.START.PARA: —More in sorrow than in anger, I have to say that the Government will oppose this gambit by the Australian Democrats which, for all its good intentions, would drive a coach and horses through the object of this provision, which is to keep to manageable proportions the ballot papers with which people have to contend by excluding, so far as it is possible to do so, non-serious candidates who do not have a measure of support. The way in which that measure of support is tested at present is by putting a financial disincentive on those who cannot command at the polls themselves a significant measure of support-4 per cent. What Senator Macklin's amendment would do is to remove that completely. It would entitle anyone who could raise 100 signatures to get on the ballot paper without any subsequent deterrent and run in the event even though the person received no support at all in the poll itself, perhaps not even from his 100 signatories. It has to be acknowledged, as we realise at petition time every day of the week, that getting 100 signatures is not one of the world's more difficult exercises, particularly when the claim that could well be made by someone seeking such signatures is not a commitment of support for him or his ideas but simply a commitment of support which would allow him to get on to the ballot paper. There are enough fuzzy- minded populists around the community to support someone in that aspiration without any difficulty.
—How about people of high principle?

—Indeed, and enough people of high principle-but with insufficient regard to the real world that they inhabit with those high principles to again make it possible for those 100 signatures to be so readily obtained that it would quite undermine the policy of this provision, which has had bipartisan support. For those reasons, we reject the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not support the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (19) Page 87, clause 52, line 19, insert ''or'' after ''enrolled;''.
(20) Page 87, clause 52, line 22, leave out ''enrolled; or'', insert ''enrolled .''.
(21) Page 87, clause 52, lines 23 to 28, leave out proposed paragraph 71 (2) (c ).
The effect of these amendments would be to delete paragraph (c) of proposed new section 71 (2) of the Principal Act. Paragraph (c) states:

in a case where a candidate is or has been a married woman and paragraph (b) does not apply-the names referred to in paragraph (a) or those names with a maiden or married name of the candidate that does not appear on the Roll . . .

if we simply added the word 'or' after paragraph (a) and added that in with paragraph (b), there would be no reason to make any special provisions for married women other than those that are made for men. This is the last remnant of something that we are trying to do away with in another Bill. In order to avoid controversy, I shall not enter into that matter. But certainly with the proposed section here, it is probably an oversight on the part of the drafters that it should have been left in because, as I say, there is no reason for it. All eventualities are covered, inasmuch as a person is entitled to enrol under a name or given names and to stand under a name under which he is entitled to enroll. That simply covers every possibility. There is no need to make any special provisions for maiden name or otherwise.

In some States the changing of names is required to go through a process of law . I understand that is the case in Western Australia. But it is not the case in Queensland, for example, where one can change one's name not necessarily by deed poll but by dint of practice and custom, and there are no laws governing those names. So the name basically in my State is the name by which one is known in use. So in that sense a woman who wishes to retain her original name, or her maiden name as it is normally called, or a man who upon marriage wishes to change his name, or a couple who wish to hyphenate their name-all of these are varieties of name changes that occur now on marriage fairly frequently-are also accommodated under paragraphs (a) and (b). So I move those amendments, which will in effect eliminate paragraph (c).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts the Australian Democrats' amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to get it clarified from the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) whether section 71 (2) (a) means, for example, that if my name happened to be Richard William Fortescue Beaufort Brian Harradine, I could retain my name 'Brian Harradine' on the roll. That is one of the Christian names. Two of those are, of course, fictitious. The sub-section states:

SPEECH.PARA: A nomination may name a candidate only by specifying the surname and the Christian or given name, or one or more of the Christian or given names, under which the candidate is enrolled.
I now see that that explains my problem. It is now cleared up.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Victoria-Attorney-General) (5.19)-Senator Harradine has answered his own question to everyone's satisfaction.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 53 to 54-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 55 (Requisites for nomination).

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Macklin' s amendments to this clause were consequential upon the defeat of material on sheet 11 and as such lapse with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to withdraw amendments Nos. 2 and 3 since they were consequential on an amendment which has been lost.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments-by leave-withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Chairman, I am opposed to sub-clause (c) and sub-clause (d) of clause 55. Obviously they increase the amount for nomination from $250 to $500 in the case of a Senate candidate and from $100 to $250 in the case of a House of Representatives candidate. I think some of the problem that has been envisaged will have been overcome by other provisions in this legislation. Though I am not in support of the list system of voting, I think the list system will substantially reduce the number of candidates nominating for the sake of nominating, or being nominated deliberately to create a problem on the ballot paper. It has been suggested that this measure is in some way to deal with the frivolous person. I suppose if I were to renominate in 1989 that might be taken by some to be frivolous. But I would not see it as frivolous and $500 is a fair whack so far as an individual is concerned.
—It won't be in 1989.

—I almost feel like sitting down after that comment. I am quite serious about this. It is a problem, particularly when a candidate is trying to gear up for an election and needs the $500 at that time. People tend to look at independents and want the money first, before they print material, for example, or at least if they do not want the money first they want some sort of understanding that it will come forward. I suppose the major political parties are not in that position. I simply mention the matter-although as Senator Gareth Evans has said, maybe $500 in 1989 will not be a problem-because I think it should be raised in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just make one contribution to the debate: Some people would see this as a large increase but equally one can look at it as a large decrease because when the Commonwealth Electoral Act was last amended, in 1965, the cost of nomination for the House of Representatives was three or four times average weekly earnings, whereas today it is about two-thirds of average weekly earnings. The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform was very conscious not to put it up too much, although I must say one of the National Party people did suggest $1,000 for the House of Representatives and $2,000 for the Senate. As well as putting the amount of the deposit up, though not to the same extent as inflation, we have reduced the amount of vote a candidate needs to 4 per cent, which will also help.
—That doesn't worry me; you can put it up to 20 per cent, if you want.

—It might not worry Senator Harradine, but four or five years is a long time in politics so you never know. He might be looking forward to the cheque coming back one day. We have lowered the required vote and have made it far more rational. The increase in the deposit is not massive if we put it in the historical perspective of when the Act was last altered.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 56 to 61-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 62.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Page 92, clause 62, proposed sub-paragraph 86 (1) (b) (i), lines 10 and 11, leave out ''(not being a hospital that is a polling place or a special hospital) ''.

Clause 62 seeks to cover the question of registration of general postal voters and the proposed section 86 (1) (b) (i) in the principal Act will seek to deprive certain people in certain hospitals of the capacity to cast a postal vote. The purpose of this Opposition amendment is to ensure that those people shall continue to have a capacity, if it is their wish, to apply for and to vote by way of postal vote.
