The words in the Bill at line 10 of page 29 are:
. . . not being a hospital that is a polling place or special hospital.

They are the words that would deprive people in those institutions from exercising the alternative route of applying for and obtaining a postal vote. The amendment would allow persons resident in a special hospital to retain their right to obtain a postal vote when it is their wish. It is a belief we hold that we should make it easier, that we should increase the options, for people to vote. I can see no reason for wanting to take away from people the right to exercise a postal vote in these circumstances.

I looked at the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and could not see-someone may correct me-a recommendation which would lead to this provision being put in the Bill. So it is not a provision which enjoyed the support of those senators and members who wrote the report of the Joint Select Committee. It is a simple straightforward amendment. Taking out those words would simply enable people who are patients in hospitals to have the right to apply for and exercise a postal vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to the Government the reasonableness of what we are seeking to do. To say that a person in a hospital or special hospital that is a mobile polling place can vote only at the time when the mobile polling place is functioning is to overlook the fact that many people in hospitals, for a variety of reasons, may not be able to do so at that particular time due to their frailty, their particular state of illness-
—Due to operation.

—Due to operation or due to a whole range of situations . It is not within the ordinary course of reason to suggest that the only way in such a place that a person can vote is if that person happens to be fully conscious and available at that point of time. In any case, why should not people in hospital over that period be able to have that freedom? They are the frail; they are the people who have bad days and good days, days on which they get particular treatment and feel absolutely bad. For example, they are the people who are receiving chemotherapy or who may be getting all sorts of treatments. Why should we force upon them the requirement to vote on that particular day instead of saying that they can have the freedom of a postal vote so that any time over the fortnight leading up to the election they can vote. In any case, why should a person be denied a postal vote if for all other reasons- that is, if they are suffering only from frailty or of ill health-they conform. The only reason is that they happen to be in hospital or a special hospital that is a mobile polling place. That seems to have no reason to it at all when I say that the other limitation on it is they have to be available and well enough to cast a vote when the mobile booth is working instead of having the freedom and opportunity to vote a fortnight before. I believe it would be reasonable for the Government to accept this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we have to go back to the reason why people apply for a vote by post. The reason is that they have no other method of voting. If we take Senator Peter Baume's point to its logical conclusion, everyone should be able to have a postal vote if they so desire. That seems to be the logical philosophical extension of what he said.
—And why not be logical?

—I would have thought that we declare an election day and people have to vote on that day. At the moment there are restrictions on the manner in which people are eligible to get a postal vote. The criterion is basically that one may not be able to vote on the day, for whatever reason. One may be interstate or ill. There may be maternity or religious reasons or whatever else. All those people who are in a prescribed hospital or nursing home that comes within the ambit of this Act have the opportunity to vote when the mobile polling booth comes around. I know that some people say that those people may be out playing cricket when the mobile polling booth comes around. In that case they can easily get to the normal polling booth.

SPEECH.PARA: To explain why mobile polling booths have been proposed, I have to go back to the basic reason: If there is one area of the electoral system in this country that can be rorted, it is the area of postal votes. I have previously expressed some examples of that and made the point in the Senate that that is probably the area that is most likely to affect an election result. I must say that not everyone in the Australian Labor Party may be happy with the particular clause that has been put in because traditionally the Liberal Party has been best at getting postal votes. In recent years in nearly every State, and notably in New South Wales, Western Australia and Victoria, the Labor Party has continued to pick up and has caught up with the Liberal Party. If one wants to draw a graph one will see that we are on the way up and unfortunately the old Liberal Party postal vote machine, based on the blue rinse set, is on its way down. So in many ways maybe the Labor Party machine would be happier to have the old system of an open go on postal votes. In reality we have been complaining for so long that the Government had to fix up the electoral system and remove any potential rorts out of the system. This legislation does it. It gives every person in those nursing homes or hospitals an opportunity to vote and vote fairly with an independent person there when the mobile booth comes around. What it does prevent is a matron or other person from using undue influence to force people who cannot resist that pressure to vote in the particular direction that the matron or whoever else wants and in the way that such a person brings that undue influence to bear.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Robert Ray or someone in the Government to answer the point made specifically by Senator Sir John Carrick that people will be prevented from voting because, being in hospital, they are more likely to be ill on particular days or certain events are likely to occur, someone suggested a person may be under an anaesthetic. Some people will not be able to vote on the day that the mobile polling booth comes. Without the capacity to have a postal vote they are going to be disenfranchised. I want Senator Sir John Carrick's point responded to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be. If Senator Baume looks to page 90 of the Bill, clause 61, proposed new section 85, sub- paragraph (cc) he will see that it is squarely directed to this situation. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the hours of polling on polling day-

TALK.START.PARA: —That permits them to apply, but if you want to know who can -

—It is the point the honourable senator is making. If someone is in a special hospital and for some reason unable to take advantage of the mobile polling booth facility at that hospital he or she is still entitled to apply for a postal vote. We cannot foresee all contingencies. That is the situation now.
—How does one know one will be unable?
—The people who do not know they are going to be unable will not be able to vote anyway. The honourable senator is trying to cope with the contingency of someone who has a car accident on the day.
—But they have good days and bad days. That is the very nature of people in nursing homes and these hospitals. They know that and you know that.
—I can understand the honourable senator's passionate defence of the system that he has been rorting so effectively in his Party.
—Mr Chairman, I ask that that remark be withdrawn.
—The Attorney-General will withdraw that remark as it is a reflection on Senator Sir John Carrick.
—I will withdraw the remark if Senator Sir John Carrick finds it offensive.
—Order! It must be withdrawn in any case as the Chair finds it offensive.

—I withdraw the remark but make the point that what this whole exercise is about in relation to mobile booths, and indeed the reduction in the facility of postal voting, is to void some of the misuse of the postal voting system that has operated in the past. There is no doubt that that occurred in a number of different situations, and there is no doubt that is needed to be addressed. As Senator Ray has quite precisely indicated, it is addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: The only point that is left for the Opposition benches is the argument about anomalies that would be created if particular individuals are deprived of a vote if they are in effect unable to use the mobile polling facility in the hospital in question. I have addressed the answer in the terms that clearly and starkly emerge from the Bill. There is a facility.

TALK.START.PARA: —How will they know days beforehand that on polling day they will be incapable?

—It may be that there will be some people in that category, but equally there are some people now who do not know that they will be the recipients of an accident or something and as such will be out of action on the day. That is a problem built into the postal voting system at the moment. I cannot honestly add anything more than that. It may be that there will be a handful of cases around the place that might satisfy Senator Sir John Carrick's objection, but basically it is perfectly likely to be the case that anyone who does wax and wane, and as such might be open to the description that he has given, would apply for a postal vote. I believe, on a proper application of the Act, that person would be entitled to get a postal vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret very much that Senator Ray has put forward the idea that we are trying to do this because it is spoiling some kind of vigorous activity of ours. I would not want to toss the ball back into the Australian Labor Party's court to remind it of its fervour, its undue activities, in chasing votes in many other ways; I think that is entirely out of court. Let us put Senator Ray back into his court. He is perfectly willing to accept that persons who are sick or incapacitated and are in their homes or, to put it another way, are not in hospitals or special hospitals, are entitled to postal votes and are entitled to receive whatever influence there may be from the community. According to the Government, influence is only naughty if it is in a hospital. This is the ultimate of the ridiculous, and I put it to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that that is so. If the test is that a disabled person, in his home or in his in-law' s home or elsewhere than in a hospital, is unable under this Act to be advised or to be influenced in any way by anyone-he can get a postal vote-what is wrong with the same circumstances happening in a hospital or a special hospital? That one remains unanswered.

SPEECH.PARA: The second situation is that by their very nature, persons, who are in hospitals as chronically ill or chronically infirm, will from day to day vary in their ability to be able to cast a vote. There is no way in which those people can predict ahead of time that they will be off colour. There is nothing in this Bill, I invite the Attorney-General to state if there is, to allow a person who is frail and has good days and bad days, to say: 'Because I cannot predict how well I feel, how competent I will be, when the mobile booths comes around, I am eligible to apply for a postal vote'. If that provision exists in the Bill I invite him to let me know as I am eager to know.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the attitude being taken by the Government is quite outrageous. It is clear from what Senator Ray said that the clause is introduced on the basis that the Government objected in the past to the provision of postal votes because its opponents were using the system more effectively. Now that the Government is doing very much better in that regard it is grinning like a cheshire cat. It is not a grin; it is a scowl. The Government still fears that it will not do well as it hopes, so it wants to take away from people what should be their normal right of a postal vote. Why should not people be entitled to that? The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) tried to bring in this red herring that clause 61 was going to cover the situation, but of course it does not. It enables people to apply for a postal vote when they are in a place other than a hospital which cares for a person who is seriously ill.
—Look at (cc).
—Yes. Clause 61 (b) (cc) states:

SPEECH.PARA: (cc) will- (i) throughout the hours of polling on polling day be a patient in a special hospital; and
(ii) be unable to have his vote taken at that hospital in accordance with section 113C;'';
How can people be sure that that will be so? How can they make a declaration that they will be unable to vote?

TALK.START.PARA: —If they have an operation booked, they are sure.

—Yes, but they cannot know whether, in the course of their stay in the hospital, they will he to have a further operation and be under sedation that day. They will not know whether they will be able to attend the booth. I put it to the Committee that it is outrageous not to allow people, perhaps frail people, who want to make a postal vote and take their time over it to do so. They should not be forced to totter down to a booth somewhere or even perhaps be taken out of the hospital for the day to go to a booth.
—Why take them out of the hospital? You are just misunderstanding the clause.
—I do not think that I am misunderstanding the clause.
—We are talking about a booth in the hospital. That is a precondition of the operation.
—But the person has to be capable.
—Yes, but if people are not capable of voting at a booth they could be capable of filling in the postal ballot before the event. They may fear that they may not be recovered by voting day.
—We are talking about mobile booths going from bed to bed. A person would not even have to totter 10 feet.

—I know about that, but I am saying that people may not be in a position on that day actually to lodge the vote. If they have a fear in regard to this, why should they not be able to put in the vote beforehand? It is not only a matter of what they are being denied by this proposed change. Many people , particularly old people, have a very serious concern about the possibility of their not being able to vote. This legislation only adds to the fears and worries of people in this situation. They are being refused the opportunity to exercise a normal democratic right. I suggest that the attitude of the Government in this is quite outrageous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Liberal amendment is a major health measure. It will have the effect of ensuring that everyone will have a good day- the day the postal vote arrives. That is the guts of the argument. Senator Sir John Carrick said that people have good or bad days. I concede that they have good or bad days, but there is nothing in life that would enable us to know whether they filled in their postal votes on a good or a bad day. I have been to plenty of nursing homes-occasionally I have even been beaten into them by the Liberal organiser-and upon looking around have found that 50 per cent of the people are ga-ga. If three days after the close of the poll one checks on who has in fact applied for postal votes and who the witnesses are, one finds that it is the same witness for all 40 of them. That witness is the Liberal organiser in the area. They have all voted; they all had a good day. Yet it is suggested that on polling day 20 out of 40 may not be having a good day. I must say that some of these Liberal organisers are very good for the people in nursing homes. On the day they visit, they all have a good day.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sir John Carrick rightly objected to what Senator Jack Evans said about postal votes. But I know people in Victoria-Mrs Stanley of East Malvern and Gladys Grant of Toorak-who go out and do 80 to 100 postal votes. They go right through the nursing homes. They are welcomed with open arms. Everyone else is barred. They go in and collect the application forms and arrive back two days later to help fill them out. We all know it goes on. The Opposition knows it goes on.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—People are not given the opportunity to cast their vote. They are in special care. They are in a position where undue influence can be brought to bear on them. That is why they are in those institutions to begin with. A mobile polling booth will go from bed to bed with independent electoral officers. Party scrutineers by all means may observe the proceedings. That is provided for in the Bill. In those circumstances, people can cast their vote. I suggest that it will be a lot easier, even on a bad day, to cast a vote through a mobile polling booth-a person will only have to give his name and address and fill out the ballot paper-than it would be to go through all the application forms and so forth for a postal vote. If we accept Senator Baume's amendment, the institutions that were previously doing it fairly will have a mobile booth and those which were conducting it in a crooked fashion will do it by postal votes.

— The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform looked at the proposal for mobile polling booths. The debate we are now having was actually rehearsed fairly extensively during the proceedings of that Committee in the preparation of its report. Indeed, the recommendation for the mobile polling booths came precisely from consideration of the problems which undoubtedly have arisen in nursing homes and other special hospitals. I do not want to make accusations of one kind or another, as I have no evidence that undue influence occurs in Commonwealth elections in hospitals and the like. I believe that such evidence is pretty hard to obtain. However, I do have evidence in relation to a Queensland state election. A booth is situated in a particular hospital, thus enabling one to find the figures as they are isolated in the statistics. The situation in that particular hospital is that only one party is allowed in by the matron. That particular hospital registers something in excess of 85 per cent of votes for one particular political party. Undoubtedly, it would be possible for that to occur. If that were on the application to get into the hospital, I suppose it would be possible to establish whether that was the case. But I do not think that anybody in the Senate would suggest that a percentage as high as that could arise from a situation that was dealt with fairly by all concerned with that election. I think everybody has to accept that there are problems in this area and that there have been problems in the past. In recommending the mobile polling booths, the Committee sought to give additional assistance to people in those hospitals; it did not seek to take anything away. If honourable senators look through the Bill and the Committee's report, they will see the care with which the mobile polling booth issue has been handled. It is designed positively to assist people in hospitals to cast a valid vote. I think that should be seen as a major advance. In the debate we are having now it looks as though that advance has been cast as something which is taking something away from the citizen. It is not. It is adding something quite significant. It is my hope in supporting that recommendation of the Committee and in supporting the current clause in the Bill that we will obtain more valid votes from those hospitals than we have in the past.
—What do you mean by valid votes?

—I mean formal votes. Certainly if one looks at the statistics one finds very many informal votes. Again, I cannot get evidence for Federal elections because statistics are not provided on a hospital basis. There may be some, but I do not know of any. I am going only on what happens in my own State, where we have very similar laws in relation to hospitals. The fact is that the hospital I mentioned earlier is able to provide statistics which show a very large number of informal votes. My hope is that this combination of mobile polling booths and the ability of parties to have scrutineers with those going around with them will assist in the fairness and effectiveness of the new procedures proposed in this Bill. I believe that we ought to give this a fair and reasonable chance and see what occurs. The Senate and the House of Representatives have kept in session the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform so that it can look at the results. I believe this will be one of the very areas that that Committee will be very interested in analysing after the next Federal election. It will be able to see precisely what has occurred and compare that with what occurred in previous elections. It can then make recommendations as to what changes ought to be made to the Act in the light of experience. I urge this chamber to support the clause in the Bill in the hope-I hope not misplaced-that we will be giving greater assistance to people in hospitals than has ever been given to them in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macklin, Senator Robert Ray and, I think, Senator Jack Evans have made some quite extraordinary assertions. Senator Macklin has suggested that whatever a vote of 85 per cent for one party is obtained it is prima facie evidence of some kind of wrongdoing. I can identify subdivisions of Sydney where the Australian Labor Party gets well over 85 per cent of the vote. Is anyone suggesting that that is prima facie evidence of any kind of wrongdoing? I can identify postal voting mechanisms in certain Aboriginal communities which return to the Labor Party votes well in excess of 90 per cent. Is anyone suggesting that that is prima facie evidence?
—Yes.
—Senator Macklin believes it is prima facie evidence of wrongdoing. That is an interesting proposition.
—Nobody in his right mind would vote for you lot.

—Senator Macklin is asserting something else. I just think that that is at least a testable proposition. I do not think it is easy to sustain. Secondly, one goes to the report of the Joint Select Committee and looks at the chapter on postal voting to see what it had to say about all the rorts that people are talking about. It now comes out that this is some kind of mechanism prompted by a background of a paranoid belief on the part of the Australian Labor Party. Where does that appear in the report of the Joint Select Committee? A chapter has been written on postal voting but I can find no reference to, no suggestion of, any of the rorts about which honourable senators are talking. Are they telling me that they sat down all winter, examined these matters, examined postal voting, and came up with a lot of suggestions; that they were so passionate about rorts but did not write a word about it in this report? I do not believe that is credible. There is some hidden agenda which is political, which they did not want to go into the report. They could not sustain it, could not make out a case that would wash with the public, so they did not put it in the report where it would be criticised. Instead, they bring it out now in the Parliament. We are going on what is stated in the report, which we believe expresses bipartisan views.

SPEECH.PARA: If one goes to page 109 of the report and looks at the way in which the mobile polling booths are to operate one sees that they will not necessarily go around on polling day at all, of course. They can go around on any of the five days preceding polling day, on polling day, or on a day subsequent if polling has been adjourned. If they go around on polling day and a person is unable then to use a booth such a person will not have available the other opportunity, that of obtaining a postal vote. It is predictible that there will be occasions when people will be unable on polling day to use the mobile booth. The obvious case is that of the person who might have some kind of surgical procedure. Senator Sir John Carrick mentioned chemotherapy, where a person knows that he or she is to have it and, for many, it will knock them out for a day or so. If such a person cannot vote then that person will be unable-unless he or she knows for certain in advance of that inability to vote-to obtain a postal vote. We are not objecting to the use of mobile polling booths; we have made no objection to them at all. We accept that they will represent an advance. However, we have asked that the extra option, that of casting a postal vote, if one should so desire, should be available to people. I cannot understand the reasoning put forward by Senator Macklin. It is deficient in logic and I wonder at the hidden agenda that people have in their minds when they make the assertions that they have made in this Committee debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address myself to the statements made by the Australian Democrats, who say that they welcome the provision of an additional facility for people in hospitals and special hospitals, but in fact there will be the loss of a facility, the loss of a postal vote. I put it to the Democrats that such a facility is available to all such people if they are in the same condition in their homes, with the benefit of their families around them. Nobody objects to their families or others then assisting them with their vote. The extraordinary argument that has been proposed-and I need some clarification on this-is that, somehow or other, Senator Macklin knows how people have voted when they have cast postal votes from institutions; that he believes it would be better to have a mobile polling booth. There is no way on God's earth that anyone could know how people who have used postal voting in hospitals and nursing homes have voted-no way of knowing that 85 per cent have voted one way or the other. In fact, the postal votes are secret, they are mixed up and they are not counted en bloc when they come from a hospital. I ask the Senate to reject any allegation that anyone here knows how a group of people in a particular institution have voted. That is completely wrong ; it cannot be so. The ballot papers of the people to whom Senator Macklin has referred to as voting federally by means of a postal vote have gone separately to the Electoral Office, have been opened separately, put into a ballot box and counted in that way; so no one could know these things. What we are saying is that we welcome the provision of the additional facility of a mobile polling booth but we believe that the postal vote should be maintained because, the very nature of registered or long term patients in hospitals or nursing homes is such that their state of well-being and health on a particular day is unpredictable. Therefore, they should have the facility of the postal vote to use when they are well, when they are not receiving treatment. After all, what is the very nature of the elderly? It is such that they go from illness to some kind of well-being. Think of the general geriatric who suffers from heart or other degenerative disease. Of course, such people will have good and bad days.
—And this duty concerns them greatly.

—Indeed, many of them take very seriously their right to vote. We will be creating a serious fear among them if we deny them the postal vote. The only reason anyone would take out of this Bill the right to render a postal vote would be a selfish, partisan, party reason; there can be no doubt about that. All logic suggests that if a frail person who, when well and in his or her own home can get a postal vote-nobody objects to that-the same facility should be provided to such a person if he or she is in a hospital or nursing home. Such people should have the right over a period of days to cast their votes when, in their judgment, they should, and not according to a random exercise governed by whether a mobile polling booth will turn up on a particular day I put it that there can be only one reason for rejecting an opportunity being given to render a postal vote-that somebody calculates that that will benefit the Australian Labor Party. That is a pretty poor reflection on one's intention in amending an electoral Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few brief remarks concerning clause 62. Senator Sir John Carrick has referred to mobile polling booths. I was in the Northern Territory last week and am not entirely happy about the way in which mobile polling booths are operating there. I will wait until the election is held to see what happens but there are serious doubts in my mind that some of the mobile polling booths that are to come by air will be at particular strips long enough for the mainly Aboriginal voters to come in and vote. In one electorate there are only three static polling booths. They are all , of course, in white communities. The remainder of the electorate will vote at mobile polling booths, which will be moved around by air. I hope that it works because I support the concept of mobile polling booths but perhaps I will have more to say about that next week.

SPEECH.PARA: We are dealing with the real world. I have over the years worked in election campaigns throughout New South Wales. For a period it was, of course, my job to do that for the Australian Labor Party. We know what happens in some nursing homes, not all of course. I have been denied access to nursing homes during a by -election campaign. At times we waited until the visiting hour and then went in, seeking Labor Party votes, as visitors. We have been told that the man from the Electoral Office has been around. It was, of course, the Liberal Party organiser . You cannot demand access to these private nursing homes. All of us have had this experience in the past. I believe that over the years the New South Wales Liberal Party bent the rules-it did not break them-as far as postal voting was concerned. Let me explain what it was able to do. It had a very good organisation and a lot of funds. The organisers would have a list of all the people in the electorate who had sought a postal vote last time, and the reason why. The next time the person would receive an envelope with inside it an application for a postal vote, all filled in.

That is where I reckon that the rules were bent and that it was a breach. There is some doubt about that. The reason for wanting the postal vote would be the same reason given by the person the last time. The form would be filled in in its entirety. All that was required was a signature from the voter. Of course, inside that envelope was the official envelope in which the form could be sent back to the returning officer. Inside also was a Liberal Party how to vote card which, of course, was posted from the regional office of the Liberal Party in North Sydney. People came to me and complained because this material had been sent to members of their family who had since died from the illness that caused them to apply for a postal vote in the first instance. I do not believe that postal voting was put into the Commonwealth Electoral Act for this purpose. I do not believe that any government intended that postal voting should be used in this fashion. I believe the Committee ought to agree with anything that can correct this situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make one brief point in answer to Senator Sir John Carrick. If he is as concerned as he says he is about the inability of the clause to which I previously referred to cope with someone who has good and bad days, he ought to be equally concerned with the present postal vote rules as they apply under section 85 (1) (c) of the existing Act which would equally preclude any such person from now applying for a postal vote. The requirement is that a person be seriously ill or infirm and by reason of such illness or infirmity be precluded from attending at any polling booth to which he would otherwise be able to resort. One has to be able, under the rules as they now stand, if they are to be properly applied and not bent, to satisfy the returning officer in question that by virtue of that particular serious illness or infirmity one will not be able to make it to the poll. That is not an appropriate way of describing someone who has good and bad days under the existing rules. So it might be thought to be a debating point. It is a debating point of some significance when one understands the extent to which Senator Sir John Carrick builds his whole defensive edifice on the notion of the continued application of a facility now legally enjoyed by such people. It does not exist.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) said that people such as the frail and the geriatric to whom I referred as having good and bad days could under this Bill apply for a postal vote. I would like the position to be made clear because I think the very large community affected by this provision would like to know the position. Will the Attorney tell me specifically how those people can get a postal vote under this new Bill? It is very important that they know that they can get a postal vote and that there are no doubts about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I reject the Attorney's statement that when I said 'good and bad days' I meant that on their good days these people were physically fully well. That is not what I meant at all. As I have said, I am talking about seriously ill people who may be under treatment for malignancies. These people may be fully conscious on some days and have chemotherapy on other days. I am talking about people receiving dialysis treatment. I am talking about the cardiac cases who are obviously seriously ill and on some days quite incapable of reacting. So let us put aside the statement made by the Attorney. The kind of people I am talking about are fully accepted as being entitled to a postal vote under the present Act. The Attorney has said quite clearly that provision will be made for those people under this Bill. Will he please spell out how people in hospital and nursing homes can, in the knowledge that they are frail or seriously ill and they have good and bad days, apply for a postal vote?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not unduly prolong this debate because it is now being steadily reduced to bathos. The main points have been made out. However, the short point can be made that if an application for a postal vote can be made under the present law by someone in the circumstances described in section 85 who anticipates that at the day of polling he will be unable to vote, equally that kind of reasoning is available in relation to the provision in proposed new section 85 (1) (cc). A person will be unable to have his vote taken. What I am saying is that if the sauce is there for the goose it is there for the gander. If one can construe the clause one way in the context of the exception to the mobile booth provision, equally, one can construe it that way in relation to the existing postal vote application provisions.
—Is that the advice from the Electoral Office to you now?

—I am not saying what the advice from the Electoral Office is. It may be a matter for argument as a matter of law which interpretation applies-the liberal one, which the honourable senator applies, or the illiberal one.
—You are stating adamantly that there is no argument.

—The advice I am receiving is that, if one can anticipate or predict with a reasonable degree of precision that it is likely to be a fact that one is going to be unable to vote when the booth comes around, one would satisfy the description of not being able to vote. In other words, the same kinds of criteria would apply as are presently applied in terms of infirm people applying for a postal vote. If someone knows he is going to be seriously ill within the meaning of the present provision he will be granted a postal vote even if he is not seriously ill at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think this debate is going to prove terribly productive if it is further prolonged. It is a matter of interpretation for construction. But the point that I have been making all along still holds; people in the kind of condition that Senator Sir John Carrick is referring to would be entitled to apply for a postal vote and to do so with about as much chance of success of getting it as they do, on my reading, under the existing law.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Senator Peter Baume's amendment) be omitted.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 63 (Duty of witness).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Page 95, paragraph 63 (d), proposed new paragraph 87 (3) (b), lines 14 to 17, leave out the paragraph.

If one were to look again at the chapter on postal voting in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, one would see that the change proposed in paragraph (b) of clause 63 is recommended because of what has been done in Victoria. No real argument has been advanced in favour of this change, so I would be grateful if, to start off the argument, we could hear from the Government why it is proposing this change which will limit very much the capacity of people to witness postal vote applications.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was waiting with interest to see why the shadow Minister, Senator Baume, would move only that amendment which appeared on the list of Liberal Party amendments. I thought his amendment might be more comprehensive.
—I do not understand.

—I would have thought the honourable senator would have had more objection to some other parts of clause 63, than to the actual part of the clause to which he objects, which is paragraph (b). The intention of clause 63 is to make it a little more difficult for people who try to garner postal votes and put pressure on others. I ask Senator Baume to note that at some other stage , we take out of the Commonwealth Electoral Act the old section which dealt with persuading and inducing people making postal votes-the Claytons section, the section one has when one does not want to have a section. We did this because it could never be enforced. In this proposed new section we are trying to make it a little more--
—The Joint Select Committee recommended that that be taken out.

—Yes, the Committee recomended that it be taken out. May I say as an aside, and Senator Sir John Carrick may correct me if he wants, that I admit that the attention given by the Committee to postal votes was probably not as satisfactory as it should have been. That chapter on that subject was written in haste. I draw the attention of Senator Baume to the comments I made when the report was tabled in the Senate. I mentioned that some chapters in particular had not been given enough attention and depth due to the pressures of time. I think that is a fault of the Committee. It was caused by time constraints. The honourable senator is correct to draw that fact to the attention of the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberal amendment does not seek to bar witnesses from going to a person's home. It does not seek to change that nor does it seek to charge the proposed new sub-section which calls for a written request in the case of the seriously ill or of those approaching maternity that a witness come to a person's house. The only part of clause 63 which the Liberal amendment seeks to change is paragraph (b). The effect of that paragraph is that those people who are not affected by illness or those who are not approaching maternity will actually have to go out and seek a witness rather than the witness seek them. That is the essence of the paragraph which the Liberal party seeks to delete. I think it should remain there. I think it should be incumbent on all people provided, firstly they are not infirm or, secondly, approaching maternity to go out and seek a witness. Paragraph (b) states that a person seeking a witness must do so at that witness's residence or normal place of business.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to us that there is no good case for this change to be written in to the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill. I agree with Senator Ray that we are restricting our objection to a very particular matter. Paragraph (b) of clause 63 in the Bill will make it improper for a person to witness the signature of an elector making an application for a postal vote at any place other than the ordinary residence or place of business of the witness. We see no reason why that restriction should be necessary. If Senator Macklin cannot vote at his local polling booth and decides he wants a postal vote and picks up a postal vote application and at the airport seeks to have someone witness that application, that person will not be permitted to witness it because the airport is not his ordinary residence. It is not his place of business.
—If he is at an airport he will find someone working at the airport.

—He might. I can see no reason why, if at the airport, Senator Macklin should not be able to ask me, for example, to witness his postal vote application. There is no impropriety to which the Government is trying to put a stop. We can see no logic whatsoever in that restriction. Senator Ray correctly said that we are not objecting to many of the principles in the clause . We cannot see why that restriction is either necessary or beneficial.
—Will not that restriction lead to people accidentally breaking the law? They will not do it correctly because they are not in the right place.

—That becomes a hazard. People may in fact inadvertently do this. We believe this paragraph in clause 63 could cause unnecessary inconvenience to people. They are able to make an oral application for a postal vote. They are unable to ask a neighbour in that neighbour's house to witness it , if they want to go next door and have it witnessed. The responsibility is in the hands of that person seeking the postal vote. It should be in their hands, but-
—He can go to the neighbour's house. The neighbour does the witnessing in the neighbour's house.
—It was a bad example, but it does not alter-
—That was half of your objection.

—No. It does not alter the main argument which I was putting . A person may be able to go to his neighbour's house, but I come back to the airport example. I can see no reason why this paragraph is necessary. Tearing it out will certainly not give rise to abuse. It is a small point which adds to the capacity of people to fill in their application forms incorrectly. Again I come back to Senator Ray's point that it is a very narrow compass which we are seeking to have looked at here. I hope it can be accepted by the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I foreshadow an amendment regarding this question. I draw attention to the amendment because in it I have tried to pick up what I thought was the problem which the Opposition was looking at. It simply eliminates from 63 (4) the words 'in writing'. Obviously the clause was designed to prevent the canvassing of postal votes, by people going around the electorate . I assumed the Opposition was objecting to the restriction in paragraph (b), because if one reads (3) (b) in junction with (4) I believe there are some restrictions. People who need their postal vote witnessed can go next door or to any other house and get the vote witnessed. They can go to where anybody works and get it witnessed there. If they cannot do that, because of incapacitation or serious illness or approaching maternity, they may under sub-clause (4) request somebody to come to their home and witness it for them. So that really covers every place where a person could possibly want a vote witnessed.

SPEECH.PARA: What I thought was restrictive was the fact that people have to make the request in writing. It seems to me to be very odd. Let us take the case of a mother who is living at home on her own. Her elder son normally does most of the work for her. She would have to ring up and say: 'Charles come over. I have some forms that I need witnessed so that I can lodge a postal vote'. It seems to me unduly restrictive to talk about the request being made in writing. A person could call out to a neighbour over the fence or through the window: 'Could you come over here?' That would be a request. But under the clause as it stands any request would have to be in writing. It seems to me that if we simply eliminated the words 'in writing' we would solve the problem which the Opposition is talking about. The restriction in (3) (b) would remain. I believe the restriction in (3) (b) is important because in that case the initiative is on the part of the person seeking a witness. The initiator has to go to where the witness is-say, that person's normal place of business. People picking up a postal ballot application form at a post office can get the form witnessed there . They can get it witnessed at the Australian Electoral Office. They can go to the local newsagency or chemist an get it done there. It seems to me that we are really putting the initiative back with the person who is seeking an application . I do not really believe (3) (b) is unduly restrictive, provided we can fix up the problem in (4).

TALK.START.PARA: —For a person who is incapacitated or seriously ill.

—Yes, that is right. It relates to a person who is incapacitated , seriously ill or approaching maternity. Incapacity is a broad possibility. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) might be able to clarify what ' incapacity' actually means. To me, it seems that 'incapacity' may very well cover the situation of an elderly woman who is fearful of leaving her home. Indeed, because of a problem she may not leave home except on very rare occasions. That seems to me to be a reasonable definition of 'incapacity'. I seek clarification on that before I continue my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Peter Baume, the shadow Minister, is listening, I am about to give him some interesting and unexpected news. Just to demonstrate that this whole debate is not necessarily preordained, I point out that we have been thinking about the arguments as they have been put and they seem to us to be reasonably compelling. Senator Macklin, in foreshadowing his proposition, advanced reasons for the need to delete the expression 'in writing'. The basic reason was the unenforceability of the provision in its operation if the writing requirement is kept in. It would be very difficult to ensure that it was observed in practice. We accept the force of his argument in that context. Equally, I think the argument has to be put, in relation to sub-clause (3) (b), that whatever the justification for this prohibition-we would suggest there is a justification for it as being incidentally designed to assist the policy of this provision, which is to move against canvassing-it will in practice be extremely difficult to enforce. A law which, for practical purposes, is unenforceable is really not one that we ought to sanction on the books. One might say the same of sub-clause (3) (a). The policy thrust behind (3) (a), a direct prohibition on visiting, may be such as to act as a disincentive. But in (3) (b) we are talking about what will be perceived as very technical restrictions. When one contemplates the fact that fines of $1,000 are attached to it I think the argument is reasonably well made by the Opposition, and we will take the risk of wrath and indignation in the party room and accept it on the run.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 95, clause 63 (d), proposed new sub-section 87 (4), line 23, leave out 'in writing'.

The amendment is simply an attempt to allow a person to make a request over the telephone, over the back fence or in some other way, rather than simply in writing. Insisting on a written application seems to me to be unduly restrictive .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my 17 years as a member of the Australian Labor Party in Victoria, and in campaigning, I have never known anyone to give written permission for a postal vote. I think the point which Senator Macklin made is right. This provision was only ever put in the legislation as the ultimate sanction if a really systematic attempt was made to canvass votes. The difficulty in putting that provision in this Act is that one cannot really go for the ultimate sanction when it applies to everyday affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 64 to 73-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 74 (Correction of errors).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Page 101, clause 74, proposed new section 96A, line 24, after ''error,'' insert ''other than an error (including an omission) by the elector,''.

This may be a fairly minor amendment, but we think it is worth submitting it to the Committee. There is no definition of a formal defect or a formal error. We do not need to argue for hours about a definition at the moment. It seems to us that we should require the applicant for a postal vote to fill in his or her part of the form correctly. But if there is an error on the part of the electoral officer that should not be suficient to disqualify a vote. I understand that there is some case law in Western Australia in which that may have been at issue. Very recently, I think a judge said that it could not be said that an error by an electoral officer would make all the votes invalid. Our amendment seeks to add the words 'other than an error including an omission by the elector'. We think the elector should fill in his or her part of the application correctly. But if an error has been made-we think this is probably what is meant by a formal error-by the electoral officer we think that should not have an effect adverse to the elector.

We think all that will require is that the elector fill in the central part of his or her application correctly. If the Government does not accept the amendment it has to worry about what is a formal error or what is a formal defect in the application of an elector. Might it mean that the application is not signed? Might it mean that a name has not been put in?

TALK.START.PARA: —Leaving out a proper subdivision?
—But there is no definition of what a formal defect or a formal error is. We think it not inappropriate to throw back on to the elector the task of filling in his or her part of the application--
—Including the subdivision.
—I will not argue about the subdivision.
—That is what you are arguing about because that is a classic example of a formal error made by the elector.

—I am sorry. If Senator Evans wants to define what is a formal defect or a formal error we will look at that, but at the moment it is totally undefined. It really is something which we cannot predict what it will mean in practice. I do not see how anybody can see what it will mean in practice . It simply has not been defined. We think that the amendment which we have proposed-it is a relatively minor amendment-at least makes it clear that we are trying to protect the elector against errors which might be made by the Electoral Office. We feel the elector should have that protection. In a sense we are trying to meet the Government part of the way along in what it is trying to achieve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government resists this amendment. It is not something either side ought to go to the wall over because it does not involve anything other than proper practice of the Australian Electoral Office which, I think, all of us can be satisfied will be carried out in a bona fide way.
—We are not questioning the bona fides.

—If Senator Baume is not questioning the bona fides and he is not worried about rorts or anything like that, it is the Government's suggestion that he can leave it to the sense and common practice of the Electoral Office to ensure that this operates as it is meant to operate without the need for the very restrictive amendment which the Opposition is now proposing. The concept of what is formal and what is substantial is well established as a matter of law in a variety of contexts. Should it ever come in issue that the validity of some contested vote will be decisive for the elections, it will ultimately fall to be resolved by the court if the vote has been allowed in as a result of an application said by the officer to involve merely the formal errors on the part of the voter. So there is a mechanism for ensuring, if it really mattered, that the correct criteria were being employed by the Electoral Office. The sorts of things that the Electoral Office has in mind as constituting formal errors on the part of the elector are a failure to put in the correct subdivision or putting in an accurate subdivision, a misspelling in the name of the person's street perhaps, the omission of a street number but in circumstances where there is no ambiguity about identification of the person in question. What would clearly be a substantive error and not merely a formal error would be the absence of a signature on the application. That simply would not be an application but with some errors in it; it would not be an application at all.

SPEECH.PARA: We can argue about things of this kind. We cannot anticipate every one of the kinds of errors, perhaps, of someone from the Middle East who is used to writing in Arabic and who has only, farily recently, acquired citizenship and become used to writing his or her name in ordinary letters. That person may, in fact, misspell his or her own name.

TALK.START.PARA: —Arabic or ordinary letters.

—Senator Baume knows what I mean. Actually, they are Roman letters and Arabic numerals. Let us be erudite about it. People can even misspell their own names, yet in the circumstances where it is utterly unambiguous and the application is otherwise totally sound. Under those circumstances we believe that the person ought not to be, in effect, disenfranchised through errors of that kind. The difficulties of writing in a more extensive definition of formality versus substantive error are such as to make the present clause appropriate as it stands. We urge the Opposition, on this occasion, to rethink the validity of the arguments it is putting.

—Perhaps Senator Baume may be able to clarify my concern. I am worried about the fact that the normal thing that most electors have no idea about are the subdivisions. I am worried about that. On some forms the division is printed in and the subdivision is left blank. It seems to me that the subdivisions could very well be filled out by the Australian Electoral Office without anybody being terribly upset by reference to the electors address . However, if we accept the Opposition's amendment which I am not inclined to do because of that reason, presumably what would occur would be that that would not be a valid application.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It depends on whether that has to be filled in by the elector or whether Senator Macklin might regard that as being something to be filled in by the Commonwealth Electoral Office. I am trying to respond to the points made. The subdivision, in fact, could be filled in by the Electoral Office. I agree completely with the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) that the bona fides of the Australian Electoral Office are not, and never have been, in question in this issue. But the Government is leaving to the total discretion of the electoral officer which parts of the application he may fill in to complete the application. Senator Macklin mentioned the subdivision. We think that is something that the Electoral Office might be able to fill in. But we think that what we have proposed is a reasonable attempt to try to minimise the chance of the inadvertent ruining of an application and, at the same time, leaving an appropriate amount of onus on the elector.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 75 to 79-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 80.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Page 105, clause 80, lines 39 to 41, leave out proposed paragraph 106C (2) (c).
(23) Page 105, clause 80, line 42, leave out ''where paragraph (c) does not apply-''.
(24) Page 106, clause 80, line 1, leave out ''where paragraph (c) applies'', insert ''where only the name, or a name, of 1 party is so entered''.

Basically, our concern refers to the Senate ballot paper. We have the possibility here, for the first time-I think that ought to be acknowledged-of giving great assistance to the voter by having the party affiliation of the candidate, if the candidate desires, placed on the ballot paper. I think this will help enormously. By way of an aside, I point out that, in the Northern Territory election on Saturday, for the first time in Australia, ballot papers will carry photographs of the candidates. That seems to be an extremely interesting innovation. It might be detrimental to some candidates but I think it is an interesting innovation.

The problem I am alluding to is that, as the ballot paper was originally drawn up-if honourable senators wish to refer to it it is actually Form E in Schedule 1 attached to the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendment Bill-there arises two ways in which the teams could be indicated on the ballot paper. First, the name could be put beside each of the candidates; but, secondly, if all of those candidates were of the same team, the name would appear once only. I do not expect to get a great deal of support from the National Party or the Liberal Party on this subject, because basically it is not in their interests. But I think they would accept that it is a fair thing that, since the Australian Labor Party would be running a team, what would happen to the Labor Party would be that its name would appear only once whereas in those States in which the Liberals and the Nationals run a combined ticket there would be Liberal and Liberal, National and National, or Liberal and whatever the operation was. So the whole ballot paper would become unbalanced in terms of having a dominance of one party in relation to one team and lots of names next to another team. I am not quite sure why the Labor Party put this provision into the Bill. I hope that it will see that it is in Labor Party interests to take it out, because it tells against the Labor Party and, speaking from the Australian Democrats' point of view, I believe it tells against us. But in all fairness, the simplest way of dealing with the matter is that every candidate ought to have next to his name the party designation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government accepts the amendment.
—I ask Senator Macklin what this proposal does to his final amendment which relates to taking out the number '5'; are they connected in any way?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — Yes, they are connected. The later amendment picks up the schedule in relation to numbering.
—Is it consequential?
—It is consequential on these amendments being passed, yes.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Clause 80, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 81 agreed to.
Clause 82 (Group voting tickets to be displayed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes clause 82. I draw the Committee's attention to page 122 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. As far as I know, there were no dissenting statements entered in relation to this page; so I can presume that what is written on it had the agreement of Senator Robert Ray, Senator Macklin and Senator Sir John Carrick. At paragraph 6.28, this question is discussed. The essence of the argument there is that, with the new provisions for the ballot paper, with the new listing of party affiliations, the Joint Select Committee actually recommended against suggestions that there should be a non-defaceable poster to be placed on display at polling booths indicating the political affiliation of candidates. It goes on to indicate that it recommended against the display of posters in polling booths.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand that something slightly different is now being recommended here, but it was at not stage recommended by the Joint Select Committee. The only recommendation that we can find is a recommendation against the display in polling booths. A large number of questions would have to be answered, such as how those group voting tickets are to be displayed, what the technical requirements of the tickets themselves would be; who determines which one goes in which place; and whether they should be drawn by lot. A whole lot of questions, we think, might be the subject of more examination by the Joint Select Committee. But at present what we have is a recommendation by that Committee against almost the same recommendation, and we have a lot of unanswered questions about how one would move in a polling to see those recommendations put into effect with fairness, as between different groups standing for the election. Because of that, the Opposition opposes the clause as it presently stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would need to stand corrected if my understanding of 'booth' as distinct from 'place' is a booth where the individual goes to cast his vote. We are not talking about a display within a polling place. We are talking about a facility for each elector, privately to be able to look and to see displayed the how to vote recommendations of the various candidates and teams.
—That is precisely what was recommended against.

—Indeed, the Joint Select Committee looked at this matter and said that it was quite impracticable, upon reflection. Let us reflect upon it. In New South Wales, for example, one might have as many as 10 groups, as such, and one might have five or six independent candidates. So, technically, somehow or other inside the little booth one may have between a dozen and 15 or more individual how to vote cards all pinned up. If one believes that one should get fervent about donkey votes in this place, one at least ought to run a lottery as to how to pin up those cards, apart from the impracticability. A paper hanger would have a big job.
—This is not a polling compartment; it is a polling booth.
—Have a look at the definition, Senator.
—A new definition has been put in.

—Even so, let us take it both ways. As I understand it, a polling place is the actual facility to which one goes. When one goes through the gate, that is the polling place. Then one has a booth in which one casts one 's vote.
—No, that is the room.

—Whether it is the one little dog-box compartment or whether it is somewhere in the polling place, the same situation applies. Somehow or other, we get a dozen or more different how to vote cards on display. Let me take it in two ways. Let us suppose that what is intended is that narrow little compartment with the narrow little shelf. It becomes ludicrous to imagine that one could have a series of pakapoo tickets all displayed there, with everyone getting wry-neck trying to put their head up or down. In any case, as some are keen to have a lottery for donkey votes, surely they must have a lottery for that. One would have to know where the prime place to be was. Probably at 10 o'clock on the left would be the prime place, I suppose; or would it be better to be down at the bottom? Let us suppose that the polling booth means somewhere in the vicinity of those funny little cubicles. Does each voter race over, have a look at this, and then race back to his or oher booth? The whole thing becomes the essence of the ridiculous. In any case, as I say, it is overcome by the fact that the Joint Select Committee recomended that names of parties and designations of candidates should be on the ballot paper. The Committee recommended that the handing out of how to vote cards outside should be continued. I stress that, on whatever interpretation the meaning of 'booth' is taken-whether it be the little cubicle or the bigger compartment altogether- in the view of the Joint Select Committee and certainly in my view, the thing is quite impracticable. If it were to be put in, let us put it aside for a while and work out a lottery, because there will be a lot of fun in deciding where the prime place is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume is quite correct in saying that there was a unanimous view. But that unanimous view I believe was that how to vote cards should not be displayed inside each cubicle into which an individual goes to vote.
—Posters-I am quoting from the report.

—Well, posters or how to vote cards; I think that the terms are interchangable in this context. Here, in any event, we are really talking only about Senate and list voting. We are not talking about House of Representatives voting. The original concept of having how to vote cards in polling booths would have been to contain both the House of Representatives and the Senate cards. The very points that Senator Sir John Carrick has made are valid. I believe that it is impossible to fit such a poster fairly inside a booth, given the complexity of the federal system. I know that Senator Maguire can probably tell us that it works adequately in South Australia. I do not mean to infer that that is a backwater or a small place, Senator; but the details on the tickets are just not the same as are found at a Senate election.

SPEECH.PARA: The definition of polling booth to be put into the Act is:
. . . a building, structure, vehicle or enclosure, or a part of a building, structure, vehicle or enclosure, provided at a polling place, in pursuance of paragraph 98 (1) (b) . . .

I interpret that to mean that the booth is basically the building; the polling place is the surrounds plus the building. It does not mean the cubicle. Why put this clause in? I just think it was felt that if there were registered how to vote cards somewhere in the booth for those who were anxious to see what the registered how to vote cards were, there should be a poster saying that the Australian Labor Party has registered its card and this is the direction in which its preferences go. The Liberal Party and the Australian Democrats would also have issued their split cards, and this is the direction in which their preferences go. I think that is the reason it is there.

Senator Baume raised the point of who gets pole position, in effect. I would not have thought that was particularly relevant or advantageous in this situation, where there is only one poster on a wall somewhere in the booth. Obviously that poster would not be put right outside a cubicle; it would be put on a wall away from those cubicles, and those who are interested enough to chase it up will look at it there. I do not think it would matter much in those circumstances whether it was on the left hand side or the right hand side. It would be fairly similar, I imagine, to those old posters which used to be in electoral offices prior to a legal challenge and which used to give the names of all candidates and their party affiliations. I think it is a public service poster rather than a political poster meant to influence people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that Senator Ray's view of this matter and his interpretation of the definition of polling booth are wrong. The definition in the amending Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: 'Polling booth' means a building, structure, vehicle or enclosure, or a part of a building, structure, vehicle or enclosure--
note the word 'enclosure'--
provided at a polling place, in pursuance of paragraph 98 (1) (b), for the purpose of taking votes during polling;
Paragraph 98 (1) (b) in the principal Act, which I do not think is amended, provides--

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't take this too far, Senator, because I am about to chop your legs off.

—I just want to say that the returning officer's duty is to provide and furnish proper polling booths and ballot boxes. What is meant by the ballot box is clear and I think what is meant by the polling booth is clear, too ; that is, the little enclosure one goes into. It is not the whole building. I think the polling place would be the whole building and its surrounds. I suggest , therefore, that it follows that these posters will have to be put up in every one of those little enclosures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to disappoint Senator Missen but I have to say that the formidable legal exegisis of Senator Ray is in fact well founded. His intuitions are well founded because if we look at all the relevant provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, it is clear that the sequence is this: There are places, there are booths and within booths there are compartments. We have talked about the definition of polling booth as it appears on page 3 of the amending Bill but, on page 2, a few lines down from the top there is a definition of compartment, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: 'Compartment', in relation to a polling booth, means a compartment constructed in the polling booth in pursuance of section 101;
If we go to section 101 of the parent Act, we find this:

Polling booths shall have separate voting compartments, constructed so as to screen the voters from observation while they are marking their ballot-papers, and each voting compartment shall be furnished with a pencil for the use of voters.
So the compartments are where we find the pencil; the booths are where everyone gathers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I concede that.

—Okay. That takes us only half-way down the track, of course; we still have the argument of Senator Sir John Carrick. But as to that, I think Senator Ray's contrary explanation ought to be sufficient to carry the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just make the point that if we accept Senator Ray's view that these posters are put there for the information of the electors, one has to assume that alongside them is a little ledge and a place for the elector to put down his ballot paper and copy the poster. Does anyone really believe that it is intended, under the secret ballot procedures, to have that happen? For people simply to stare at a mass of figures on a wall and not be able to copy them down is the essence of the ridiculous. I ask the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Australian Electoral Office whether they really envisage that, alongside that display, there will be provision for an elector to make a copy. If there is, how many posters will there be because only one elector at a time can go up to the poster in the booth and make the copy? Apart from that, of course, it ceases to be a secret ballot because it is done in the open and not in the compartment. I am not in any way hexed as to whether it is a compartment or a polling booth; that does not matter . I am glad it has been clarified.
—It was pretty important to your argument a few minutes ago .

—No, it was not, because I said, if the Attorney had listened, that in fact I did not care what the meaning of a booth was. I made that abundantly clear. I did not care whether it was a compartment or a booth. Perhaps he will acknowledge that. What I am now asking the Attorney is this: Is he now saying to us that in a polling booth there will be one set of posters on the wall and some provision for an elector to copy those figures? Is it intended that the elector copy it on to his ballot paper there or does he have to copy it down on a bit of paper, then take it to the compartment and vote?
—If he wants to vote the list he has only to tick it, not copy it down.

—One of the great things that Senator Ray, with his democratic principle, recognised was the need to give everyone the right to fill in all of the 60 or 70 squares, and indeed that is why these posters are so complex. What is this poster really intended to be? Is it to be one from which electors can copy the figures on to their ballot papers? If it is we have an open vote going on; we do not have compartments at all. Is it simply for them somehow to look at the poster, memorise it and go away? Are they to copy the information on to a piece of paper and take it away? What are they to do? That is what needs to be answered before we get anywhere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sir John Carrick would know that in the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform I argued for the poster to be put into the compartment, but I graciously gave up on that because I recognised the physical impossibilities of that occurring, particularly in relation to New South Wales, the honourable senator's home State. However, I take this display-I was quite pleased to see this provision in the Act when I saw it for the first time-to be basically a way of providing public information. I think probably we have the argument around the wrong way.

SPEECH.PARA: Really, the first argument here is whether or not the list system will be on the ballot paper. If the list system is on the ballot paper the registered how to vote cards or the registered distributions of preferences that are crucial for the list system at the top to work, must be somewhere. Presumably the Commonwealth Electoral Act could simply say that these will be held by the Australian Electoral Commissioner, but I think the Act goes further, and quite rightly, and says that all of those registered distributions of preferences must actually be also in every polling booth for the information of every elector. Essentially the electors will be interested in those only if they wish to check precisely what a tick next to the Australian Democrats or the Liberal Party would mean in the list system. They do not actually have to copy it down. All a citizen has to do is put one tick on his ballot paper if he is making use of the poster on the wall.

The next section along, of course, could be-this is the point that Senator Sir John Carrick raised-that they could also use that poster if they wished to do so for filling in all of the names at the bottom of the ballot paper in the normal distribution, shall we say the manual distribution, of preferences. I also know that the political parties still, unfortunately-it is something I have fought, as Senator Sir John Carrick would remember-will be handing out how to vote cards outside. They will be how to vote cards for the manual distribution of preferences at the bottom of the ballot paper. So I think that really, rather than castigate the Government on this, one should simply say that this ought to have been done if a list system is put in place. Surely every citizen has the right to view precisely what the parties have done in registering their how to vote cards.

I discussed this matter with the Government before the Bill went through the House of Representatives and was instrumental in getting the definition of polling booth put in the legislation. There was not one in it. I could foresee a very interesting debate in the absence of such a definition. It makes it a little clearer. I was in fact keen that there be more than one, but as much as I could get from the Minister, who was eminently co-operative on this one, was an agreement to put in the word 'prominently'. That was an amendment made in the House of Representatives. We have this displayed prominently, as indeed it should be, somewhere in the polling booth, not in the polling place, and I do not see really that there is much more physically that can be done in terms of assisting and informing the voter if the list system is accepted by this place. So really this is predicated on the acceptance of the list system. If we accept the list system I believe that poster ought to be in the polling booth as a matter of course for the information of citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether this is the appropriate place to mention this but certainly this is the first clause which talks about two-group voting tickets. I appreciate that there is a substantive clause on that issue which comes up subsequently. I have a suggestion to make in relation to that subsequent clause, and if I am successful we can come back to this clause. I would like the Attorney-General to explain why two-group voting tickets are mentioned here. If he says it is mentioned here because it is relevant to the subsequent part of the legislation I would like to ask him why there are two and not three or four.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister, when he is replying, to answer one of my original questions. Assuming that this is proceeded with, in what order and by what method will the various registered tickets of the parties be displayed? If in fact it has been considered that there ought to be a lottery-and there are wonderful phrases such as 'double randomisation'-what system is to be used for the order in which these are displayed upon the poster?
—I am sorry? Was that a question?

—I simply said that assuming that this is carried, as it is likely to be with the Democrat support, what method will be used to determine the order of display of the particular registered how to vote cards in this situation? After all, it has been regarded as of great significance to have a random system in other things. What is going to happen here?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —To answer Senator Sir John Carrick's question, the absence of agreement as between the parties as to the order in which they appear and in the absence of prescription in the terms of the statute, the appropriate technique would be to draw the order by ballot. I am sure that is how the courts would regard the matter as being best addressed , should anyone be minded to challenge some sequence established otherwise by the Australian Electoral Office.
—Would that include also the order of the two preferences that the party used?

—I imagine it would be up to the party with a two-sequence ticket to determine the order in which it wanted those two successive sequences to be put. No doubt it would want half the posters printed one way and half printed the other way, but we will cross that bridge when we come to it.

SPEECH.PARA: As to Senator Harradine's question as to why we have only two-group voting tickets rather than three, four of five, I suppose the simple fact is that we are adjusting this legislation to the realities of the world we inhabit, and so far within that world there seems to have been pressure to have only a two-group voting ticket. Should the real world throw up someone who wants more than that-I do not imagine it would be Senator Harradine because he would regard his electors as being far too intelligent to require this sort of open-ended direction from him-it could be considered at some later stage. But what we are trying to do is simply accommodate the demands of those parties existing in the system at the moment which have a view that their supporters and the peculiar idiosyncracies of their supporters ought to be accommodated in a particular way.
