I do not think one can honestly claim that there is any high principle behind the establishment of a two-group ticket system rather than some multiple ticket system, but it is just a reflection of the realities that presently prevail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Attorney-General says that he expects that the random system will be the appropriate one, will he therefore consider the Government adopting an addendum to the effect that the order of the ticket on the poster shall be determined by random ballot?
—Yes, in an order determined by lot. We can add those words at the end.
—Whatever words the Minister chooses.
—There is no difficulty about that. I have consulted the technical committee scattered around the chamber, as it is, and we are in no difficulty in accommodating that suggestion.

—I mention a matter of procedure. The indication that we have given to the Committee is that we will oppose the clause. I do not know in what order the Government wants to vote on the clauses, but if it is intended to accept an amendment a little time will be required to draft it and get it into the right form. Senator Harradine has suggested, I think correctly, that what is contained in this clause is consequential to what is contained in another part of the Bill. I take it that an appropriate course of action might be now to move for the postponement of the consideration of this clause to some appropriate stage. Perhaps the Attorney-General might care to so move.
—Yes, that would appear to be sensible. I appreciate the Opposition's embarrassment in dividing on the location of posters.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —In any case, I could not put the question that this clause be printed until the amendment has been put.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That further consideration of this clause be postponed until a further hour this day.
Clauses 83 to 85-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes clause 86. I declare a vested interest, being of the Jewish faith. The convenience and rights of electors and individuals need to be set against the convenience, rights and legitimate interests of parties and electoral officers. The Commonwealth Electoral Act provides for 8 o'clock closing of the polls. This is a valued time of closing for certain people. There are members of my religion who will vote after sundown and, although with daylight saving it is not always possible, at many elections it is possible for Orthodox Jews to vote in person after sundown during those hours, 6 p.m. to 8 p.m., which it is now being proposed be removed from the hours of polling.

SPEECH.PARA: It is possible for members of the Seventh Day Adventist religion to vote on many days between the hours of 6 p.m. and 8 p.m. The extension to 8 p.m. provides an opportunity for small minorities in the community to exercise a vote in person, and it really is an important symbolic matter because the reduction of the polling hours to 6 p.m. will remove from some of these people the capacity to cast their votes in person at most times of the year unless sundown occurs before 6 p.m. That is the argument in terms of two religious minorities. They might ask why we do not move election day to Sunday. For the religious majority election day is not the day which happens to be the Sabbath for it. I accept that tradition has had it that elections are held on Saturdays. Let me remind the Senate that in many countries around the world election day is on neither Saturday nor Sunday. Such countries respect the sensibilities of people and have elections on mid-week days and make quite appropriate arrangements. I think that if we carry out this kind of major review of the Act a good case could be made for moving our polling day to a day which would give no offence to anyone. That would then enable us to look again at the question of 6 p.m. closing of the polls. But there are other groups of people for whom 8 p.m. closing is important. They include certain people in rural occupations who, if the election is held at or about harvest time when they are working from sun-up to sundown, value the opportunity to come in late.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about daylight saving?

—I mentioned earlier that daylight saving on some polling days means that sundown will occur after 8 p.m., but that is on only some polling days in summer. People in some rural industries and others have to travel considerable distances. Again, Saturday is a major day for sporting activities and some sporting events. Cricket matches, for example, do not finish until 6 o'clock. For those people the extra two hours provide extra opportunities to vote in person. I freely acknowledge that for parties the convenience of having party workers free at 6 o'clock is an advantage. I freely concede that for the Electoral Office there are advantages in having the polls close at 6 p.m. but I put to honourable senators that they have to consider on the one hand the convenience of the Electoral Office and parties and on the other hand the convenience and opportunities for individual electors.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously, if I were putting here the interests of the Liberal Party or the National Party I would be endorsing 6 p.m. closing, but we see that it means a reduction in the opportunites for pesonal voting for a few Australian electors. The number does not have to be great. It is not great. If we reduce the opportunities for anyone it is very hard to call it a reform. It is an amendment of convenience for those in politics, in political parties, or in the bureaucracy responsible for the conducting of elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about all the money it would save?

—Again, we have to set on the one hand the savings and on the other the possible extra rights of electors. I certainly do not think that alters the argument one bit. The other argument I heard put is that 6 p.m. closing would enable us to get the results more quickly. I suppose it would. We could work out the mathematics and work out east coast, west coast and daylight saving in one State. I do not argue against the proposition that we would get the results more rapidly. Again, the issue is what advantages might flow to one elector or to a small group of electors. From the desire to get election results quickly, one might say that such a group is small enough not to matter. I have never belived that the rapidity with which results come through affects the democratic process one bit. It does not matter. I recall my election to the Senate. Senator Sibraa drew attention to that particular contest during the second reading debate. It took 35 days to get a result. I could not care less. The fact is that it is the process and the fairness in the process which is more important than the convenience--
—What is more democratic about physical voting than postal voting?

—Many people prefer, and it is easier for them, to vote in person close to their homes. the process of applying for a postal vote is slightly more complicated. In any event, I am very much surprised to hear the Attorney-General, as it were talking down the opportunity which some people presently have to vote during those last two hours. I simply put to the Committee that it is the wish of the Opposition to preserve the rights of even small numbers of Australians to vote in person. It is for that reason, whether on the grounds of religion, occupation or sport, that we will oppose the clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that it would be more democratic if we kept the polls open till midnight because the natural corollary of what Senator Baume has said is that certain people, expecially for religious reasons, miss out on voting on certain occasions. Even with 8 o'clock closing during daylight saving it remains light until 9 o'clock and those people miss out. I would have thought that the natural extension of his argument was to keep the polls open until about 10 o'clock at night. Approximately 8 per cent of the electorate, when there is 8 o'clock closing, vote between 6 and 8 o'clock. The average one would expect is 18 per cent if people voted evenly in two-hour blocks. Therefore, I contend that fewer people vote between 6 p.m. and 8 p.m. than in most other two-hour periods. The reasons for moving to this particular position relate back to why we originally had 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. voting. I suggest that the problems of communication and transport were great around 1900. Perhaps almost no one at that stage owned cars; today a majority of people own them. People today are more mobile; they get to booths more quickly. I suggest to Senator Baume that he has put up a theoretical case rather than a practical one, although he may be able to adduce evidence--
—It depends whether you are Jewish.

—He may be able to adduce evidence that some people are upset by it. He has produced none today and I can relate other experiences. For a start, Queensland has had 6 o'clock closing since 1915. I am unaware that the conservative Government up there, which I am sure the honourable senator will concede is no less sensitive than himself, has ever moved to revoke 6 o'clock poll closing in the past 26 years it has been in office. I remind the Senate that it was a Liberal Government that introduced 6 o'clock closing in Victoria for the 1977 election. In my speech during the second reading debate I related that many people were worried that in the initial election people would be disadvantaged and that there would be complaints about it. I saw no complaints registered in any of the newspapers, including the Jewish News in Melbourne. I instructed all scrutineers throughout the State to report if people were unhappy with those particular voting procedures. In the end, we got no complaints at all .

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Maguire informed me a few minutes ago that South Australia went to 6 o' clock closing in 1982. Again, there were no problems. I think Senator Baume is inventing the problems. New South Wales has had 6 o'clock for some years. Again, there have been no major problems. I believe it is an economical move but it is also more than just a matter of economics, more than a matter of saving several hundred thousand dollars by cutting out two hours. I do not care about the party workers in this regard. We roster people in two hour shifts and we always have too many people. Manning that number of shifts is not a party problem. The one thing that I agree with Senator Peter Baume about is that there is no political advantage in having either 6 o'clock or 8 o'clock closing. But there is a disadvantage to those people who are hired to work that day. They have to work from 8 a.m. until 8 p.m. with perhaps an additional three hours counting. So it is a 15-hour day for individuals concerned with the electoral process. I know that they are paid to do it, but 15 hours is a fairly long day. Cutting two hours off it is a major advantage. The earlier results argument, I agree, is a fairly ephemeral one. It does not really matter whether one gets earlier results . It is probably a little nicer, a little easier, but it is not the absolute argument.

Before we finally consider this, it is incumbent upon those opposite to come up with some evidence that a large or even a substantial majority of people are upset by this. As I say, when the changeover occurred in New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria, there were to my knowledge no complaints made. People adapted to the system fairly well. Senator Baume makes out a case for the Orthodox Jewish community, but he conceded that in probably half the elections we have they are still unable to vote. In the elections of 2 December 1972, 13 December 1975 and again this year I think daylight saving came in a week or two later, so in three out of the last six elections they have not been able to vote in person. The logical corollary is either to extend voting to 10 o'clock or 11 o'clock at night or to give those people a postal vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —March 5th, this year's election?

—I think that we were then still operating under daylight saving. That no doubt can be checked. I am assured that I am correct. Certainly, from memory, in Queensland the results came in an hour behind those of other places. Polling places there closed an hour later than polling places on the rest of the east coast, so certainly daylight saving was in operation then. In conclusion, I say that it would be cheaper, and it would be easier on the workers inside the booths. It has not been brought forward out of concern for the workers outside the booths because usually they are not doing a 12-hour shift, unless they are very dedicated. It does not really affect them at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been suggested that our amendment concerns only a small number of voters. From the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, one notes that the Electoral Office stated that 8 per cent or more of voters vote between 6 p.m. and 8 p.m. That is a little matter of three-quarters of a million voters-not exactly a small number. Given the opportunity, at least 8 per cent of the community find it convenient to vote between 6 p.m. and 8 p.m. That is something that we ought to consider profoundly. What is our purpose if not to provide a polling day that is convenient. I cannot, for the life of me, understand why a government which is obviously opposed to extending postal voting wants to deny to a significant section of the community the right to an ordinary vote. Surely one should devise a polling day which will permit all sections of the community that are physically capable of voting to go and cast an ordinary vote. Yet what we are being told is, no, the Jewish community and the Adventist community can obtain a postal vote; sometimes it does not matter anyway because daylight saving applies . That is a convenient situation. Surely it is fundamental that we should not say: 'Look, we have adopted 6 o'clock in such and such a State and therefore to force that 8 per cent of the people to vote by that time is valid'. Why is it valid to say that the 8 per cent who in the past have chosen to vote between 6 p .m. and 8 p.m. should be forced now to vote earlier, against their normal practice; if we do so, everything will be all right? After all, there are many examples from around the world of government sanctions that have squeezed the population. Of course, there is no overt reaction: but ask the Jewish community one by one whether it is happy about having to fill in a postal vote, ask the Adventist community one by one and see whether it is happy about it; of course, they are not. Ask those who, because of work or recreation, will be forced into tighter hours whether they are happy. I repeat that the evidence before the Committee is that not a handful of people, but 8 per cent of the community-one in every 12 voters-if given the opportunity will vote between 6 p.m. and 8 p.m. That must mean that they find it the most convenient time to vote. If that is so what we are saying to them is: 'We are not concerned about your convenience, about the convenience of one in 12 voters of Australia; you can now react to our convenience'. That, of course, is a summation of the argument of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are doing is bringing the federal laws into line with those of the rest of the country. As has been said today, only in Western Australia and Tasmania now do the polls close at 8 p.m. All of the other States, including the Northern Territory where the poll this weekend will be closing at 6 p.m., now close the poll at the earlier hour. In New South Wales, when 6 p.m. closing first came into operation at the State elections, we were terrified that the 8 per cent of whom Senator Sir John Carrick talks would be our supporters and would not vote. But when we looked at the statistics afterwards, at the number of people who got to the polls before 6 p.m., we found that there was no difference. The 94 or 95 per cent of people who vote voted anyway when the closing hour was brought back to 6 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: What is proposed is a reform. An argument has been put about cost. I will not put it because I do not think that a lot of money is involved when we consider the cost of running an election. What is proposed is a reform of working conditions. I do not think it is reasonable to expect the hard workers to be at the polling booths at 7 a.m. and to stay there until 10 p.m. or 11 p.m.

Senator Peter Baume mentioned sporting events, such as cricket, but I do not think any sporting event today starts at 8 a.m. and goes through to 8 p.m. At the last elections, the first results from Queensland came in at 10 p.m., so daylight saving must have been in force. I recall that for that reason we did not get the first results from Western Australia until after 11 p.m., eastern summer time.

Senator Peter Baume said that in 1974 it took 35 days to count the Senate vote and that in 1975 the election took place on 13 December and we did not get a result for the Senate in New South Wales until 6 February. In 1976 it did not really matter because the result of the election was clear cut. It mattered to only a few people, of whom I was one, but the other reforms that are effected by this Bill will not, I think, allow that situation to occur again. It was farcical but it would not have been funny if the control of this Senate had hung in the balance from 13 December 1975 to 6 February 1976.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it did in 1974; it did hang in the balance.

—I am aware of the situation in which Senator Peter Baume was placed in 1974, but I hope that that situation will not occur again. What we are suggesting is that federal laws should now be brought into line with those of the majority of the States. I am sure that Western Australia will soon go to 6 p .m. closing and that will leave only one State, Tasmania, which always seems to want to be different on many things, where it will not apply. We should pass this measure as soon as possible.

—I wish to mention briefly a matter that may not have been given due consideration by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform or by this Committee. It is that whereas, when 8 o'clock closing was introduced, there was not the extent of commercial activity on Saturdays that there is currently. The argument has always been that shift workers would have shifts which finished at times which would be convenient for them to register a vote at the appropriate polling place in their subdivision. Now, with the unfortunate extension of Saturday afternoon trading, particularly in New South Wales where it appears that all-day Saturday trading will be in vogue, we will have thousands of workers on that day in shops, at the counters, between 9 a.m. and 6 p.m. If we have, as we do in Sydney, a lot of city workers travelling considerable distances, for up to an hour and a half, to and from work, such people will not be able to register a vote in the subdivision. I wonder whether the Committee has considered that or whether, if this particular proposal goes through, the Joint Select Committee will keep its eye on that aspect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to respond to a couple of points that have been made. Just for the record, 5 March is close to the equinox; sunrise is at 6 a.m. and sunset at 6 p.m., more or less. Therefore, even allowing for daylight saving, people will be able to vote during the daylight hours on 5 March. Secondly, I have taken the trouble since the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform made its report to canvass the appropriate religious bodies. Although I did not receive universal concern about an 8 p.m. closing of the poll I received substantial majority concern. As a result of requests from the people I canvassed in the Seventh Day Adventist and Jewish communities, I seek to oppose the earlier closing of the poll, at 6 p.m. instead of 8 p.m. I am grateful to Senator Harradine who drew our attention to another group of people who may be quite unable to vote in person between 8 a.m. and 6 p .m. I ask honourable senators--
—They are members of my union.
—I suppose the Jews are members of my union too.

SPEECH.PARA: Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., pursuant to the order of the Senate I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the Chair and report to the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Censorship of Parliamentarians-Parliamentary Delegation Gifts-Professional Protestors against Uranium Mining-Human Rights Commission of Inquiry on the Northern Territory Police-Parliamentary Committee Sittings

PROCTEXT.PARA: Censorship of Parliamentarians-Parliamentary Delegation Gifts-Professional Protestors against Uranium Mining-Human Rights Commission of Inquiry on the Northern Territory Police-Parliamentary Committee Sittings

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: — I want to make an important statement regarding the position of democratically elected senators speaking publicly on issues of concern to their constituents. On 3 November I responded in the Townsville Daily Bulletin to statements made by the Premier of Queensland in which he said a mining lease would be granted for the processing of uranium at Ben Lomond in north Queensland. To many in the community this appeared an irresponsible move as in 1981 Erich Landich, the mining warden at Charters Towers, recommended against the granting of a lease to Minatome Australia as he felt it could prejudicially affect the interest of the public. There was, in his opinion at that time, grave doubts concerning the safety of the mine in relation to the pollution of the water catchment area of the Burdekin system, and Minatome had not provided sufficient technical information to enable a proper assessment of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: In my statement I reminded the Premier that several years ago a radioactive uranium stockpile at Ben Lomond was found to be leaking into the local creeks feeding Keelbottom Creek and the Burdekin. If further seepage occurs in that creek system, the magnitude of the consequences could be formidable. Not only could the water supplies for the residents of Charters Towers and Townsville be affected but so too could the grazing and agricultural industries in the north. This response was based on evidence produced in the Mining Warden's Court in 1981 and from several well-discussed news reports of the aforementioned radiation leak.
Yet on 21 November I received a letter from the Chairman of Total Mining Australia Pty Ltd, formerly Minatome, Mr Phillip De Boos-Smith, in which he wrote:

I have seen somewhat belatedly, a report in the Townsville Bulletin of 3 November in which you make very serious allegations concerning operations at the Ben Lomond site by Total Mining Australia (formerly Minatome Australia). In particular you are quoted as saying '. . . several years ago a radio-active uranium stockpile at Ben Lomond was found to be leaking into the local creeks feeding Keelbottom Creek and the Burdekin'.
He went on:

This statement is not correct, and is of course very damaging to us, particularly in view of the fact that it was made on the eve of our publishing an environmental impact statement for the Ben Lomond project, which had been prepared at very significant cost and which involved three years of work. In fact we have been informed by our legal advisers that the statement is clearly defamatory and would give us grounds for legal action.

I was somewhat surprised by the tone of this letter which was clearly designed to intimidate by reference to possible legal proceedings. My legal advisers have informed me that in any action for defamation under Queensland law, a defendant has recourse to the defence of truth and privilege when matters allegedly defamatory are published in the public interest.

Furthermore, the question of the radiation leak was confirmed by the Queensland Water Quality Council, and in evidence submitted in the Charters Towers Mining Warden's Court in 1981. At this stage I seek leave to table two documents, one from the Queensland Water Quality Council and a report headed 'Creek Radiation Over the Limit'.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The basis of my concern has in fact been aired publicly by many people over a number of years. Therefore, any public expression of concern is clearly my responsible duty to the people of Queensland and I will not be silenced by veiled threats of legal proceedings. My concerns have been echoed by individuals and groups from very diverse backgrounds including the Queensland Minister for Northern Development and Aboriginal and Island Affairs, Bob Katter Jnr, the Townsville and District Regional Conservation Council and the Charters Towers Council.

SPEECH.PARA: In Charters Towers the local councillors recently passed a motion opposing all heavy mining in the Burdekin catchment, including Ben Lomond. It is also reported that the Charters Towers Development Bureau and the Charters Towers Chamber of Commerce are deeply concerned about the Ben Lomond proposal. The trade union movement has also spoken out on the issue of potential environmental and health risks. Members of the James Cook University of North Queensland community with expertise in relevant disciplines are currently studying the implications of uranium mining at Ben Lomond.

Yet the Total company dares to stifle genuine community debate by writing to me in this clearly intimidatory manner. I would like to know why this company feels so under threat from a mere back bench Government member who speaks of genuine community concerns which have been discussed publicly over a number of years. If the company's recently released environmental impact study satisifies the doubts expressed by the Mining Warden's Court in 1981, why is it so nervous about my comments? Why should a reputable company wish to silence me on such an important issue?

The fact that the letter suggests legal action will not result if I am prepared to withdraw my statement is, I believe, an insult. Surely if the Total company is serious about alleged misinformation it certainly has the resources and the influence to argue its own case through the media. It can, if it has appropriate documentation and research, surely prove its own case without resorting to such bullying standover tactics.

Its recently released environmental impact statement is a public document, which is open to scrutiny and comment. That scrutiny and comment, I would submit , cannot occur in an atmosphere of intimidation. How many similar letters have been sent to concerned members of the community who dared to question the proposal of Total Mining? How many more letters are planned for anybody who dares to speak out? Will the State Minister for Northern Development, Bob Katter Jnr, be similarly rebuked for his letter to the Premier on 7 December 1981? In that letter he said:
Dear Mr Premier
re BEN LOMOND

This issue has sparked off an enormous public reponse in Charters Towers and the surrounding district, and a very strong public opinion has voiced itself through the 'Concerned About the Burdekin and Ben Lomond' (CABBL) Group.
One of the major fears of our community, whether the individuals are pro-or anti-uranium mining, is that the decision to extend Minatome's lease will not be given back to the Warden's court.

Although I have always thought the magistrate was an inappropriate person to make such decisions, in this case it is important that the case should go before an open court once again, rather than behind closed doors in a situation where the public are not able to put forward their case.
You have previously said yourself--
this is referring to the Premier's statement in the Australian of 6 June 1981--

that the decision will have to go back to the Court. In this way justice will be seen to be done. This decision must be made in an open hearing or we will leave ourselves open to accusations of a 'snow-job'.

I would plead with you not to take this case lightly. The untold damage that this issue could do to this town can already be seen. Enrolments in our largest industry, education institutions, already appear to be down to a significant degree as a direct result of the uranium situation.
Awaiting your urgent reply.
Yours sincerely,
BOB KATTER JNR, MLA

I believe a further incident should be reported to the Senate. On Wednesday, 23 November, just two days after receiving my letter from Total Mining, my office began inquiries to locate the report of the Queensland Department of Mines on which the Minister based his decision to grant the lease without reference back to the Mining Warden's Court, as called for so vehemently by Mr Katter. That report is shrouded in secrecy. Apparently, it is not to be made available for public scrutiny despite the comments in this letter of 1981. If officers of the Queensland Department of Mines are so confident that they can recommend the granting of mining leases, surely their report to the Minister should be a public document.

At the same time as I was making fairly fruitless inquiries about this report, I received an anonymous STD phone call at my Townsville office, telling me simply to keep out of Ben Lomond. Whether this call was made deliberately by a person of some authority or was merely a coincidental call from an unknown antagonist is questionable. The issue I wish to highlight in this place is that democratically elected representatives have a clear responsibility to their constituents and should not expect to be thus intimidated. In the case of Ben Lomond, it is certainly not my intention to assume a dogmatic expertise on the complex issues involved. I welcome an ongoing rational debate about any issue of significance to the people of Queensland. Therefore I hope that, despite the unfortunate circumstances on which I have reported tonight, it will be possible to resume such debate to guarantee that all opinions and information are duly considered in decisions affecting Ben Lomond and the people of that area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The matter that I want to raise tonight has caused some embarrassment to most if not all members of a parliamentary delegation of which I was a member. I know from talking to fellow members of parliament that something similar has caused members of other delegations some embarrassment. The matter I refer to involves the appalling quality and the often embarrassing inappropriateness of official gifts which parliamentary delegations offer to officials whom they meet on overseas visits. I cite, just as one example, something which happened on a delegation of which I was not a member, but which I heard about when I returned recently from overseas. Apparently the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made a gift of an ashtray to somebody who was a non-smoker. It would seem to me that a little research on the part of whoever is responsible for allocating such gifts would overcome this sort of thing.

SPEECH.PARA: The delegation I was on had a wonderful trip to Italy, Spain and Greece. While in Spain we were guests of the Spanish Government. It excelled itself in its hospitality and its generosity. I think that the fact that it put us through a fairly punishing routine from day to day and that we were all suffering from exhaustion by the end of the week, spoke more for the Government's enthusiasm than for its attempts to get rid of a few Australian parliamentarians. The Government paid for our accommodation, our meal expenses, and the cost of our travels throughout the country. It was exceptionally generous, as I have said, and most hospitable. The official functions which it invited us to were some of the best to which I have ever been. The Government also showered us with gifts both as a parliamentary group and as individuals. The gifts that it gave us ranged from a miniature leather-bound set of the Spanish Constitution for each of us to personal gifts-I received a most attractive gold shawl-through to a beautiful plaque which was a gift from the Spanish Senate to the Australian Senate. It was not a gift to the Australian Parliament but was from the Spanish Senate to the Australian Senate and was a most attractive plaque.

I really do not know whether I have the strength to report what we gave in return. We were at the final dinner, hosted by the Spanish Cortes. Members from both Houses of the Spanish Parliament were present. We had an extremely elaborate four-course meal, with different wines provided at each course. The dinner was held in the Cortes, but the meal was provided by one of the best restaurants in Spain, so it was brought in from outside. The Government brought in minstrels from the law faculty of the university; in fact it feted us. At the end of the meal we exchanged gifts. Quite frankly, most of the members of the delegation died from embarrassment at what was handed over. The present that was given to the Spanish Cortes was a ceramic bowl. I do not think it is going too far to say that it looked like something which should belong under somebody's bed. The gift which we gave to the Spanish Senate was a polished blackwood bowl of about 8 inches in diameter. It was simply a nut bowl, and a very ordinary looking bowl. The silence in that room was deafening.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you do not even understand Spanish. How do you know?
—It looked, Senator Chaney, as if it had come from Woolworths. Although I am assured that it did not, that is nevertheless what it looked like.
—Coles, perhaps.

—Perhaps it was Coles. In addition to that gift, we gave to the President of the Cortes and the President of the Senate what in fact were attractive gifts. They were cigarette boxes. I do not know whether either of them smoke. I know the Spanish have a penchant for cigars. These cigarette boxes were made of wood and covered with leather. Sending leather to Spain is a little akin to sending coals to Newcastle. I suggest that when we are part of an official delegation and when we present official gifts to high ranking officials in another country, we are representing this country, a country of which every member of a delegation is proud, and we should offer gifts which we are equally proud to give them.

SPEECH.PARA: I can see no reason why we can not offer a parliament of another country, particularly if it is hosting our visits, an Australian painting, for instance. This could be hung in a parliament as a permanent memento of our visit. I understand that the gifts which we gave the Spanish Parliament-and they were similar to the gifts which we handed over in Italy and Greece-were expensive. I would argue that that is not the point. The point is that we should be giving something appropriate as thanks for our visit. It should be appropriate as a gift from an Australian delegation to the Spanish Parliament, the Greek Parliament, the Italian Parliament or to any other Parliament. It should be something which says something about our country and which is unique but tasteful. It should not be kitsch, which, to all intents and purposes, is what our gifts were.

I understand that fairly rigid protocol operates in Australia about what is given to whom and by whom. I will not argue about the cost of those gifts. All I say is that some research should be done about who we give them to and that some thought should be put into the gifts by somebody with a little more taste than, I daresay, the male bureaucrat who has gone around choosing these things and who seems to think that some level of protocol is what should operate rather than thought being given to the appropriateness of the gift.

I am sorry to come back from a trip which, to all other intents and purposes, I very much enjoyed, from which I learned a great deal, at which there was a tremendous amount of rapport between our delegation and members of the various parliaments whom we met and at which a great deal of information of mutual benefit and interest was exchanged, with this sort of complaint. It spoilt the trip. That evening after the Spanish dinner we went back to the hotel in the company of Australia's Ambassador to Spain. His comment to me was that he did not think he would show his face around the Spanish Cortes for a while. We all felt acutely embarrassed.

I do not like to keep repeating this. I do not know what can be done about it. I simply ask that some sort of shakeup be carried out in the department that organises the sorts of gifts and the level of appropriateness with which we give those gifts so that they are appropriate, of good quality, and say something specific and typical about Australia without being embarrassing. At present they are tawdry, perhaps kitschy-I do not know what the word is-but something has to be done about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on the same subject that Senator Haines has raised. I think it would be appropriate in the circumstances for us to review this situation. I had the privilege of being on a parliamentary delegation which was invited to Japan by the House of Councillors. It has quite specifically devised a medal of the House of Councillors which is quite typically Japanese but also is quite typical of the Diet. It seems that we , in Australia, ought to revise the situation so that we discontinue illustrating what we in Australia have probably become known for-that we have a cultural cringe. We have a magnificent craft industry in Australia and we have magnificent artists. Top quality people who can produce works of art that are equal to anything anywhere in the world are available to the Government. I think it would not be terribly difficult to revise the situation which currently prevails so that we can make use of the enormous talents which exist in Australia and which have been exhibited in so many places overseas and yet which we seem to leave aside on these occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: I too was upset by the gifts. I was not upset so much at the cost because I inquired and they were quite expensive gifts which were appropriate in the circumstances. I believe that all the correct protocol had been met. Nevertheless, I think the extra touch had not been met. The gifts did not display anything of Australia and, in a way, did not display anything of the Parliament. We were part of a parliamentary delegation. It seems that under those circumstances it would be most appropriate if, in fact, we could have something of the Parliament which could be used as gifts and be reminders to the recipients of the delegation's visit.

Those delegations are of enormous benefit to Australia. They help to form reciprocal ties. I believe this extra touch which currently is missing would provide a long term and a beneficial effect for Australia. It is an area which may seem small and personal, but it is the small personal touches which probably end up improving relations between countries much more than the more dramatic and high-flown speeches which are made. I hope we can address ourselves to this problem. I hope the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) conveys these thoughts to the Government so that we can look at the situation and employ the enormous talents that we have in Australia to promote Australia and this Parliament overseas when our delegations visit other countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I commence speaking about the subject I wish to raise in this adjournment debate, I add my concern to the views expressed by Senator Macklin and Senator Haines. I have been a member of one or two parliamentary delegations. Some of the gifts that have been handed to other countries as representing Australia have been poor. Perhaps the word is junky. Whatever the word is, the gifts are certainly not up to the standard of gifts given that should come from Australia. Many lovely things which represent Australia could be given. I join with the two honourable senators in hoping that something can be done to improve the standard of these gifts which are given by Australia and by our Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight I want to talk about the controversial matter of Soviet funding of peace organisations in the Western world. Perhaps a more appropriate name would be surrender organisations. Before doing so, I table in the Senate various newspaper clippings numbered from No. 1 onwards to which I will be referring. They are mostly clippings from various Australian newspapers and are of considerable interest.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just recently the Australian radical left protest circuit has made the important Australian United States defence installation at Pine Gap its target. During the 1970s and the 1980s, Australia's Marxist forces came to a consensus on the issues of stopping the mining of uranium, a vital fuel supply in a world so heavily dependent on unstable Middle East oil supplies and on having American forces frozen out of Australia and the Asian-Pacific region, thus removing the United States deterrent to the Soviet Union in the Pacific region. Australia's Marxist hard left forces are acting on behalf of the Societ Union to help stop United States rearmament in the face of the rapidly expanding forces of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

SPEECH.PARA: After a decade and perhaps millions of dollars of campaigning they have utterly failed. Now, with the Left of the Australian Labor Party an indistinguishable part of this movement, their immediate aim is to fragment the ALP, Hawke and the non-Left forces. To this end they have skilfully set out to manipulate the media . They use what never amounts to more than a couple of hundred professional demonstrators to attract continuous Press, radio and, particularly, television coverage. Mr Hawke and his supporters helped bring this situation upon themselves. When they supported the Franklin Dam protestors who have formed the core of the Roxby Downs and Pine Gap protests, they let these protestors believe that mob rule even on the wilderness and in the streets could mould the policy of a mainstream party. At least with the Roxby protest, the Press found that the hard Left movement against uranium mining and the Friends of the Earth were running training camps and using Victorian government school property for this purpose. I refer to Press cutting No. 1 which I tabled. The media also learned that the much advertised non-violent direct action was to be included.

According to News Weekly-I refer honourable senators to the newspaper clipping No. 1A dated 7 September 1983-the term 'non-violent direct action' is, in itself , contradictory. Direct action involves the use of physical force and, to that extent at least, is violent. The tactic involved in 'non-violent direct action' is one of provocation-to provoke the police by obstructing police vehicles, intimidating police officers, shouting abuse, and chanting slogans containing demands. These actions are designed to create a situation in which the actual nature of events appears reversed to those in the media and their audiences. The police are depicted as violent, while the demonstrators who have provoked the police are depicted as non-violent victims. The media plays a special role in the direct action process. To publicise and promote 'the cause', violent scenes are orchestrated by provoking the police beyond endurance. The subsequent confrontation between direct actionists and police provides exciting viewing and reporting.

The Roxby 'non-violent direct action' plan included occupation of the mining site's generator plant, writing graffiti on the runway at the mine and across the company's trucks, the use of video cameras trained on police to convince them that they were being constantly monitored, and a plan to tear down the fences at the mine as a last resort. When put into action, the violence that the plan was designed to provoke was achieved. The Press, to its credit, exposed the protest for the way that it provoked violence, so much so that one of our senators, Senator Don Chipp, decided not to fly in to lend his support. I think that he was very wise not to support the blockaders there. Spurred on by their success at getting Hawke and Australian Labor Party support for the Franklin protest and after the Roxby farce, this band of professional protesters set out for Pine Gap and the lawns of Parliament House as well.

The Sydney Morning Herald, some months ago, carried an article telling of the move from Roxby to Pine Gap. But as the Communist Party of Australia's newspaper Tribune pointed out, there was to be one major difference. This protest was to be restricted to 'radical feminists'. The protest has been in the planning stage for months. Sarah Walls, in the Australian-I refer to the third clipping, of 10 June 1983-joined one of the Pine Gap protesters' main organising groups, the Women's Action Against Global Violence, the WAAGV, at a warm-up protest being held at the time outside the Australian Atomic Energy Commission research establishment at Lucas Heights. It was this 'mob' of 300 who protested earlier this year at the Canberra War Memorial, followed by a march on Parliament House, calling for more child care but, in the same breath, demanding the cessation of uranium mining and the ousting of United States defence bases from Australia. They also staged a 'die in', representing the effects of a nuclear war, in Martin Place, Sydney. This was repeated outside Lucas Heights.

I say all this to show that the 'protest circuit' has become a professional operation, well planned, involving the co-ordination of many widely dispersed groups, especially staged to gain maximum media coverage; and behind it all is big money. Inquiries have revealed that about $40,000, perhaps, must have gone into just hiring the buses to take the protesters to Pine Gap. It is believed that four buses came from Sydney, and one from each of Melbourne and Brisbane. I ask: Where is all the money coming from?

Overseas, the Soviet Union is known to be pouring huge amounts of funds into Western pacifist groups. An article entitled 'Pacifists Wary of Moscow's Influence' in the Wall Street Journal-I refer to cutting No. 4-dated 19 October 1983, revealed how millions were being poured into the West German pacifist groups. Friedrich Heuer, the Director of Domestic Security at the West German Interior Ministry, said that the DKP, West Germany's Communist party, was receiving about $US23m a year, much of which was being laundered through two unilateral disarmament-pacifist groups to run campaigns against the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. The West German pacifist movement is financially dependent on the DKP. Hence, when Moscow says 'Protest against the deployment of Cruise and Pershing II missiles and ignore the Soviet SS20s'-which are being deployed at the rate of one a week-the West German pacifist movement falls into line, naturally.

In Denmark last year, Ingmar Wagner, the Deputy Chairman of the National Association for Co-operation between Denmark and the USSR, and Danish representative on the World Peace Council, admitted that he was just a courier for Soviet money that he said was being used for 'international solidarity work' . This was after a young thief, arrested by the police, said how surprised he was to find 100,000 Deutschemarks hidden in Wagner's house. That is contained in clipping No. 5, from the Daily Telegraph, of London, of 24 August 1982.

This year the Swiss Government closed the office of the Novosti Press Agency, threw out the chief of the agency and forced the withdrawal of a Soviet diplomat identified as an officer of the Komitet Gosudarstrennoi Bezopasnosti-the KGB- responsible for Novosti. The agency's officers were accused of political agitation, disinformation and interference in Swiss affairs. They had infiltrated the country's pacifist movement and organised numerous left-wing demonstrations. These are just a few examples of Soviet involvement in hard Left Marxist so-called 'peace' groups.
Back in Australia, the Communist Party of Australia last week admitted in Tribune-that is No. 6 of the papers, of 3 November 1983-that:
The National Council Meeting of Communist Party decided to make a demonation to the action--
That is, the Pine Gap protest-
to provide cooking gear and to contribute to the bail fund.

That fund was considerable. Where else is the money for this great 'media exercise' coming from? Note: It is just a media exercise, for without free media coverage, 450 protesters or more out from the back of Bourke would be written off in the same category as mad dogs and Englishmen.

But the amount of money about which we are talking is by no means slight. On top of the estimated $30,000 to $40,000 spent on buses, as mentioned earlier, there were the day to day living costs and the women's fines to be considered. That sum in itself was considerable. I believe that 159 women were arrested during the protest, with the cost of fines totalling well over $11,000. If one assumes that it cost, conservatively, say, $100 to keep each protester in the field for a week, that is another $45,000 in costs. Conservatively, then, this protest has cost well over $100,000. This is just the beginning, because many of the protesters-and we saw them arrive for the other demonstrations-have arrived by air. Obviously, the air fares would have to be included and paid for by someone. I suggest that it would not be the organised demonstrators. So it is extraordinary that no one in the Press-no one that I have heard of, at least-has bothered to ask: 'Who is footing these enormous bills?'
