TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Honourable senators will note that the list contains the names of idnividuals and organisations notorious for their connections with the Communist Party of Australia and other Soviet-oriented groups. Listed also-and this is of interest-is Lesbian Line. It is rather peculiar and it makes one wonder about the naivety of some people when three members of the Tertiary Catholic Federation of Australia, including its National Chaplain, a Uniting Church minister, one or two other Christian groups and two nuns are seen to be running not only in a campaign dominated by communist groups who are philosophically committed to the annihilation of Christianity but with a lesbian organisation. It is sad to see such people being used to legitimise this campaign and, therefore, making it 'respectable' to the media. Perhaps 'used' is not the correct term for, when one sees some of the people and considers the role that they have played and their background, one is very doubtful as to them having been 'used'.

SPEECH.PARA: Other groups known to be supporting the protest include the Movement Against Uranium Mining and Friends of the Earth-both boasted of being the main groups behind the main groups behind the Roxby Downs attempted blockade-the Women's Housing Co-operative, of Sydney, Women Against Violent Exploitation, that is WAVE, Feminist Anti-Nuclear groups, that is, FANG, and various ALP groups. The Young Women's Christian Association in Alice Springs provided it facilities, including its telephone and its conference room, and appeared to be be the headquarters for the demonstration.

This material provides strong evidence, and I invite people to read it, that the forces ultimately behind the network of the radicial Left feminist group at Pine Gap were the Australian communist parties and the front organisations serving the interests of the Soviet Union. It is part of a well-financed, co- ordinated and ongoing campaign orchestrated ultimately from outside Australia. That has been admitted by various people within the peace demonstration, who have said that its roots have come from overseas. This well financed, co- ordinated and ongoing campaign has been stepped up to force the Hawke Government to break with the United States, to deny the Americans bases on our soil and to deny access by their naval vessels to our ports. The Press and the Government have a responsibility, I believe, to make this information known to the Australian people. What I am saying is that it was not one of those casual demonstrations, it was very well organised. As I said once before, I suggest that interested people should see these cuttings in association with my remarks. They are most interesting.

Just to clear up one or two matters very quickly; there are other things I wish to say, but not tonight. I was very interested to see an article in the Centralian Advocate of 23 November 1983 headed 'Aboriginal women ''talked into demo'' ', which stated:
Aboriginal women who took part in the Pine Gap Demonstration were talked into it, according to a prominent Aranda woman, Betty Pearce.
She is a most respected local Aboriginal person. The article continues:
Ms Pearce said Aboriginal women who took part would not have had a deep enough understanding of the Pine Gap issue to make a decision on their own.
She said the issues of world peace and nuclear disarmament were not fully explained to the women.
Ms Pearce said: 'When the protestors leave there will be confusion among the Aboriginal women who went to the protest.
One hundred Pitjantjatjara and Luritja women attended Pine Gap during the demonstrations.'
It is believed the women were brought in from surrounding areas by bus, Ms Pearce said.

That, in itself, is most interesting. I would like to see the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) look into this aspect of how and why it was that Aboriginal women were brought in, quite obviously not knowing what the game was all about. The article goes on:
'Most Aboriginal women have no concept of what the protest is about.
Part of the Aboriginal culture is violence.
Our culture is controlled by the payback system.
Aboriginal culture has had to be violent to survive all these thousands of years.
Peace as preached by the local and visiting Pine Gap protestors is not the Aboriginal way'.
This is the word of a very well-known local Aboriginal person. The article concludes:
'It also seems farcical because I have been threatened in an underhand manner that if I don't keep my big mouth shut I will be beaten up,' Ms Pearce said.

Very interesting. Knowing the person, I believe her. Before the Senate rose a week or so ago I asked the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) whether he would look into the possible misuse of funds and vehicles by the Central Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service during the demonstration at Pine Gap. I have not received any answer from the Attorney and I ask again: Is the Attorney able to answer my queries and, in light of the complaints, has the matter been investigated? If not, is it the intention of the Government to review the matter ? That is not much to ask.

Another matter on which I wish to speak very briefly also relates to the demonstration. I refer to the report of the Human Rights Commission inquiry into police treatment of women at the Women for Survival protest at Pine Gap. I believe the report casts a slur on members of the Northern Territory Police because it lists allegations against them, yet gives no indication as to whether or not these allegations have any foundation. The allegations are extremely serious. I believe the police have every right-surely they must have human rights too-to ask that the investigation be completed as a matter of urgency so that this slur on them can be lifted.

Very many matters relating to the demonstration should be investigated, particularly to give the police the opportunity to be cleared of those serious charges. I draw the attention of authorities to the way directional microphones were used. I refer to the complaints made to the Human Rights Commission, and ask that the Attorney ensure that every complaint made is properly investigated. I believe, and I forecast, that when this report is placed in the hands of the Attorney-General, the Northern Territory Police will be completely cleared. That leaves one matter. Do people have the right to make complaints in the way in which these complaints have been made? I suggest that these complaints have been engineered. I leave them to the authorities to look at.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with considerable interest to what Senator Kilgariff had to say. I am particularly able to speak in reply to some of the comments he made because I did visit Pine Gap. I am amazed at some of the things he said, and I am amazed because of the way he in fact used the very tactics about which he was complaining. For instance, in the very early part of his speech he used the word 'mob' many times in relation to the women. That is a very gentle way of speaking, if one likes, and is nicely inflammatory, but he was doing exactly what he protested that the women were doing.

SPEECH.PARA: I would say Senator Kilgariff has a different understanding of what happened at Pine Gap than the understanding with which I came away. There were many more than 200 protestors. Some women came and went, even during the time I was there, for the eight days of the camp's life. While I was there there were 200 women that I could count. There may have been a few more, but I counted those women while we were attending a film. At that stage we were gathered in rows watching the film; so it was a fairly accurate assessment of the number of people there.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were about 550 to 600, and the genuine ones left very quickly.

—I prefer to make my assessment on what I saw. The women came and the women left, so many more than 200 would have been there over the time of the camp. I had the opportunity to meet with and speak with many of the women who were there. I can assure the Senate that they were not a mob of wild, radical leftist feminists. Many of them were what one could call grandmothers. Some of them claimed to be grandmothers; they were certainly of a grandmotherly age. There were young women, teenagers, women from alternative communes and women from academia. There were office workers and teachers, doctors, nurses, lawyers, housewives and the well-publicised nuns.

SPEECH.PARA: Many of those women had made the free choice to come to Pine Gap because of the passion that they felt about the issue. They are terribly concerned, as many people in the world are, about the issue of peace. I think it is a matter of real interest that the public participation in peace demonstrations around the world has enormously increased in the last year or so. While there may be in any of those demonstrations a small group of people who are there for their own mischievous reasons, I cannot believe that one million people in a demonstration in Holland were all mischievous and were all stoolies in the pay of the Soviet Government. I do not accept that interpretation in regard to the people involved in peace and I do not accept that interpretation in regard to the majority of women who went to Pine Gap.

I also wish to make some comment on a few of the other things Senator Kilgariff mentioned. The Young Women's Christian Association in Alice Springs did provide a room for the women as their town base. When asked why it provided the room, the YWCA said: 'We provide sanctuary for women'. I think that is a most appropriate answer. I can also tell the Senate that I have a brother and sister- in-law living in Alice Springs and those people are fairly actively involved with some of the community there. On the Saturday preceding my visit there they took part in and actively campaigned for a peace demonstration in Alice Springs because a number of men from Alice Springs were unable to go to Pine Gap by reason of their sex. Some 200 people went to the peace demonstration in Alice Springs. I think that this has probably not been reported, and certainly Senator Kilgariff did not allude to it.

There was and still is wide concern about matters of peace and nuclear disarmament in the world. The Australian women, in establishing the camp at Pine Gap, were representative of the Australian people who feel very strongly about that. Certainly there were some radical feminists who went to that camp and certainly there were some very non-radical women. There were women from the whole spectrum of attitudes and values who were there principally because of their concern for peace and their legitimate fear about the possibility of nuclear war. I think that needs to be stressed. There is an increasing reportage in papers-if one likes, a real hyping up-on matters of nuclear war, nuclear arms and so on. I do not wish to criticise the reporters for the majority of the copy that they have put in newspapers over recent times. I think for a variety of reasons, particularly the change of balance of nulcear power in Europe, the matters of nuclear war and the increase in nuclear arms have made the prospect of nuclear war very much more real and more alive. I think these matters have been the subject of factual reportage in the majority of papers.

Many people reading those reports can confuse those facts with fear-mongering. I think it is not a matter of fear-mongering but it is true that the facts can engender fear in many people. I think that is only right and proper. Nuclear war is a matter of terrible fear. It is also a problem that we have to address, and I think it is not constructive to put the argument as Senator Kilgariff has. I think the assertions he has made tonight are wild and I do not think they address the very real and very rational fears that people have in response to these facts. If we are going to look at the issues, I suggest we need to look at them in a calm way but also acknowledge that people really do have fear and that that is a proper and appropriate response to the prospect of nuclear holocaust. We need to address that fear too, but we do not do it by wild innuendo and assertions.

I think the other important thing that the Pine Gap camp did was to bring home to the Australian people the importance and the power of women in this country who are concerned about matters of peace, who established that camp in solidarity with the women at Greenham Common and with the peace movement around the world. I think that they achieved a remarkable effect and they also achieved a remarkably effective camp-about that I can speak from first-hand knowledge. The women were somewhat delighted at the discovery they had made of their own strength. Certainly the camp was very effective and very neatly and efficiently run. There was fresh water and fresh fruit and vegetables and there were adequate facilities. For the eight days that the camp had been running before I arrived it had been running very effectively. I think we ought not to be distracted from the principal issue of that camp by the questions and some of the issues that Senator Kilgariff raised. The purpose of the camp was to make nuclear weapons and the prospect of nuclear war a matter of public debate in Australia. That is terribly important at a time when Cruise and Pershing missiles are being deployed in Europe to counter the previously deployed SS20s put in the Eastern sector by the Russians. While the Americans and the Russians talk of a reduction of nuclear arms, and while they talk of the need for peace, they have both increased their arsenals. I find that much more evocative of fear and I find it very hard to believe their claims in the face of the evidence of those increasing weapons.

The women of Australia feel that it is very important to have made a statement about this increase of nuclear arms, and that is what they did when they went to Pine Gap. They went there too because they appreciate that Pine Gap is a possible nuclear target in a nuclear war. I think that is widely held to be true by a majority of people in Australia.

There are many things that could be said but I cannot answer all of Senator Kilgariff's points. I am proud of the Australian women for what they achieved at the camp. I think they did take the debate to the public and I think they have made it an issue of public debate throughout Australia. While some people are antagonistic, I think the majority of people are thoughtful or quiet about it. Of course, some people are quiet because they wish to bury their fear, and other people are quiet because they feel impotent in the face of the evidence that, no matter how one protests, the Americans and the Russians increase their arsenals.

But I think, no matter what, the Pine Gap camp caused nuclear arms and the prospect of nuclear war to be talked about throughout Australia. I think the ordinary community voice that has been raised around the world, to which the Pine Gap camp contributed, will continue for goodness knows how long, but I think most of those people committed to peace are aware that, until the military industrial complex from either side gets the message, they will continue their peace campaigning. Pine Gap was part of an historical process. I think it is a matter of pride for Australia and it certainly is a matter of pride for me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —More out of deference to the very heavy demands being made on the kitchen and dining room staff than for any other reason I will endeavour to be brief. I just want to touch on a couple of matters which were raised on the adjournment by Senator Reynolds. She is no longer here and because of that I will temper my remarks. Because some of the other things I wish to mention touch on the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and he is not here either, I will also temper my remarks in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Reynolds raised her dealings with the Total company and complained about that company seeking to silence her and or threatening legal action against her. In the course of that she mentioned certain matters which had been raised in the Mining Warden's Court in, I think she said, 1979, and some criticisms which were made on the environmental aspects of that particular mining proposal. It just happens that the company made available to me, and indeed to the general public, a statement of 14 November on the Ben Lomond environment study. I seek leave to table the statement made by the company on that date which refers to the mining warden's comments and makes certain other comments about the work which has been done pursuant to those remarks and about the company's view of the environmental situation at present.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to seek leave to table the rather massive full environmental impact study, which was reissued by the company at the same time it issued that statement which I have just tabled, merely because it seems to me we have an enormous pile of paper accumulating and I doubt whether it will be called upon. I simply say that it is available and it is, of course, a document on which public comment can be made. That is an important part of the quite detailed arrangements which exist throughout Australia to ensure that environmental and other matters are given full and public consideration before projects of this sort proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: The other point I want to touch on really arose out of the nature of the complaint which Senator Reynolds made about the fact that she felt an attempt was being made to silence her. I think that does raise an important question of principle which probably needs to be canvassed in the Senate. I do not adopt Senator Reynold's view at all and I do not on the other hand seek to take the part of the company. I think that is a matter in which one would have to look at the material and see whether there was any justification for the complaint which the honourable senator made. But I remind the Senate of the very significant complaints which are being made, not just by the Opposition but also by the commentators who I think have some standing in the community, about the readiness of the present Government to seek to gag free speech where that is uncomfortable for them. In particular, I would like to refer to a couple of articles which, although written with some force, I think repay consideration. They are written by a man who I think is a lawyer; certainly, he has legal training. He is a journalist who has worked in Australia and overseas, Mr Robert Pullan. He published a couple of articles in the National Times of 25 November which caught my attention and which touch on the matter of principle Senator Reynolds has raised. The first article, which is headed 'The Gagging of Australia', relates to the proposed uniform defamation law. Again, because I do not wish to delay the Senate, I merely read from the first paragraph. Mr Pullan wrote:

Australia's defamation laws now impose the most comprehensive gags on free speech in the common-law world. Attorney-General Senator Gareth Evans' new bill, which is intended to form the basis of a uniform defamation law, will substantially tighten them.

He goes on to make a great deal of detailed comment on that. In a second article in the same publication the same writer comments on the attempts made by various members of the Government to prevent free speech by political opponents and others. I remind the Senate that it was the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) who sought to censor Mr Andrew Peacock, the Leader of the Opposition, because he made some comments about what was happening in the Hope Royal Commission. There was a threat from the Prime Minister who said that what Mr Peacock had said was wrong and defamatory. He said that the Government's counsel would submit to Mr Justice Hope that Peacock's statement was in contempt of the Commission and ' needs to be dealt with'. We all know now, as is pointed out by Mr Pullan, that that resulted in several newspapers withdrawing items from publication. We all know that although there was a complaint before the Commission, no attempt was actually made to commit Mr Peacock, but I think all of us should stop and consider the actions of the Prime Minister. He sought to prevent debate on what I think is an important political issue. It is important not only in the view of the Opposition, but also in the view of some members of the Government, certainly Senator Bolkus.

Other matters referred to by Mr Pullan include the fact that Mr Hawke had libel writs out against the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the Sydney Morning Herald and Time magazine for reports which allegedly ruined his reputation. Of course, as Mr Pullan points out, Mr Hawke is enjoying an astonishingly high approval rating from the public; so it is a bit hard to see that his reputation has actually been destroyed by these articles. Mr Pullan also points out:
Finance Minister John Dawkins has referred to his solicitor a joke made by Deputy Opposition Leader John Howard during a recent division . . .
The Minister for Communications, Michael Duffy, has begun a suit over a Brisbane report alleging interference in the ABC coverage of the Queensland election.

Attorney-General Gareth Evans has recanted his observation while in Opposition that a Freedom of Information Act giving ministers the power to certify documents exempt from the act was not worth having. He told Parliament that he now believes that it would be 'premature' to amend the act to make it worth having.

Other things are stated, but I think I have given enough of the background to say that when a Government senator raises this question, it raises a much broader question than the rights of senators to proceed in a way which they believe perhaps exempts them from the laws which apply to other citizens. I think it is important that we consider what are quite difficult questions, particularly now that the Attorney-General has produced a uniform defamation proposal that we address the question of principle which has been raised by Senator Reynolds. I have as thin a skin as the next man and perhaps thinner than most, but I have come to the reluctant conclusion that one has to suffer a lot of slings and arrows in the game of politics. I think that the matter raised by Senator Reynolds is one that should not be raised as an isolated instance which affects simply a company threatening senators' free speech. It is an issue in which politicians are all too ready to threaten the free speech of others.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the question of holding of meetings of committees or parliamentary groups such as the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association during the time that the Parliament is sitting. I appreciate that the Parliament has problems at present because of the different hours that the House of Representatives sits from those when the Senate sits. I understand that problem and it will be even more awkward in the future to organise appropriate meetings. I found myself today committed to a meeting of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Executive at 6 p.m. while debate on the Commonwealth Electoral Legislation Amendments Bill was proceeding in this chamber. Obviously, that Bill was of vital interest to me and to many other honourable senators. The Bill was at the Committee stage and, quite frankly, we needed not only to be present but also to be alert as to the particular clauses. I found myself in the situation of leaving the chamber for a couple of reasons, one of which was to register my apology to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association executive for not being able to attend. When I got back to my place in the chamber I was rather confused and found that an important clause, that regarding the registration of group tickets, had been carried. I latched on to another part of the Bill, clause 80. I had it in the back of my mind that I needed to speak on this matter because it is one which will substantially disadvantage me in any election that I might run in in Tasmania or any group which I might run in an election in Tasmania. I know that I cannot canvas the earlier debate. I am simply positing the suggestion that it will be discriminatory against me or my group and favourable to only two groups in the list system of voting. I am now in a position of having to seek leave tomorrow, or whenever we are to discuss the Bill, to have that clause re-submitted. When I stood in my place I was of the view that the substantive clause came later in the Bill. That is how confused I was. But I make the point that I believe I would not have been in that situation had I not felt I should, as a matter of courtesy, proceed to the meeting that was being held at the same time as the Bill was being considered in this place to apologise for my absence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reply first to Senator Harradine, while it is in my mind. I understand the difficulty and the controversy in this place about parliamentary committees meeting while the Parliament is sitting. I merely make the comment that the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association is a voluntary organisation of parliamentarians. I am not a member. What that voluntary organisation does and when it sits is really not up to this Parliament, not is it anything to do with this Parliament. It is up to that organisation. I think the honourable senator's redress in that situation is with the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. But I accept the fact that at other times we have had problems with the Public Accounts Committee and with other committees meeting while the Parliament is sitting. That is a matter for the Standing Orders Committee, I believe.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter which comes to mind is the matter raised by Senator Haines and Senator Macklin. It is something that I have heard many times before in this place. In fact, I have been in the situation of being on a parliamentary delegation and being acutely embarrassed by the sorts of gifts which are provided by the Australian Parliament in those circumstances. I am particularly distressed by the situation Senator Haines mentioned, because Felipe Gonzalez happens to be a friend of mine and I have many friends in the Spanish Government . I make two points. First, it is my understanding and my memory that it is up to the secretary of a delegation and the president of a delegation to choose the gifts, although at certain times I understand that the choice as to what is available in this place is pretty limited. One is tempted to say that it in fact is, and should be, the responsibility of the members of the delegation to make sure that the gifts are adequate. But I add one proviso. I am afraid that I and many of my colleagues are probably the worst people in the world to make choices of that kind. Therefore I must say that I have sympathy with Senator Macklin's view that we should have some formal method of selecting such gifts to make sure that they are appropriate, coming from Australia, and are of appropriate value; and also to ensure that, if possible, they reflect proper taste-I suppose that is the expression to use. In fact, I thought that the previous Government had gone some way along the track in doing that. I was under the impression that it had made some arrangements to overhaul this system of providing gifts, but clearly it had not.

Perhaps I could briefly inform the Senate that the worst episode of which I have heard concerned a delegation which, during a visit to a foreign country, had with it a person who was a combined interpreter, guide and bodyguard for 10 days and it was left to the Australian staff in the Embassy or High Commission to choose a gift for that person. To the horror of the members of the delegation , he was presented with a book on Australian venomous insects and a pair of Australian woollen socks. I agree with Senators Haines, Macklin and Kilgariff that something ought to be done about it and I will certainly pass their comments on to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I have very little comment to make on the speeches of Senators Reynolds and Chaney. I was not present for most of the time during which Senator Reynolds was speaking, so I do not know the details of what she said. The matters that Senator Chaney raises, concerning the laws of defamation and libel, are matters that I believe should be debated much more widely, by people who have had more preparation and expertise than I have been able to gain tonight.

As for Senator Kilgariff's contribution, all I can say is that it is of the kind that we have heard in this country and in this place over the years. It indicates, I suppose, that in some ways nothing changes. He used what I consider to be an unfortunate tactic by first producing in this place and tabling a series of some 16 cuttings from newspapers. Those that were recognisable came largely from newspapers such as News Weekly and various propaganda publications of the Left and the Right. I believe that a couple came from the Australian but others were from papers which were not marked. We had no idea where they came from. They seemed to me to represent expressions of opinion. Secondly, the honourable senator went on to condemn everyone who had taken part in the Franklin River protest and the Pine Gap protest as Marxists, as communist stooges, in the pay of the communists. However, I notice, for instance, that the list he documented included such people as Mum Shirl, whom I have heard, in a most articulate, profound and devout manner, talk about her religious beliefs. There were organisations from various churches and other organisations which included the Young Women's Christian Association in Alice Springs. It is a silly tactic to claim, first of all, that all the people who were there were in fact marxists-part of the marxist circus, I think he called it. Secondly, for anyone to suggest that everyone who went there had his or her expenses paid by the Soviet Union or anyone else is as ludicrous as the utterances of those on the Left who consider that everything that happens that they do not like is paid for by the Central Intelligence Agency or the United States of America.

I just remind Senator Kilgariff that that is the sort of thing that was said about those who, in the early days, were protesting about what was going on in Vietnam. It certainly could not have been said, with truth, about the vast majority of those people in this country who ended up agreeing with them, or of the large numbers who took part in the moratorium march. I do not think that it helps the debate in this place to apply that sort of label to everyone who, rightly or wrongly, whether one agrees with them or not, takes part in protests or demonstrations, any more than it is right to blame everyone in those demonstrations or protests for the actions of a few who may not have done the right thing or who may have acted in other than a proper or civilised manner; but I suppose that sort of debate will go on here for a long, long time.

The remarks of Senator Crowley I have not mentioned because she quite effectively answered many of the comments that were made by Senator Kilgariff. In fact, she stated in a clearer, more concise and terse way some of the things that I said. I will refer the specific questions which Senator Kilgariff asked at the end of his speech, about the complaints against the police in Alice Springs, to the relevant Minister and hope to be able to get an answer concerning them in the near future.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the matter raised by Senator Harradine, might I say that as one of the joint chairmen, along with Mr Speaker, of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, I can inform him that it was absolutely essential that a meeting of the executive of the Association be held this year before this sessional period concluded. It was hoped that we might be able to hold the meeting either at lunchtime or during a dinner adjournment on one day or evening next week but, as it turned out, either Mr Speaker or myself, or both of us, will be caught up during the whole of next week. It was found to be absolutely impossible, it being expected of course that it would be the last week of the session for the House of Representatives. Because of party and parliamentary committee sittings it was felt that the most convenient time to call the meeting would be this evening.

INTERJECT.PARA: The meeting was due to commence at 6 p.m., but as it was just about to get under way, as Senator Harradine might recall, the Senate was sitting as the Committee of the Whole and a division was called. That meant that the start of the meeting was delayed for some time. In fact, the meeting did not get under way until just before 6.30 p.m., which was, of course, the time for the dinner adjournment of the House of Representatives. However, what Senator Harradine has said has been taken on board by me and I will draw it to the attention of the executive officers of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association.

So far as the remarks of Senators Haines and Macklin are concerned, I do not know whether the gifts that they took with them came from the hospitality section of the Prime Minister's Department, or from this Parliament, but so far as the Inter-Parliamentary Union is concerned-the vote for that organisation comes within the vote of the Senate-I have already asked the officers of the Australian IPU branch to provide me with a list of the gifts presently available so that it can be revised. It has now in fact been provided and if Senators Haines and Macklin have any suggestions as to other types of gifts that should be provided they might let the officers of the Inter-Parliamentary Union have such suggestions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 3 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government intend to resume talks with Indonesia concerning the delineation of maritime boundaries as more than two years have elapsed since the last round of negotiations; if so, when.
(2) What are the outstanding issues needing clarification in these Australia/ Indonesia negotiations.

(3) Will the Governments of Western Australia and the Northern Territory be invited to contribute to the next round of talks with Indonesia, due to the considerable interest which settlement of the outstanding issues will arouse.

(4) Will the Government press for a treaty covering mineral exploration rights in the area of sea bed between East Timor and Australia known as the 'Timor Gap' which includes a highly prospective area for petroleum resources-the kelp structure, as well as law of the sea matters.
(5) What is the present situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. We are ready to hold further rounds of discussions as soon as the Indonesian side is ready. No date has yet been fixed.
(2) The outstanding issues are:
(a) the delimitation of continental shelf jurisdiction in those areas not already covered by existing agreements;
(b) the location of permanent sea boundaries for other jurisdictional purposes, such as existing and future exclusive economic zones.

Sea bed boundary agreements with Indonesia were signed by Australia in 1971 and 1972. These agreements determined the boundary in the Arafura Sea and in the area south of West Timor. The boundary further west was left for later talks. A gap was also left in the boundary south of what was then Portuguese Timor. Between 1979 and 1981 four rounds of inconclusive discussions were held between Indonesian and Australian Officials to consider, amongst other things, drawing a sea bed boundary in the area of what has become known as the 'Timor Gap'.
(3) The governments of Western Australia and the Northern Territory have been, and will continue to be, closely involved in the boundary discussions with Indonesia.

(4) It can be expected that the next round of discussions will be concerned primarily with negotiating a sea bed boundary in the Timor Gap. Such a boundary would delimit control over the resources of the sea bed and subsoil.
(5) The present situation is as I have described it above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs , upon notice, on 24 August:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Australian Government write to the United States Government expressing its deep concern at all expenditure on chemical weapons in view of a report in the Washington Post that the Reagan Government is seeking a total of $114m for binary chemical artillery shells and equipment and chemicals for Bigeye binary bombs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The United States Administration's request for funds for the production of binary chemical weapons has been one of the most controversial aspects of its proposals for defence funding for FY 1984. In mid-September, Congress approved the 1984 Defence Authorisation Bill which provided $114.8m for the production of binary chemical munitions, including artillery shells and aerial bombs. In the final consideration of the 1984 Defence Appropriation Bill in mid November, however, this item was deleted, which means that the Administration will not be able to proceed with its plans for binary nerve gas production in FY 1984.

United States spokesmen, including Defence Secretary Weinberger in his Fiscal Year 1984 Report to Congress, justified the Administration's wish to proceed with the production of binary weapons in terms of the need to reduce the Soviet Union's incentive to use chemical weapons against the United States or its allies by rebuilding and maintaining an adequate US chemical warfare capability. Secretary Weinberger's report states that the Soviet Union possesses a considerable advantage in chemical warfare capabilities and that notwithstanding a unilateral decision by the United States in 1969 to halt production of chemical weapons, efforts to achieve a bilateral agreement between 1977 and 1980 with the Soviet Union to ban chemical weapons were fruitless. It notes that current efforts to obtain a ban on chemical weapons are centred in the Committee on Disarmament and reiterates that a complete and verifiable ban on chemical weapons remains the United States goal.

The Australian Government finds the concept of chemical warfare abhorrent and the use of chemical weapons repugnant. It is committed to the conclusion of a fully effective and verifiable convention that would outlaw the use of chemicals as weapons in armed conflict and would ensure the destruction of all existing stocks of chemical weapons. It is actively pursuing this objective in the Committee on Disarmament in Geneva. Australian views on chemical weapons have been made known to the United States and other governments on a number of occasion both bilaterally and in multilateral fora such as the Committee on Disarmament.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 19 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there specific regulations for the acceptance and wearing of foreign awards.
(2) When were such regulations adopted.
(3) When was a review of such regulations initiated and when is that review expected to be completed.

(4) Do countries conferring awards to Australian citizens have to go through authorities in the United Kingdom; if so, what is the reason for this and will this particular aspect of the Regulations be altered.
(5) Why are there regulations which prevent Australian citizens being entitled to awards conferred upon them by an overseas country without interference by Australian or any other authority.
(6) Will the Government consider returning to a situation which applied before 1972, that is, no regulations in this area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia has adopted the United Kingdom Regulations governing the acceptance and wearing of foreign awards.
(2) In 1930 with revisions in 1954, 1958 and 1969.

(3) The need for Australia to have separate regulations has been considered in the past. A review of the operation of the regulations is currently being undertaken. Completion of this will depend on various consultations.

(4) A foreign government wishing to confer an award on an Australian citizen is required to forward a request for approval through official diplomatic channels. The Special Minister of State, as the Minister responsible for advising the Government on honours and awards, considers the request and forwards a recommendation through the Governor-General to The Queen, as the Head of State and Queen of Australia. There is no role for the United Kingdom Government or its authorities in this procedure.

(5) In providing that Australian citizens should not accept a foreign award without the permission of Her Majesty as Queen of Australia, the regulations reflect the fundamental principle that the Head of State is the fount of honours for the citizens of that country.
(6) As mentioned in (2), the regulations with revisions have applied in Australia since 1930. The Government will consider its position on the regulations on completion of the current review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 November 1983.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have Australian P3C Orion ASW aircraft ever used the facilities at Diego Garcia in the Indian Ocean.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Since 1976 Royal Australian Air Force P3 Orion aircraft have occasionally staged through Diego Garcia while undertaking routine maritime surveillance operations and long range navigation training flights. Such transits currently take place about nine times a year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 15 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many civilians have been: (a) killed; and (b) injured in Granada due to the US invasion.
(2) How many people are being held as prisoners in camps.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) According to United States figures, 45 Grenadian civilians were killed and 337 injured during the recent intervention in Grenada.
(2) Cuban casualties included 25 killed and 57 wounded.

(3) It is understood that about 50 persons continue to be held in detention in Grenada and that these people are to be charged. This information has not been confirmed with the Grenadian authorities but it is considered to be accurate.
